reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was excited to get this game - Civ4 was my favorite civ and so I expected a lot from Soren Johnson.

This is a much more accessible game than Civ. The complete lack of a combat system revolutionizes the RTS genre and feels alien, yet the core mechanics can be understood within 30-45 minutes of play. The interaction of the game sytems is complex, and mastery and strategy will take a lot of time to develop.

You play one of four factions, each with different bonuses and penalties. It is vital to play to your factions strengths, because you are severely resource constrained and must make difficult decisions about how to expand.

You interact with other factions in five ways: the map, auctions, the stock market, the black market, and the market.

On the map, you compete for resources and tile placement. Taking a key tile from another player can be enormously damaging by preventing adjacency bonuses.

In auctions, you bid against other players for a special bonus. This is the most head-to-head" aspect of the game. Depending on game options
date: you are not constrained to bidding with cash on hand. Instead
recommended: you can go into debt to purchase the item. If you arent careful
hoursPlayed: you might win an auction to your overal detriment.\n\nOn the black market
voteText: you purchase attack powers. These seem to suck
helpfulPercent: though perhaps I just don't understand how to use them effectively yet. You are very rate limited in how quickly you can purchase these powers
votesHelpful: they go up in price quickly
votesTotal: and they are usually very weak. Disabling a tile for 60 seconds is painful
votesFunny: but doesnt seem to be enough to cause any long term damage.\n\nOn the stock market
commentsCount: you buy and sell ownership stakes in each player's faction. You win by forcibly buying out the other players.\n\nAnd finally the market. You buy and sell resources
column16: and your actions affect the price of the resource. In my view
column17: a critical weakness of the game is that the market supplies unlimited resources. Resources are not supplied by other players; instead
column18: the market steadily raises prices. One consequence of this is that there is no resource tech race - you can buy any resources at the start of the game
column19: which really break the idea that you are a startup colony on mars. You also get no real benefit from being the first to supply another resource.\n\nThe game also gives you very limited insight into the price elasticity of demand - how much price will change in response to a purchase or sale. This is probably because there isn't a "real" market system. In order to allow you to buy an unlimited amount of resources on the market
column20: the game must model its own price elasticity of demand curve. This is contrived and can fall out of sync with the specifics of each game. You also have no insight into the global supply of a given resource - there is no way to answer the question "Is this resource cheap because no one needs it or because everyone is producing a surplus?" Perhaps if you had some way to view the global aggregate stockpile of each resource
column21: this could be improved.\n\nBecause of the way the market functions and the lack of insight into its details
column22: it doesn't quite feel like you are playing with other players. Again
column23:
maybe this is just due to my inexperience.

There are a couple UI issues:
* An easy way to see the space market price for goods.
* An easy way to find your buildings/tiles on the map.
* Graphics performance is ok

but not good.


Overall
column25: I'm still pretty excited about this game. Its a new idea in RTS. It greatly reduces micromanagement compared to other RTS. It needs polish
column26: but I think its going to make for some amazing multiplayer matches.\n\n"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You *might* like this game if :

You are into very simple economic games
Like short games
Are into realistic sci-fi themes

You won't like this game if :
You like to sink your teeth into empire / engine building
Find economic games boring
You like direct in your face interaction between players

In the notes for this game the designer states it was his goal to create a short playing economic RTS - Starcraft based around trading not fighting if you will. A New Kind of RTS.

Uh huh. Well, they've certainly succeeded. But does it work ? And is it actually new ?

In the main it does not work and is not actually new. When you stop and look at what it's doing you realise it's not that far away from any of the Railroad Tycoon games - except there is no railroad building or locomotive managing here.

So that comparison bears some inspection. In RT you ship goods around to make money, buy stocks, bid on auctioned inventions, buy industries all in a goal to buy out your opponents.

In OTC you ship goods around to make money, buy stocks, bid on auctioned things all in a goal to buy out your opponents.

Sound familiar ?

The difference here ( apart from one being set on a green playing field and one being set on a red playing field ! ) is that whilst in RT the shipping and management of that shipping forms a large part of the challenge in the game, in OFC its abstracted - build your resource producing building, and you're done. The shipping just happens".

With the shipping abstracted the challenge in the game for a player lies elsewhere. But. Uh. Where ? Choosing what building to build next ? That's it ?

What's left is a very thin game - one which comes down to cracking the (simple) puzzle of what build order you should build buildings in - whether to skip some
date: concentrate in others and so on. In fact this is pretty much the economical part of the RT games. There's literally nothing else to do in OTC however - apart from a bit of sabotage
recommended:
which by and large comes down to paying X dollars to knock out Y building for Z seconds. Call it an EMP blast. Dynamite. An uprising. The upshot is largely the same.

Given a relatively simple resource / building tree in the game ( it's a short game ) there is no complexity there either in figuring out what sneaky specialisations you can bust out or great economical wizardry you can pull off. This is definitely at the lighter end of the resource manipulation gaming tree.

Also

reviewText:
THIS REVIEW IS OUTDATED - It covered the first version of the Early Access Release.
-----------------------------------------------------------------


This Review is negative, but judging the potential of further development in, it could be positive for the finished game. It is made shortly after the early access release on steam and it might get updated at a later point.
-----------------------------------------------------------------

The first thing you need to know is that this game is not an economic strategy build-your-empire game, like the Anno games or Railroad Tycoon, or certain lesser well known games in that niche. This game is not slow, and the building up your empire part is pretty shallow compared to other such games.

But what is it then?

Its a kinda unique thing, the closest game to compare it to is probably M.U.L.E. from the 80´s, but as i never played that myself, i cant say how much it resembles this old classic. It is a real-time economics strategy game, on the backdrop of Mars.

So the mechanics are that you build up your base (one of 4 factions) by upgrading it, harvesting different resources and processing them into other products plus eventual doing research and managing the black market, all while competing with several other players for the market and resources. Your aim is to make huge profits and buy out your competitors on the stock market while they try to do the same.


What state is it in? (15-02-2015)

It is a well functioning Beta product at the point of writing this i would say. There are issues with the pacing of the game and with the gameplay itself. I also had 2 or 3 crashes within my playtime. I did not try the Multiplayer part yet.

The most aggravating thing right now is the buyout mechanic, in which the AI just piles up the money and then all of a sudden within a few moments buys up all your stock, which means Game Over" to you. There are popup warnings about those stock buyouts
date: but most often they simply happen too fast to prevent them.\n\nOverall the game feels not much fun to me right now. The tutorials are a joke

reviewText:
Offworld Trading Company is an economy building simulator, set in a sci-fi futuristic space setting. The game exited Early Access on April 28th 2016. The game had been in early access for a little over a year, after initially being released in February 2015. With the developers being constantly updating the game over the past year, the game exits the process in a really strong position.

The game’s introduction tutorial is very in depth but still guides you through the processes within the game in a helpful manner. To begin with I felt a little overwhelmed with all of the numbers, UI functions and other mechanics in the game, but thankfully this tutorial is one of the best I’ve seen in a long while.  The game play itself is essentially make as much money as you can, using trade markets, sabotaging your opponents and espionage.  The game takes place on Mars, there are no combat mechanics or forceful attacks to use on your opponents, and only through economy gain can you wipe them off your planet.  The tutorial consist of 7 missions, each having their own individual objective which differs from a standard skirmish mode, where your ultimate goal is to just beat your opponent by purchasing all of their stock.  The game’s campaign mode also offers a different set of objectives, but you also get to make a few choices which effect in game numbers, such as more jobs, and bonus money.

This is quite possibly one of the most in-depth games I have ever had the chance of playing. It is certainly a very deep rabbit hole you can get yourself into. Your company’s share price is affected by everything you do on a mission, meaning you always run the risk of a hostile takeover from your opponent.  If you like watching the stock markets and crunching numbers, you may just have met your perfect match already.

Visually, OTC looks really slick and clean.  The game’s hardware requirements are low, given that resolutions higher than 1080 are not supported sadly. The game’s models are all really interestingly designed. Mars itself is perfectly presented, with a real rustic feel to it. A little unknown fact about the game is that the maps you play on are actually based off the real red planet itself.  A smooth animation of units also tips everything off nicely. Honestly it is just a real treat to sit back and watch your economy grow with this aesthetically pleasing game.

Given the amount of detail that has gone into the game play in OTC, the difficulty levels really depend on how well you get to grips with the system. If you are able to pick up all of the processes, build orders, and able to study the numbers in front of you to a T, then the game will be just about challenging enough. If you are like me and even after the well-designed tutorial you still found yourself struggling to comprehend the amount of information being thrown at you, then you may be in for a bumpy ride. The difficulty ceiling is not a bad thing at all – this is obviously a game for a very specific market of people.

The tutorial section of the game, as well as the skirmishes afterwards, took me just over three hours to complete. I am about a quarter of the way through the campaign currently but I am starting to hit that virtual brick all, where my opponents are just too clever for me to be able to progress further. The game’s online modes, as well as single player skirmishes allow for an endless amount of replay ability.

Other than the game not allowing any higher resolutions than 1080p, I am pleased to say I had no technical issues. The game runs at a steady 60 FPS, and can even be capped at higher rates if your hardware allows it.

Offworld Trading Company is a fantastic niche title that will happily find a home in anyone’s library that has even a passing interest in any sort of economy. Like I said at the start, you can really find yourself in a deep rabbit hole with this, you can get so in depth with all of the different trade markets and stock prices that you may as well just take up a second job as a market broker afterwards. This is the first game in this genre that I have tried, and I already believe this to be the aiming point for any others wanting to break into the economy genre.  The regular retail price of £29,99 may price a few on the fence buyers, so some may want to find a cheaper re-seller online or wait for the sale season. People who want a game that will more than likely suck hours of time out of their life with an extremely in depth game play, you will find no better game out there at the moment than Offworld Trading Company.  Personally I am going to give this game a recommendation, purely because it isn’t my favourite genre in the world, but I want to give this game merit where it is due.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up. If you would also like to follow my reviews more easily, be sure to join my group by clicking here.

You may also be interested in checking out a PC gaming podcast, be sure to head here.

http://store.steampowered.com/app/271240

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really, really love this game. But nearly every single game, I get frustrated about the market mechanics. Bear in mind that this review is written based on beta as of Sept 2015.

The game bills itself as a market simulation, and yet the price mechanics of pretty much everything just seem wonky. As far as I can tell, resource prices are probably influenced by what the other players are buying/selling, but in both cases, they're not using a supply/demand system, but instead some formula that bumps the price up and down with every sale/purchase. The net result is that prices fluctuate dramatically over the course of the game (which is not bad, and could be actually good), but that you never really feel like you understand why.

The second part of this -- and the far more frustrating part -- is around the (current, as of Sept 2015) mechanics around winning, or buying out" your opponents. Firstly

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Revised 3/6/2016:

As SilvermistInc pointed out in the comments, I did stop playing the game before Beta 10 came out, but given the additional time I have since put into the game upon returning, I did change my review from negative to positive. Beta 10 didn't correct all of my original complaints, but an improved tutorial did explain some of the backstory and market dynamics the game uses without necessarily having to delve into the campaign like before.

I will say that this is a game that grows on you. You may not like it at first, but if you slow the game down to snail or even pause it while you are learning, you can get a better feel for the game mechanics. It gives that '5 more minutes' feel, and even though the rounds are short, you can walk away after a round feeling satisfied all the same.

Also, complacency isn't an option. Alot of RTS games seem to have recommended build trees/queues, that, when combined with overwhelming numbers, virtually gaurantee a victory every round. While this game has some of that, it keeps you on the edge of your seat constantly analyzing the market to determine the most profitable configuration. Someone who thinks they are going to win as long as their structures are profitable will be romped by the person who seeks to constantly *maximize* profits.

My main complaints are that: 1: An unintelligent 'auto-supply' toggle button that will purchase inputs for your buildings even if the output is unprofitable is illogical,  unusable (the game even warns that this could lead to rapid  bankruptcy), and annoying because not using it requires you to constantly click the 'buy' button yourself upon figuring out whether the output is indeed currently profitable. In short, you will be doing alot of clicking that could easily be avoided given a few improvements in the game's design. 2: A building's read-out displays the cost of power and fuel for the building, but it doesn't include those terms in a calculation of whether the building is profitable, leaving you to do simple but needlessly repetitive mental math to make the final determination. (It is not likely these things will change as it is getting too close to release. I have however had an extensive debate/conversation with Early Access users on the game's - not Steam's - forums regarding these concerns, so we can hope! I will update this review once the game is out of Early Access.)

Still, even with these reservations I have enjoyed my time playing the game. There are seemingly few other games on the market like this, and though I initially felt the game wasn't worth the $39.99 price tag (I bought it for $19.99 on sale - it is worth that much), if you go into it knowing a moderate investment of time might be necessary, it will reward you in ways that both few other games do and that make it well worth the asking price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-EARLY ACCESS REVIEW-

Before I continue writing this review I want to state that I'm more in the middle ground in terms whether or not I suggest this game.


GENERAL OVERVIEW

What is Offworld Trading Company? Simply put, Offworld Trading Company is a RTS without the conventional functions that we're used to seeing in RTSes today, that being a focus on military might and tactfulness. Instead of focusing on countering your enemies unit types and movements, maintaining map awareness and control, etc., you're in a race, so to speak, to survey the land of mars, identify what resources are rich and poor as well as what the best places to found are, figuring out the best way to maximize your profits while stiff-arming your opponents, and ultimately buying out their companies and declaring yourself the sole CEO of corporate mars. This is a lot easier said than done, of course, as there are lots of things that you need to be aware of and work around.

At the beginning of a match, the only thing you see on the map is the main trading hub and the tiles surrounding it, with the rest of the map covered in fog of war (you can see the terrain, in the fog of war, just not the resources that might be lying within the covered tiles). You start off with 6 scans" and gain another one every few seconds
date: You click on a tile that has already been exposed completely and the scan will further reveal tiles in a radius around it. If the border of your scan is near a resource that's hidden a yellow beam will extend from the tile it's in
recommended: and if you include the tile within your scan it will show you the tile's yield. As you begin to uncover the location's resources
hoursPlayed: you need to immediately begin figuring out how you want to start. For example
voteText: if you're finding the planet is heavy on iron
helpfulPercent: it might be wise to try playing as the Robotics or Expansionist division as steel is a major component for their progress and it will be something you will likely not have to deal with
votesHelpful: while on the other hand if iron is short you may want to choose Scavenger as they are not dependent on steel like the other divisions
votesTotal: and also try to snatch the iron and refuse to divulge supply so as to drive the price of steel up and make the competition pay through the nose in order to expand. You'll also want to make sure you do not found your colony too far from the resources you plan on claiming
votesFunny: as blimps use fuel to transport their goods
commentsCount: and if you have lots of long routes then your blimps will -absolutely- chew through your fuel reserves (or lack thereof).\n\nOnce you pick your division and landing spot
column16: it's time to start building. Your colony HQ will start at level one
column17: and you will have a handful of claims which are used to...well...claim tiles on the map
column18: which then allow you to build your production buildings. You will learn quickly that in order to thrive
column19: you need to amass claim rights so you can continue building production buildings and the resources which will give you what you need to expand your buildings as well as amass the capital you'll need to trade for goods you may not be able to produce and

column27: and auctions (which often becomes very expensive). Once you've amassed enough capital from the market you've so devilishly cornered

column32: and patents to name the main ones

but as for the basic gameplay that about covers it.


THE GOOD

- Break from the current status-quo of RTSes
- Moderately in-depth and complex resource and production trees
- Procedural maps
column34:
meaning you'll have to fine tune your strategy game to game
- Decent AI

THE BAD

- Anti-climatic
column35: nonsensical winning condition (You win by buying your competitor out of their own company
column36: which results in the last moments of the game being a frenzied click fest to shotgun your opponents; a mindless-feeling ending for what's supposed to be a strategy game
column37: albeit there is a sort of strategy to when you do commit to the kill.).\n- Sub-par interface. Right now the interface "works
column38:
but is somewhat ugly and uninformative, namely the important status reports which pop up in small text off to the side. They are difficult to read and sometimes you can miss out on important tidbits such as resource shortages/surpluses or sabotage events (luckily their are fairly obvious audio ques for more important events that draw your attention to them, such as a crushing soda can for an aluminum shortage). In addition, I found that a couple of the special buildings such as the hacker relay lag out the interface when you bring them up, but that's likely due to a simple bug.
- First impressions of the pace of the game make me feel like the gameplay is rushed. I'm not going to make a strong point about this as I don't really have an explanation or concrete examples to point to adequately support the point. After watching the trailer I was expecting the game to determined by who thought the smartest, not the fastest, which it is to a degree, but a major part of the game is jumping on map position and resources before anyone else does. This is probably mostly attributed to the nature of the game being it is a RTS. This may well be something that tradition RTS players like (rushing to gain decisive map control).
- Some strategies can be unbalanced in some circumstances, and can be annoying and feel very gamey at times.


FINAL VERDICT
Should you purchase this game as of the time of this review? Depends, really. I gave this game a recommendation because I, personally, have a fun time with it and I expect it's quality to rise over the next periods of development as I have faith in the credentials of the developers. However, this game is not for everyone, especially at it's price tag. Taking into account what I've experienced as well as what many of my friends have, I would say that for the average consumer ~20$ is a fair price tag for what you're currently getting. Bear in mind, of course, that the game is still in early access and may well be undisputably worthy of it's price tag, but until that day is etched in stone I would simply follow this game and watching where it goes.

reviewText:
The game is alright, but not terribly deep. A few rounds is all it takes to understand the mechanics of the game, and without a huge amount of complications it becomes very repetitive very quickly.

On the bright side, the game is absolutely functional. The economy works in a way that is responsive and satisfying. Your opponents actually seem to know what they're doing (at least on harder modes). The sound and visuals are both good.

On the down side the gameplay is shallow, leaving the player wanting more after a fairly short amount of time.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It's been a few months and the game has now come out of early access. I'm afraid that the only difference I see between the current game and the original game is Far better AI, and a nicer UI. The depth of the game hasn't been changed, and basically no new features have been added.

My review remains very similar to what it was before: The game is solid in what it does, but what it does isn't all that complex, and with so few tradable items and minerals the game becomes a straight race to get Offworld Trading Companies, and flood the market. There is some nuance at the beginning depending on the map, but beyond that every game basically plays out the same.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros:
- Completely playable game with very little bugs, very good for an Early Access Game
- Competent AI
- Single/Multiplayer Skirmishes are fast paced and intense(even vs AI)
- A breathe of fresh air for the Strategy/4X genre
- Intuitive Interface, for a complex economic game, the interface makes it easy to understand things
- Every map is different, this means you or any other person cannot rely on the same strategy everytime and will have to adjust their playstyles accordingly

Cons:
-  A bit too pricey for an Early Access Game
-  Multiplayer games are hosted by Players, lags later in the game is nearly inevitable
-  Single Player Campaign feels a bit too short in comparison to other Strategy/4X games (Civ, Total War & etc)
- Games are shorter in comparison to your standard Strategy/4X games.
-  The game targets a very niche market, thus this may be a boring game to someone and an addicting game to another
-  Needs more polishing on the interface (e.g. Events Notification is nearly unnoticeable if not for the SFX accompanying an event)

Verdict:
The game delivers what it promises, if you like what you see(check out Mohawk Games youtube channel and watch some VODs) and don't mind shelling out a high price for an Early Access Game, then it is a good buy. While the game is still in early access, the foundations of the gameplay itself is well polished. However there are still a lot of room to grow for this game and one may get frustrated or regret his or her purchase. If you are a 4X or Strategy games enthusiast I suggest buying this game, otherwise waiting for a sale may be a wiser choice.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I can't recommend the game right now; obviously it's Early Access, so I write this more to inform other people to probably wait to see how it improves. Even with all possible features they could put into this game; it's almost insultingly overpriced.

It just needs a little more 'something' in the game at its current price point. From what I got from playing, I felt like it should have been priced around $20 max. I'd ceretainly appreciate to hear from the developers as to why they believe the cost of the game is this high. The only reason I purchased it is because I'm usually the person that grabs games of interest in our community and I let them know if it's worth it or not. I can't recommend it at this price point.

The UI needs some works; it's pretty sluggish. The 'Notification' system is lackluster and need polish. They just pop-up in the lower-right corner 'Chat Window' so you really need to keep an eye on it at all times so you know when things are going to be effecting you.

Don't expect to just jump in this game and know what to do; it has a high learning curve so expect to spend some time figuring a few things out before you get to know what you're doing so you can beat other players.

The fact that an AI (or a player) can just race to earn a ton of cash, and then buy people out... is a silly win condition. I understand it's a 'Trading Game' and that's sorta the point; but I think there needs to be more to it than just Stockpile Cash -> Insta Buy-Out Player" - You learn to counter this by buying your own stock of course
date:
when possible.

I expect to see a lot more from this game at this price though; and I just don't see the value yet. I'm going to keep playing over the weekend and I'll update this review after a few more play sessions.

---------- Review Update -------------

I still can't really recommend it yet. Winning doesn't really feel like anything special. Here's why; you spend most of the game just attempting to get a good supply of things going
recommended:
then in the last 2-3 minutes of the game everyone scrambles to start 'Selling All Their Stuff' so you can just buy everyone else out.

This seems extremely anti-climatic to me; I feel like they just don't have any other ideas on how you can 'win' at the game. Once someone starts buying the stocks... it's just a silly race to finish buying everyone out in the next minute or two.

So here's my constructive feedback on 'How To Win' should be done in the game. Since it's about "Saving Humanity" and all that... you shouldn't be buying stock on the other companies; instead players should be 'Offworlding' their goods to "Earth" in order to 'Save Humanity'. The first 'Trade Company' to meet the demands of "Earth" should win. You could have "Earth" have random demands every game
hoursPlayed:
or even shift/change in the middle of it if you want to get crazy.

It's odd that that isn't how you win? Maybe it is? But all my games always just end up being "Stock Buyout Races". Who can press the minus and plus buttons faster than the other.

TL;DR Version - Winning isn't rewarding; the game builds you up

reviewText:
I am very pleased to give this game the thumbs up - I own it since its launch on Steam. I had a feeling it will grow well and achieve a good level of greatness by the time it was finihsed. Coming back to it now, over 9 months later, I cannot help but enjoy what the developer (Sören Johnson was the lead designer of Civilization 4) has achieved. Regardless whether in single player or multiplayer, you are treated to a fast-paced, ever-be-on-your-toes gameplay. To me, this is the best fast-paced economic sim I have ever played.

So, let's take a look at the good and the bad.

The GOOD:

1. Extremely engaging gameplay - that, to me, outweighs everything else. The game is built in such a way that keeps you on your toes all the time. A small slip-up may result in a loss. I can tell you, there are some real sharks out there.
2. Strategic Thinking + Awareness combo wins the game - you need to know exactly what you want and how to manipulate the situation you have been put in. You need to play a few moves ahead and you need to be ready to adapt and commit to the plan you have in your head.
3. Great single player - the developers have really programmed the AI well, as I expected of them. Even on lower difficulties (say, Employee or Assistant) the AI may suprise you and even buy you out in a skirmish game. In addition to that there is a great campaign (explained in #11), daily challenges, leaderboards, pretty much everything to satisfy your single player demands.
4. Multiplayer is damn good - but be aware, there are people out there who have played the game for a long time and will destroy a newcomer in no time. I know I have 26 hours in the game and got trashed. Do not get disheartened and do your best to learn and improve.
5. You can pick from a number of companies to lead to victory - and each one plays differently to boot! It is quite surprising just how much a dependence on one resource can affect a game, and how huge of a replayability it may provide. You may opt to play the sneaky scavengers, the tech-crazy scientists, the extremely expansive... um... Expansive corporation that gains extra claims on plots, or the Robots, which need no sustenance, but have to replace their parts and chips in a timely fashion.
6. Many ways to victory - while in skirmish the goal remains the same, to be the last man standing, there are many ways to achieve it. You are given lots of obvious and subtle ways to do so. Do not take your eys off that black market, I can tell you that much... or for the same reason off the resource table... or the shares table... uh, I am quite sure that you get my drift.
7. Many hours of enjoyment - due to its awesome replayability, you will easily be looking at 20+ hours of enjoyment, more if you want to test every corporation in various situations, and then go ahead and do some skirmishes, play through the campaign, do the daily challenges, and maybe play online vs other people.
8. An extremely pleasant music - the soundtrack is awesome, very nice and relaxing.
9. Good tutorial comprising of ways to teach you how to win, a number of practice games vs the AI up to Manager difficulty, and in my opinion, a great design decision to have you actually win a game in skirmish first before diving into the campaign. The campaign can be a bit overwhelming, I can tell you that from experience. The AI won't sit back and let you feel smart, MLG Pro gamer. It will crush you like a maggot if you don't play well.
10. Post-game statistics - the post-game statistics have been improved and made even more in-depth, much to my delight. I really like taking a long hard look at them and analyze what I did wrong or not.
11. Great single player campaign -  In its essence, you are given 7 weeks worth of challenges, with your chosen company, vs 3-4 AIs of a difficulty that you choose in the beginning of the campaign. From week 1 to 6, you use the cash you make to improve an AI colony by buying any of the 4 upgrades for it over a 7 day period. The winner with the most purchases gets the best weekly cash bonus. In the final week of the campaign, you enter a skirmish match with the top 4 companies left and to win you must buy them out. Each company starts with a number of upgrades, and you can hire additional staff either for a week or permanently to further boost a building's efficiency (you can boost a windmill's energy output, a metal mine's efficiency so that a single metal mine supports 3 steel mills, etc.). Then you are allowed to select one of the 3 missions given to you. Each one of them carries a different challenge which is clearly explained (example: limited resources, black market items, special conditions, etc.) and satisfies a certain earthbound sponsor (UN, USA, Russia, China), which, gives you another reward (like extra claims, better scans, etc.). Depending on how well you do on the mission, you get to carry more week-based revenue home and use it for further upgrades to your production buildings. And if you think that's not enough - you can even unlock a secondary or even tertiary sponsor and use it on a certain mission! Limited water with a scientific? Play robotic then!

Now, let's take a look at the BAD:
1. The graphics - call me weird, but I actually preferred the basic Early Access, more blocky and sci-fi-ish graphics. Since then, the game evolved into a more colorful, cartoonish look, which to my taste, was unnecessary. It sure gets the job done, but not for me.
2. The UI - the UI underwent a number of changes, which in my opinion made it more complex than it needed to be, with way more tabs and sub-tabs than necessary. Coming back to the game 9 months later, I was a bit overwhelmed myself for the first 5 minutes of play. Granted, I managed to make my way easily around it, but for a new player it will be a lot to process.
3. Punishing AI - yep, that could be a bad thing. If you are not ready to play vs tough AI who can exploit your mistakes, best stick to the lowest difficulties or... stay away from the game.
4. While a number of changes were made, the game did not change dramatically from the first early access build. But then again, the starter build was already quite good, polished, and enjoyable.
5. Huge skill difference in online games - many people who play online since alpha have way better understanding, time proven tactics and thus, the upper hand on someone who's just starting.
6. The price is a huge gripe for many people, and I can understand why. Yesterday, I was looking through my mails to see for just how much did I buy this game, and I was very surprised to find that I got it for 18,50€, which is roughly half of what it costs now. I would argue, that if you watched youtubers play it 9 months ago, that you should have already realized its potential and bought the game. However, on the other side I can totally understand how people like to wait till a game exits early access first, and then buy it. For them, the price tag will be high.
7. Last, but not least, the game suffers from the snowball effect. Once you get ahead, and if you know what you are doing, you will most likely stay ahead till the end of the game. That is a tad off-putting to some gamers, but I can tell you from experience, you can still turn it around... to a point. Then you just lose :)

Conclusion:

If you are willing to forgive the current price tag, this game is an easy buy for gamers who enjoy economic games comprised of a lot of wheeling and dealing, tormenting their opponents by scamming (cook the books for the win), crashing the market, freezing their best production plots for a time, boosting your own effectivenes, destroying their resources (underground nukes, yay!), or even toying with them as they spiral into huge debt. I, personally, find the game a great experience and am looking forward to playing the new and improved campaign, learn the new tricks and quirks of the game, and enjoying myself thoroughly in the process.

reviewText:
Played this for a little over a year throughout the Early Access. Can't recommend it enough. Here are just a few of the assorted points as to why I love it so much:
- The AI had been dramatically improved over the time and is quite, quite competent now. To a point that a newer player might struggle with it quite a bit until he really gets the hang of the game.
- Getting the hang of the game might seem challenging - the learning curve is quite steep and usually that's a sign of a deep game. And trust me, this game is deep in spite of what some people might say. I can see how playing AI can get repetitve but in a multiplayer every game is different and every game presents you with plenty of important and difficult decisions that you need to make quick.
- There is no one way to victory. Every game you have to adapt to the ever-changing environment, fluctuating prices, resource spread and geography, shortaging, colony growth etc.
- I have very little RTS experience. In fact nearly none and I am hardly at all inerested in the genre. Yet somehow when I first saw Offworld I got interested in it and after watching a whole pile of videos I realized that I HAVE to play it.
Now, I understand it's not a feeling everyone will have, not immediately for sure. But I think that if you like RTS, if you want something new and different, if you like a highly competitive game, you should definitely give it a shot.

reviewText:
What you get out of Offworld Trading Company depends heavily on what you expect and how much time you're willing to put into it. OTC is based around 25-40 minute skirmishes (or 10-15 if things are very lopsided) rather than being a sprawling epic. As such, there aren't a tremendous amount of different mechanics available, but what is here is very well balanced and allows for deep, varied games. Make no mistake: there is a very steep learning curve here, and a lot of the depth isn't necessarily readily apparent because there's so much going on.

Note on the learning curve: the basic concepts are fairly simple, and getting to the level of competence only requires a few bits of knowledge (that aren't necessarily obvious). Really mastering the game takes a fairly deep understanding of the game, though, and really good players can exploit small advantages to open up large leads (though those can also be countered by black market and other tools if players stay attentive).

Offworld absolutely delivers on the promise of being an RTS without units. In place of the usual micro-heavy unit management, there are myriad map quirks, prices, opponent actions, and random events to pay attention to and try to take advantages off of long-term. Even with over 700 hours put into the game, mostly playing multiplayer with some of the best players in the community, there are still plenty of things in a single game that I will fail to notice. Success at this game, rather than being reliant on high APM, depends on having good awareness and a good understanding of how and why prices will move, how to appropriately react, and especially countering your opponents.

Single player is somewhat more difficult to evaluate. The AI is relatively well-made and able to put up a fight or pose a serious challenge for newer players. With experience, there are some predictable aspects and flaws to the AI that let you beat them consistently, but until then, skirmishes against the AI should prove somewhat interesting and useful as a learning tool.

If you're a competitive person, going for the best times on the Daily Challenge can be a way to keep single player fresher. Trying to figure out what strategies work or the exact way to manipulate prices to make the AI do what you want it to do can be interesting, and with the variety of maps and restrictions set for each day's challenge, it's nontrivial to find optimal strategies. Being able to see how other players approached the same challenge (using the in-game replay feature) is useful both for learning new strategies or figuring out how to make small optimizations.

The campaign is essentially a series of skirmishes where you start with limited production and are able to unlock perks and better production as you advance. All but the final week of the campaign are a bit different from your standard skirmishes; rather than race to buy out your opponents, you are competing at investing in the central colony. You can choose from 9 different executives to play as, and a lot of work has been done to make them play differently. Once you find a working strategy and manage to build a solid foundation from the first few weeks, though, applying the same strategy over and over until the final week is fairly viable, so the campaign can drag a bit. Once you get to the final week, the standard skirmish with a different set of tools than you're used to can be fun.

Basically, if you're willing to put a lot of time into learning how the mechanics of the game interplay and are interested in multiplayer, this game will definitely reward you with a deep, consistently interesting experience. Single player can be played more casually and is enjoyable in its own right, but doesn't necessarily have a great deal of lasting appeal if you reach a point where the AI isn't particularly challenging. If you're not willing to put time into overcoming the steep learning curve, a lot of the game can seem overwhelming and incomprehensible (or else pointlessly simple if you play on very low difficulty levels), and probably isn't worth your time.

tl;dr - Buy the game if you want a rich multiplayer experience and aren't worried about the learning curve. Buy the game on sale if you're mostly interested in single player and the game's concept. Look elsewhere if you're looking for a game with an epic scale or with mechanics that are simple to master.

reviewText:
This is a brilliant, polished game. It has everything that should make it an addictive experience for me... pausable real-time, many divergent strategies for victory, brutally smart AI opponents, some nice tongue-in-cheek atmospherics, different factions with totally differing playstyles, and more.

So why the thumbs down? Why aren't I playing the game right now?

What it comes down to is this: to keep ahead of the game, you need to keep track not only of your own company's development, but ideally that of all your competitors as well. Your AI opponents will try to sabotoge you using dirty black-market tricks, and you have to do the same to them to win. That means you have to know what's really going to hurt them, and what's not. That means you have to understand their strategy. Which means you have to look over their operations on the map, count their buildings, try to work our what they're up to.

I could pause the game and do all that, but even if I did for each of the 3-7 opponents, I'd have to do it all over again a few minutes later, because that's how quickly the game moves.

Info about your opponents is not easy to find. There's no summary screen of how many building of each type each opponent has, which might allow you to piece together their strengths and weaknesses at a glance. Instead you have to maually count buildings if you want that info. I hate situations where a game makes information available, but very hard to access!

Another turn-off for me is the difficulty of assessing what investments will generate the best return. I end up making most of my investment choices using a sort of intuition, but I have the feeling that on higher difficulty levels you really need to flawlessly min-max to win. Again, I could pause the game and do a bunch of calculations by hand to min-max... but that's not much fun. Too much like my real job.

So despite being very drawn to the game in concept, I find in practice it just leaves me feeling frustrated at being unable to keep up with the constant min-max calculating that the AIs are able to do in real time.

I could pause the game every 30 seconds and try to keep up, in my feeble human way, but why bother?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Offworld Trading Company is a new type of real-time strategy game, it's not a combat-war type RTS, it's a numbers-war type game, it's a player-driven, market-driven game, where money and resources is power, and power is law.

From when it was announced, I loved the simple graphics, and playing it now I'm loving how it looks, the simplicity in the design, the deep colors, the nice eye candy effects, and the quick but charming animations, all of which are splendidly made.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tRt0h_e2fiQ&feature=youtu.be

There isn't a story of the sense that there's a campaign with that's lengthy with a big story to tell and characters to meet, it's only where you have to be the best of the best company that should represent what the future life of the human race, in terms of the market life. But in the campaign itself, you start off with limited equipment, and as you progress through it you will start to unlock what's been locked by purchasing them, until you got everything and finish the the campaign. I haven't finished it yet, but I'm working there.

Notice: This game does not have an offline mode yet.

The gameplay itself is the same as an RTS Command & Conquer, but with a mix of a hex-based movement / placement like a Civilization game, and sort of a mix of an Anno game with how building and trading is. Combined with the new idea, one that at least I haven't seen, of power management in the market area by gathering resources, buying and sell them, advancing your buildings to produce more materials, try do some shady tactics to over power your competitors. It's new and fun, and what I like about it is that it's simple yet complicated in a way, simple enough for most to learn.

At first I was skeptical with what the game is facing the price that it has, but after playing the first 3 tutorial levels, I fell in love with it, so my skepticism went away and I was happy with the game and the price, obviously followed with playing outside of the tutorial of course, playing the single player content and multiplayer. I see my self playing this for a while, and I was kind of hungry for this type of game, so win win. Also, while the game is sufficient enough to keep it self going for some time, I wouldn't mind seeing more buildings and units to play around with, just more content.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I bought this game, I though that it would be something different than what it is; and, I feel many of those not recommending this game made that same mistake. What this game is NOT is an economic/city builder simulation where you continually grow (ie a 4X).

What it IS is a resource management RTS (others have gone into further detail) - probably the first of its kind (at least the first that I've played). In any case, it is very innovative and very good for what it is, in my opinion.

I read through the other reviews to see if there was anything that I could add to what others have said, because I agree with most of the things that have been said about the game. One thng that I others haven't really talked about is how much strategy is actually involved in the game.

First of all, others haven't really talked about how important the stock market actually is. As others have said, the ultimate goal of the game is to buy out your oponents stock; and conversely you must defend your own stock. Your stock price (and I might be a litttle bit wrong here) is based off of your net assets; that is the value of all your resources, buildings (including your home colony), minus any debt that you may have accrued; but more importantly, it also includes the value of any stock you buy in other (your opponent's) companies (also maybe your own?). The part I'm not sure about is how much the actual buying/selling of shares actually influences price. At the beginning everyone's stock price is low but it rises as the game progresses. If you can buy shares early on, not only will it make it easier for you to defeat your opponents in the end, you will make it much harder for them to beat you, since the progress they have made during the game has driven up your own stock price.

Secondly, the fundamental question that the game asks the player is what is the the best/most profitable way for me to use my limited resources. By resources I mean the game's 12? resources (basic like iron or water, or advanced like electronics or chemicals), your cash, and most importantly the number of claims you have. Your claims equal the number of buidlings you can have and so are the limiting factor to your profit; that is you must maximize the profit from your limited number of claims. this raises a number of interesting questions and decisions. It may be profitable to scrap buildings for others if market prices for an output are much higher than the input, if you can buy a stockpile at a low price, or if you already have a stockpile. You may want to turn off a building if the input is more expensive than the output. Another result of this is that you are always (or should be) watching the prices on the market, and be aware of how they relate to the other resources.  Another result is that watching what your opponents are doing is important - they are working in the same market as you so, if they over or underproduce certain resources you can use that to your advantage.

This is where the black market comes in. I agree with others that some of the sabotages are overpowered - but you need to remember, this game is still in early access so balancing issues should be ironed out. However, what they are not is underpriced; if the price is low, that just means that the players aren't using the market to their full advantage. The prices grows incrementally, so by the late game they should already be expensive. And as I said above, what your opponents produce - or don't, in this case - affects the prices you buy and sell at, so you can use sabotages to help you as well as hinder your opponents.

Anyways, this got much longer than I intended, and I'm not sure how clear it was; but, I just want to say that I'm enjoying the game as it is, and eagerly await any improvements.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Have you ever played an RTS or 4X game and thought I wish non-military victories were more viable?"  Well let me tell you about Offworld Trading Company.

In Offworld

reviewText:
Early Access Review

'This isn't going to be like other RTS, it's going to be economy based instead of blowing things up' ... Put's in a 'black market' where you buy things to blow stuff up.

I like the game concept, but I feel as though the black market is detrimental to it. You are meant to outfox the other companies, by speculating on price and going after the resources that will be needed. It's like playing MULE or Settlers of Catan. The problem is it just reverts to any other RTS when the Black Market comes into play. If someone tries to plan ahead, see what is going to be needed, invest, ect. Other players just shut their stuff down. Sure, there are no armies, but is has the same effect. It's just lazy. Imagine Microsoft, instead of competing for market share with Apple based on innovation, could just nuke one of Apple's manufacturing plants. That's not how it works. Should we add a rule to Monopoly where you can obliterate Hotels? This is not in the spirit of this sort of arena.

Please remove this and replace it with something else. There are auctions, price manipulations, etc. that are better suited for this game. More ideas like those, and less 'sabotage' type things would be MUCH better. If you don't want this to be like every other RTS out there, then don't make it like every other RTS out there. There is a lot of potential here, please don't drop the ball.

I enjoy some aspects of the game, and see where it could be fun, but I cannot recommend it unless the direction is changed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's like realtime Settlers of Catan.

It's not much like city builder style economic games (such as Tropico, Dwarf Fortress, Factorio, the Settlers series) because you are heavily limited by the number of tiles (ie resources) you can claim. There's no optimising your road layout because there are no roads - your cargo flies where it needs to go.

The limited number of tile claims you have slows the pace from totally frantic to manageable. The game is bursts of frenetic energy and agression as you seize an available opportunity, then back to waiting. It feels a bit like a turn based boardgame with a chess timer.

I bought this game thinking I was going to have a nice quiet time building up a peaceful economy, as in the games I listed before, and that I wasn't too keen on the competitive aspect. Two hours later, I'm a cutthroat wheeling-and-dealing space CEO.

That said, it's very easy to make unfixable mistakes, and the game's not much good at teaching you how to play it. I think a lot of plays will be necessary to figure out good strategies. There are also some rough edges in the game balance - there are a few I win" buttons in there
date: which I'm expecting will get nerfed in future.\n\nIt's a lot of fun
recommended: though. Just expect to think on your feet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Given the oft and loudly proclaimed provenance of this game I expected a 4X-RTS experience, except with markets instead of militaries.  I imagined hours of playing vast, sprawling games across the surface of Mars, replete with complexity and grand strategic depth.

That's not what this game is.  In fact OTC is a scion of the great RTS's of the late 90s, and it operates on that same tense, refined, match-oriented, competitive level- in which the genre name becomes an anachronism, because the actual gameplay is so tight and focused that it would be best described as tactical rather than strategic.  Matches are fast-paced and relatively short, demanding a combination of quick clicks and quick thinking to stay on top.  Resources, tech, and production are all tied up with each other in a single intertangled tree" of progression.  You can buy or sell any resource or product at any time if you have the money
date: and one of the key facets of playing well is using this ever-market to drive up the value of your surplus goods and drive down the value of your opponents'
recommended: while still making sure you are keeping your levels where they need to be to avoid halts in production or debt accumulation.  There's a moment sometimes in a match where suddenly you see a way that you can make the market perform for you like a puppet- a few minutes and some well-placed clicks later and your stock is way out on top  (assuming
hoursPlayed: of course
voteText: your plans aren't deflected by your opponents' own devious machinations).  Victory in OTC occurs when one player owns all the stock of all the corporations in the match.\n\nDuring the best matches I experience that same sort of premium-grade thrumming that I used to get from a good game of Starcraft in college
helpfulPercent: complete with peculiar blink of bewilderment at match's end as my brain powers down its High Alert protocols and returns to normal functioning.  I find it interesting that the devs keep emphasizing how not like Starcraft this game is
votesHelpful:
and yet my gut-level experience has been very similar for the two games.  It's interesting as well that the devs were so worried about multiplayer catching on without any combat outlet for players.  And yet this game shines most brightly in the cutthroat multiplayer arena.  I think they underestimated our creativity when it comes to eradicating our opponents.  The markets of OTC can be just as disruptive and violent (and satisfying) as any zerg-infested terran marine making a bee-line for your base.

Overall 7.5/10

reviewText:
Product received for free

Buy low, sell high!
Welcome to Offworld Trading Company, an economic strategy game developed by Mohawk Games. Your goal in OTC is simple, make more money than your competition and, eventually, buy them out completely. You’ll need to manage all of your resources, expand your company’s HQ and maybe there’ll be some corporate sabotage thrown in to the mix.

The core gameplay all revolves around harvesting resources and then using those resources to produce other resources (for example Silicon is used by the buildings that produce glass) and sell off anything you don’t need to boost your cash-flow. It sounds easy but you only have a certain number of tile claims. If you have five claims available that means you can only build five buildings. However, you can get more claims, mainly by upgrading your company’s HQ (up to the maximum level 5) but there are in-game auctions and you’ll sometimes be able to bid on extra claims or an actual tile as well as other things such as patents (technologies that provide a positive bonus to your business) and black market items (some of which are used for personal gain, others which are used to sabotage the competition).

As with all strategy games, OTC’s gameplay is split into early-game, mid-game and late-game. The early-game in OTC is all about securing the resources that are essential to your faction (one of four), without these you’ll find yourself in a lot of debt very quickly and you’ll be unable to expand your HQ. For example, Seneca Development is a human faction so they need food, water and oxygen to run their base but Yoshimi Robotics is run by robots so they don’t require these (though you may still want them in order to sell them). It’s also important to secure at least two of the three resources you need for upgrading your HQ in the early game so that you don’t have to spend too much money buying other resources. OTC’s mid-game is essentially about preparing for late-game. By the mid-game you should have secured all the resources you need to run and upgrade your HQ so now you’ll be thinking about increasing your HQ level and starting to look at producing resources which you’ll be able to make huge profits from in the late-game stage. If you have any resources to sell off, mid-game may also be when you start purchasing stocks in other players to prepare for buying them out. The late-game stage is when you’re going to be making most of your money. Prices will be at their highest now as the human colony you’re supporting will be very large now so this is the time to sell off resources you have large stockpiles of (in small amounts so you don’t push the price down too much) but it’s also when you want to be thinking about building two or three Offworld Markets. The Offworld Market building is a rocket which will launch 100 of whatever resource you choose to asteroid mines for insane amounts of money, several times more than simply selling your resources to the colony. Once you’ve sent up a couple of rockets you’ll have enough money to buy out the weakest competitor(s) and soon you’ll have enough to buy out even the strongest of the competition, as long as they’re still behind you.

The main way to limit your competition is by sabotaging them with black market items as I mentioned earlier. Some of the items which are for your benefit include bribing officials to give you an extra claim or using a M.U.L.E to collect 200 units of a resource. The sabotage items range from EMPs which will temporarily disable a few buildings to Mutiny which will give you any profits from a building for around a minute (particularly effective when used on Offworld Markets). Some of these items did feel unbalanced to me, for example an underground nuke reduces the number of resources you harvest from a tile, if an enemy uses this several times it can be incredibly damaging as you’ll then have to focus on getting more of that resource rather than making money. It also seems that AI are more likely to target human players than other AI players which is of course problematic if you’re playing single-player. While some of the individual items feel unbalanced, the black markets presence in the game is handled very well. Once you’ve purchased an item from the market you’ll have to wait one minute before you can purchase anything else and every time a player (human or AI) purchases an item its price increases for everyone so you can’t just spam a load of EMPs. Furthermore, there’s a pool of items and you only get a random selection of them for each game (the number of items also depends on the size of the map/number of players) which adds a little bit of variety to the game.

Although I’ve really enjoyed playing OTC (especially multiplayer skirmishes with friends) it does have two major issues: a lack of depth and a high price for what’s on offer. The former feeds into the latter so I’ll talk about it first. The problem I have is there’s not really any variation in gameplay or strategies. I’ve played quite a few matches in my ten hours with the game so far (they usually last between twenty to thirty minutes) and I’ve used the same strategy every time, winning all but two or three matches. Even when I played as a different faction I only had to make small tweaks to my strategy in order to win the game. Sure, if you play on the higher difficulties it’s more of a challenge but I still didn’t feel as though I needed to do anything differently to what I did in my previous games. Obviously I don’t expect it to be so varied that it feels like I’m playing a different game every time I play but I shouldn’t feel like I’m playing the same match when I play. It’s this lack of depth that makes the £30 asking price way too high, I feel that a price point of around £20 would be much better value.

A couple more things to tie up. OTC is a really good looking game, the style of the game fits it perfectly and, though it’s only a small feature, I enjoyed watching the little transport ships fly from my resource collection buildings back to the HQ. While Skirmish is probably playing most of the time, there is also a campaign mode. It’s well designed and offers slightly different gameplay to Skirmish mode, giving you seven days on a map to be the player who buys the most modules for the nearby colony. Personally I didn’t enjoy it anywhere near as much as skirmish/multiplayer but that’s not to say it’s bad. The tutorials are very good and explain everything very well though it is possible to screw up in the tutorials (for example if you build an extra building you won’t have enough claims to complete the tutorial) which means that you may have to restart the entire tutorial mission, a bit frustrating considering it’s not explained. Lastly, the game’s soundtrack is absolutely fantastic!

Verdict
An enjoyable economic strategy game that’s good for a few hours of fun despite being overpriced and lacking depth. If you’re a fan of strategy games and you’re looking for something different I’d highly recommend picking it up on sale.

Lone Ranger Reviews.

El K.

Compete auction to take high resource depots, regulate funds and debt, buy, sell and control the value of resources, bother opponents by black market... Above all, despite the difficulty was only employee level, AI players are not stupid :)
This isn’t a perfect AAA game, but I think it’s worth of $40. It’ll be advance better and better until official release in 2016.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The learning curve Offworld Trading Company is steep, very steep.

Let me go over a few basics I've discovered so far.

When starting your colony on Mars, there are 4 types of HQ to choose from, and it's important to remember that each of them have different basic resources needs among the 12 or so which can be produced, or bought and sold in the game(you will be giving lots of attention to what you are buying or selling).

Building placement is essential as well.  Think of it like Civilization, you should keep everything attached to your Base unless it is something that absolutely must be shipped across the map.

But before you build, you must claim land.  And land claims aren't handed out like candy, there's a ton of land, but you'll only get your hands on a precious few pieces, which cannot be exchanged.

It's an enjoyable experience, and can be a fairly laidback, relatively brief, competition between other players.

I hope you'll join me, and I'll try to share some of what I've learned so far as we compete.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My roommate walked in and asked what I was playing. I told him it was Offworld Trading Company, an RTS about building a corporation on Mars, expanding your base, and specializing in the production of a whole host of materials to earn enough money to buy out your opponents. He told me it looked pretty interesting, but mentioned that I was losing... And I was, BADLY. The match was down to myself and one other company, but that enemy had bought out two other players. They were an unstoppable behemoth with 10x the iron mines, steel mills, glass factories, electronic depots, and every other profitable thing you can imagine. It was this sort of scenerio I might have just given up and quit in any other strategy game. But, I couldn't embaress myself, here. I had an offworld market, capable of launching rockets filled with my most precious materials to the skies and bringing back buckets of cash and my opponent didn't. I coud see the flashing, red percentage next to my enemy's name, noting how close they were to buying me out. I managed to buy a bit of my enemy's stock. But, it was still going to cost 2 million to win. I sold EVERYTHING, making a little bit here, a little bit there. I looked to the right: 70%, 80%, 90%... 99%. That's it! 2 million!!! Buy, buy, buy. I won. What.

I've read some reviews where people don't seem to understand why prices go up or down and don't understand some of the core mechanics of the game, so I just wanted to clear a few things up.
There are 2-8 companies in each match, with a colony at the center. All goods start at a certain price. If players buy more of one resource, it goes up in price. If they sell a lot, it goes down. The colony also expands as the game goes on and each building they create has specific demands that also affect the market prices.
Each player chooses one of four types of headquarters, each with their own abilities. The game is based on isometric tiles and when you start the game, you'll only have a few claims to own the tiles you choose. By leveling up your base from level 1 to level 5, you get more claims to diversify and increase production. At max level, you can build an offworld market that launches rockets into space. This secondary market isn't affected by supply and demand, it just has permanatly high prices. This makes it a very lucridive end game to reach and pile up enough money to buy out your opponents.

The game is a tense, corporate competition that has so many ways to play, allowing you to build a vast mining corporation, an electronic manufacturing titan, or a chemical lab empire. You can upgrade everything, specialize or diversify, build quick and unstable, or slow and steady; the game offers a ton of ways to replay. This is a fantastic strategy game that isn't much like any major game out there and is tons of fun with friends. The AI is pretty tough, though.

reviewText:
What is this game about?:
This is an economic RTS simulator that takes place on Mars. Matches will take around 15-30 minutes depending on how many people you are playing with. This is not a epic-scale game like Civilization!  So you, the player can choose between 4 different factions. The 4 different factions are: Expansive, Robotic, Scientific and Scavenger. Every factions has there ups and downs and you want to use the best faction that you think is good on set random map.

Gameplay:
-Ingame you will have a market window on the left for all the market prices and all the rescource units you might have. This is where all the buying and selling will be taken place.
-In the middle of the screen is where most of the action takes plays. On the map you build buildings that produce rescources which cost claims where you have limited number of. Because of this you need to plan your way through
-On the right top side is where you and other players companies stocks are. The goal to win a game is very simple. Buy every other company out by buying there stock. Each company has 10 stocks. You can buy someone out by having a majority of there stock (6 stocks=60%) or if they bought there own 5 stocks already, you can buy those 5 stocks, double the price, in 1 go.
-To combat the company that is leading a match there is something called the blackmarket. The blackmarket is on the right bottom side of the screen and will have a set of different items. Some items are there for to shutdown the production of your opponents or to boost your own production.

What has the game to Offer?:
-9 Tutorials which are very well done and explain you the game. after every tutorial you pass it will be a bit harder for you which is nice.
-Campaign which consist of 9 different leaders which have there own set of different buildings. You play 6 different matches where you buy into the colony and not a Company. After that there is a final match where you need to buyout the remaining 3 companies. Note: prices are going to be crazy in this mode. Campaign takes about 4-5 hours.
-Skirmish mode up to 8 Players.
-Daily Challenge. Everyone gets the same map and restrictions and you will be competing to get the best time. There is also a leaderboard for that and you can watch replays from other players to see what they did differently.
-Ranking System(online). 1vs1 is available on Monday through Thursday and 4 FFA Friday through Sunday.
-Custom Lobby games(online). Just skirmish matches with your own rules against real people or with/against AI.
-Well balanced AI
-Different types of game modes.

reviewText:
Important:  Each game is a match that takes 20-40min to complete.  There are options that allow for longer games but the design is based on short cutthroat matches over long empire building.

That being said the game is fantastic!

The single player enviroment is rich is choices.  You can play a campaign at a difficulty of your choosing that goes through 7 matches each with carry over conditions and abilities.  This forces you to mix up your playing style and adjust to different situations.  You will be restricted in building choices as well, so learning to make do with what you have is important.  The game ends after a final showdown where you are allowed to buy out your rivals.  This mode is very fun and less stressfull then the other match types.

Skirmish and multiplayer allow you to buy out your rivals from the start (this is how you win the game).  With a dynamic market then the game is all about spotting oppertunities and taking advantage or knee capping your opponents with targeted special abilites on their structures.

The game has a setting that allows you to hide the real identity of each player to prevent grudge matches from getting out of hand for a reason!!


The game is fast, but very deep, you tend to get time to think about your decisions despite the time pressure.  Production chains are rather simple, but the overall interaction of the market and the 13 resources allows for immense possibilities.  No two matches are ever alike.

The game is pretty unique and I really do not have anything else that scratches the same kind of itch (Anno series comes the closest, but the markets are pretty stale in comparision).

If you like schemes like shutting down your rivals water production shortly after causing a spike in water prices with the ultimate goal of making their food production too expensive to compete with yours, then well, you have found your dream game.

To me this game is a 10/10 for this type of game, but it is not for everyone, expecially people who do not like competitive games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Terrific game built on a purely economic and capitalist set of goals as opposed to a military one. The initial game is relatively simplistic. Build a base on mars with the resource nodes available on the map while trying to make money by selling those same resources for money. You can only hold so many plots of land at a time so you have to build your economy in a narrow frame of what you want to do with the space you have. Resources gain more and more value over time but every time a player, or the ai sells something it lowers the value of the resource. The game is a modicum of a real world stock market and economy but simpler and faster.

The game has a lot of interesting depth and complexity to these simple mechanics. There is the push/pull of using your resources more quickly to advance your base vs selling them to have cash on hand. You can prioritize basic resources for your base in the early game that have less value later or prioritize the pricier resources for cash. Playing on maps with restricted resources forces you to change how you approach making money. Off world shipping is worth bank late game when selling basics like foods but requires advance components and resources to make. It requires a good timing on when to have what resources in production in order to maximize profit. One corporation only uses robots which requires no food to operate and less water but it means a higher requirement for advance resources. This means dedicating less land plots to cheaper basic resources but a higher cash cost early game.

If aggresively manipulating economies to your benefit, moving resources for money, or aggressively selling your own stock in order to gain quick cash to make deals and then buying it back and throwing cash at your opponents in hostile takeover does not sound interesting then this game is not for you. Otherwise go nuts. Also the game has beautifully simple graphics.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I didn't think I'd like this game since I do not usually like Real Time Strategy games, but after only a couple of months Offworld Trading Company is already one of my most played games on Steam.

What makes OTC so special is how different each match is. While other games in the genre require constant study of builds as the meta shifts, here the randomized maps and varied strategies from opponents force players to play each round differently. Whereas one match might see the price of food skyrocket you to victory, the next match might find food barely worth the cost of the building. The player most able to see and take advantage of gaps in the market wins.

The result is a game that still makes me sweat after 200 matches played, yet even when I lose I still enjoy myself. What better compliment can you offer a competitive multiplayer game? Highly, highly recommended.

edit: This game has only improved over the course of Early Access, and it's still a game I play regularly!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ignore the entry ticket price, this is one of the most polished Early Access titles you'll ever see.
Offworld Trading Company, possibly the most curious of creatures. A game that dares to break the rules, it's not quite a 4x and it's not quite an RTS, and yet it's got elements of both, as well as a very brutal and brilliant introduction into capitalism in it's most true sense.

The creator of this was the lead designer of Civ IV, still widely regarded as the pinnacle of the series and still very much fondly remembered by many to this day (and often still played by many, it's got a dedicated following, mods and glorious goodies, it's still fantastic, if you don't have Civ IV, please get it). He's brought a very unique approach to this game and has effectively talen the spirit of M.U.L.E. and brought it back, shaken it up and presented us with a entirely new set of concepts to learn and re-learn.

The game plays out over a martian map, randomly generated from various landscapes made up of craters, dried riverbeds and valleys that do a fairly solid impression of conveying the martian scene, as well as various terrain that can be covered in ice, certain areas will be marked with resource node icons indicating they are of potential exploitative value for various minerals.  Arranged on a hex grid, you'll immediately be put in mind of old strategy games, but the comparison ends there. There are no units to control, at all. You only build things.

A non combat 4X, is this even possible? Say whaaaaaaaaaat?
Yes. I'll repeat that. You only build things. In this game, your structures are your units in effect. Your mines, your colony buildings, and your economy represents your arsenal" and "weaponry". This makes for a frenetic early game as everyone jumps into the map blind
