reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access Review (2/12/15)
BLUF: #1 - I feel that RTS is a poor term to describe this game and #2 - from the Devs “Feedback! We want to know how players are going to break the game, suss out any degenerate strategies, and make sure we polish every rough edge off of the gameplay. Offworld Trading Company is fully funded; we are not relying on Early Access sales to finish the game.” This statement is key.

***
For those of you who have been burned by early access games before please take the note from the Devs seriously. This is a very playable and stable game right now and they already have the resources to put the finishing touches on it. So you are not really paying to make the game, you are getting an early shot at the game and a chance to drive further balance into the system. The final quality of this game will depend heavily on balancing the PVP aspects of the game so the more feedback they have now the better.
As far as this being a RTS; while it might be the closest term we have to define it, that will give many people the wrong idea. There are no units to move, no combat, and no chokepoints. You establish a base and build buildings to harvest resources (much like the Warhammer:Dawn of War series) and use those resources to develope higher teir commdities to eventually sell for cash and buy out your opponents. It is fast paced and at times will feel like a RTS, but traditional RTS tactics will fail for the most part.
The key is that the prices that determine which resource is the 'win' resource will depend on the strat adapted by the players in the game and will change from game to game. There are no Ultimate Resources that win the game each time. The higher teir products will usually have a higher price, but if everyone in that game chases them then the price will plummet and the player sitting on a pile of low teir resources can dominate. Basically the L33T strat that everyone wants to use will neuter itself before it can win.

My current concerns:
The pace of the game is very aggressive for a strategy game. The pace can be adjusted and I have only played against the AI with their GHz brains, but knowing PVP types this could quickly devolve into a 'who can spam out the first 3 correct buildings' contest.
The interface needs to do a better job of letting the player know whats going on. There are some pretty nasty things lurking on the Black Market and all you get is a chat box type readout to announce them and maybe an onscreen animation if you happen to be looking at that part of the map at the time. The trick is to find the balance where we get the info we need without getting our screen spammed out by alerts. Good luck Mohawk!

reviewText:
There is a really strong caveat in recommending this, which is that the tags on the store page are extremely deceptive.  This is not an economic game, this is not a simulation game, this is not a trading game, and this is not a base building game.  This is a very fast paced, micro-intensive RTS.

Its an interesting take on the RTS genre, because you don't have any units to control.  But make no mistake, this game plays very similarly to one of the micro practice maps for SC2, and uses essentially the same skillset.  Its just that instead of microing units around a map, you're constantly scanning the map, spamming abilities, and hitting the buy/sell button.  I know it may sound like this is fundamentally different from microing units around, but in practice its not.

If you're someone who likes the micro game in SC2, you'll like this game.  If you're a more casual RTS player then this probably isn't the game for you.

There's nothing wrong with that, and the game itself is quite well done, but the game is definitely targetted towards a relatively small niche and the store page/reviews in no way reflect that.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game needs a lot of work to make it enjoyable. The Black Market items just make the game stressful as, if you're the highest ranked player for the mission, you will inevitably be targeted repeatedly by the other three AI players, making it nearly impossible to manage your resources. Even if you are doing really well and own all the stock in your own company in a skirmish, another player can still somehow buy stock in your company that shouldn't even be for sale and win the game. The claim system is completely hampering the ability to play the game as it is portrayed in the videos. There's just too small of a map and too limited of resources to enjoy the act of building up a company or colony. The missions are over so quickly I feel no satisfaction even if I win.
Yes, most RTS's are military games, but there is an econmic angle to them as well. The strongest economies are usually the winners. This game substitutes the lack of tanks and turrets for Black Market items that blow up buildings, temporarily disable them or capture them for other players. THIS IS NO DIFFERENT. There is no difference between this game and a military RTS except that this game is not fun, not realistic in the aspects of building up a company or the ability to focus on a single resource chain / manufacturing process, and it is over so quickly it leaves you wondering why you just spent 30-45 minutes playing a week" mission in a compaign that makes you start all over again the next week with some "upgraded" capabilities.
I spent one skirmish (because I wanted to play with all available buildings) only to find that by the time that I could start launching items into space for selling offworld (the best way to make money in the game by far) that the other computer player had already bought out the other two companies (which I had bought stock in
date: but could no longer as they were now 'subsidiaries' of the main company) and proceeded to blow up my only launchpad (because
hoursPlayed: limited building claims) with the black market dynomite option even though it was protected with the Goon Squad (the only defensive measure in the game that you have to continually and immediately purchase after each attack [which is an extremely ridiculous option considering the computer can repeatedly attack you faster than you can click to purchase and place your defense against this).\nMaybe I haven't given this game enough time to understand it completely

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As many other reviewers of this game have stated, the price point of this game is simply way too high for what you get, especially considering the game is in early access and I expect them to only raise the price from here. I don't shy away from early access games and I've had more than a few that never really progressed as I hoped/expected, but most I feel I at least get my money's worth out of them, but at $35, this is one of the few I definitely regret picking up.

It's not really a bad game and it is an interesting concept, but the sacrifices the developers have made to make matches fit into 20-30 minutes have made the gameplay chaotic and often times inconsistent... not things that are typically appreciated in an economic game, competitive real-time or not. It also lacks any decent mechanisms to defend yourself from sabatoge or simply being bought out once the bulk cash transactions start coming in in the late game, so winning or losing a match can be both frustrating and unsatisfying. You can carefully manuever yourself into an advantageous position to corner a market on a resource or disrupt an opponent's supply chain but then you get 75k from one offworld shipment of a base resource like oxygen, dump all your resources on the market, and hit a + button a couple times and win without any of it mattering.

The game definitely lacks depth and each match usually hinges completely on the base materials like glass or power. Regardless of which resources are the focus on any given match, the gameplay is mostly the same every time. It can be fun and it does have potential if the developers are open to some design changes, but it is simply not worth $35 or more right now and I seriously doubt it ever will be.

I would love to be wrong and see great things happen for this game as development continues, but right now, I can not recomment it.

reviewText:
I have been playing Offworld Trading Company since release in March and have found it to be an excellent game.  The game is easy to learn and play but has a depth that belies it simplicity.

There are 4 HQ types with different traits and advantages, they provide a wide variety of strategies to win the game.  Offworld Trading is best described as an Economic RTS, as you upgrade your HQ you receive more claims to mine resources or refine them via factories/plants, sell your products into the market to gain cold hard cash.  Use your cash buy shares in completing companies eventually taking them over and reigning supreme as the only corporation left standing.
There is no combat system as such, no need to furiously click your way to victory, however there is a Black Market function where you can buy various items to either slow you opponents down, like an EMP to freeze his/her factories for a short time or mutiny their power plant glassworks, taking those tasty profits for yourself.  Other items will give you a boost, increasing your production or a goon squad to catch those stinking saboteurs.  The game is very well balanced and there are many ways to squeeze the most profit out of your tiles.

I play multiplayer exclusively because it's so much fun, the AI is excellent and well programmed, but playing against 6 other people is miles better, this game really shines when you have a good group of human players.  Typical game lasts 20 -40mins which is the perfect length for me.

Pros
Simple to play and very rewarding for the casual player, but plenty of depth for more serious gamers
Very well polished, stable and balanced for an Early Access game, imo it could be released tomorrow at full price.
Gameplay is intense and very fun but not frantic like other RTS games.
Devs are very active in the community and actually listen to feedback.

Cons
Difficult to find higher level players to play with if you live in Europe (unless you want to stay up till 2am)


If you like RTS games then this is a must buy, I am very happy with my purchase, great re playability, really shines in multiplayer.  10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Genre
Its not often I come across a game which is a totally new genre but I think Offworld fits the bill.
Offworld is a strange hybrid of 4X and RTS but without the combat, however that description alone does not come close.

Matches
Matches are generally short (30 min) and start off with a similar feel to 4X games, you explore expand and start to exploit the landscape, but you need keep moving, resting on your laurels will get you left behind by the AI, time is the unlisted resource in this game.
Each game is a struggle for economic dominance with the winner buying out the shares of the opposing companies, now this may sound a little dry, but the fun comes with how you achieve this.
There are many ways of getting the upper hand in Offworld, with strategies ranging from predicting trends, to dominating resources, outpacing others with research and new techs, managing your debt, or using a miriad of black market options.

Early access
The technical quality of this game is very good, it works better than some finished" games

reviewText:
Offworld Trading Company is a new genre of game, which is a blend of several styles into its own new style. A fine balance bringing to the table an awesome game.

On some sides, it reminds me of the old RTS Monopoly Tycoon, with the multiplayer capitalism management on one hand and the real time business sim on the other hand. (The auction system is by the way fantastic !) While at the same time, the game is grand by its simplicity of the resources manegement and strategy planning, maybe similar to Settlers with the logistics supply chain of raw materials up to the final produces.

This game can enter into the History of Gaming, that it is at the same time a smart game, with in depth game anaylyzis without having dozens of parameters, just a few interesting resources with different rules and needs which intricately are depending on each other in a beautiful supply and demand concept.
And at the same time, it is a game fun to play, where you don't have to learn dozens of recipes, where you quickly have fun (a few tutorials teach you the basic ropes of the game, same as chess, the game can be learnt in a very short time, but it can require a long time to master :)!). Lots of events occur in game, which can change the whole course of a development, pirates intercepting your cargos, mutiny of your geothermal powerplant at the very wrong time... well you get the picture hehe !

You might be thinking that this game sounds like a very long game to play, spending hours of planification, development and implementation ... such as a Heart of Iron, Total War or a Civ game for instance ... well not at all, the games lasts hardly more than 30 minutes ! And this is in the case you are not losing after a few minutes!

All in all, this game, is, I believe, refreshing with its new genre, smart with its simple but challenging puzzles mechanics for the colonization of Mars, all this while having a good fun when utilizing the resources of the planet.

The question is ... will you challenge yourself ... go play this legendary Offworld Trading company ?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a decent game, but the price is a bit high for what you get. They definitely have a lot of work to do before the game releases. I wouldn't term this is an economy game. This is an attack your opponent RTS, but the attacks are different than your standard RTS. I was expecting a laid back economic builder in the sim city fashion that was a real-time game. This is more of a fast paced eliminate your opponent game like your regular combat RTS.

Playing on the easiest difficulty and the game on slow speed I feel rushed. If I do not start buying out my opponents quickly they will buy me out. My games typically last 30 minutes to an hour because the AI pushes the game so fast. If I go any slower I will lose.

I find it difficult to beat the computer. I feel like I have to use exploits to even have a chance. The way I am able to beat the computer is to find the least populated resource and build my base on it to reduce the amount even more. Then I claim all that I can of the remaining. This slows the computer down a little bit and will allow me to prolong the game. I have never played on anything except the lowest difficulty because of how challenging it is.

If you are looking for a casual economic game then this is probably not what you are looking for. If you are looking for a fast paced RTS that the first 5 minutes of game play can make or break you then this might be it for you. There are a lot of much better RTS' out there. As an economic builder I don't think this games is going to appeal to the type of casual player that would be interested in economic builders.

Game stability? The game has crashed on me about 5 times while I was playing tonight over the course of about 5 hours.

This game is supposedly in Alpha. If it is truly in alpha then they are still planning to add more content to the game. If they are just fine tuning, bug testing, and performance optimizing then this is not in alpha. If it's alpha then I look forward to the complete game. If this is beta then I'm disappointed.

If you have $40 to spare and would like something to do for a day or two then I would pick this up. If you have high expectations for this purchase then I would suggest waiting to buy.

Short version:
Interesting premise but lacking in execution. As of yet the game is very short in content. One can spend roughly 3 hours in it before one has seen everything and a feeling of this needs more time in development" settles in. The only reason I personally spent more time on this was from coming back for matches between patches to see what they added (and it wasn't much
date: mostly balance adjustments and bug fixes). The developers consider the game "feature complete" and in doing so crush any hope of new game mechanics to broaden gameplay.\nWould rate the experience 4 out of 10
recommended:
in particularly in hindsight of the the high price for the small game one gets in return.



Long version:
Offworld Trading Company has the complexity of a typical smartphone or board game with a tedious buy/sell minigame in the form of juggling various goods around. Player influence on total econonmy or pricing is negligible - you can not corner a market or establish a strategic monopoly as it's always possible to buy resources from the market
hoursPlayed:
even if nobody supplies them. A single match is roughly 30 minutes in duration but can take up to 40 in rare cases. Gameplay is heavily streamlined to remain within tight confines.

To illustrate a few mechanics:
Upon starting a match one has to scan the map to uncover its limited resource fields
voteText: quickly slam down a base building and then build extractors on resource deposits. Automated NPC ships haul the harvested resource back to the HQ once the extractor building is full. Those units can not be interacted with directly (except for a very rare piracy action card one can win in a random auction to steal enemy supplies for a short duration) and merely exist as a visual way to see when the next resource-"tick" happens. They are the only units on the map
helpfulPercent: everything else is just buildings.\n\nThere is a limit over how many tiles of the map you can build on as building on a tile consumes "claims" - you start with a handfull of those and only get a handful more for upgrading your HQ
votesHelpful: which in return only has 4 steps and stops at level 5. A few screenshots on the Store page show how small the fully upgraded "base" will get. As buildings give an output adjaciency bonus one just builds a cluster of similar buildings and spreads out the other clusters of different types to avoid getting targeted by expensive sabotage actions players can buy (with a cooldown)
votesTotal: such as EMP strikes.\n\nThe match itself is won by buying out the competition. This starts by acquiring "shares" of the enemy company - the total amount of shares each company has can be adjusted with difficulty settings but is typically 10. The more shares one owns the cheaper will be the final takeover - that option simply becomes unlocked once all shares have been bought by someone (no matter if a company bought its own shares or someone else did) - there is no way to prevent takeover
votesFunny: even if the company is doing well financially
commentsCount: as long as the enemy has enough cash on hand to buy one out. This means one could lose if an enemy simply stops spending cash very early to rush a buyout while one would rather upgrade and then have the stronger income/economy to win in the long run. This sounds more complex than it is but at its core feels unrefined and gets boring rather quickly.\n\nIn technical regards the game is very simple and seems to be made in the Unity Engine 4 - as such it only supports single threading
column16: has greatly limited scale of maps and environments
column17:
medicore visual fidelity and tacked-on UI. At this stage the UI seems extremely clunky - I'd have hoped it's a placeholder but as they are adjusting and updating it while adding new buttons I somehow get the feeling they'll keep it this way.
The current voice files are text-to-speech placeholders with awkward pronounciation but are the most memorable feature of the game - sentences like "Just look at all the money." from a creepy robot voice are simply hilarious.

All in all it feels like the designers behind this project had a nifity idea but no great vision with merely a few simple game systems in spirit of a board game in their heads - the blanks have been filled with convoluted mechanics. I do not believe the developers will give it a complete overhaul between now and release and as such can not recommend a purchase."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Offworld trading company is a real time strategy game focussing on simulating economy and free market trade. This is not really a tycoon game because it's not about gradually building your business over time. Instead each game is a short (30 to 60 minute) race against your competitors to see who can buy out each other's companies first, by setting up an effective and efficient organisation.

You do this by producing, buying and selling resources in such a way that ensures profits in the short and long term. Everything you do has a benefit and a cost, using resources but producing them at the same time. You need to ensure that you read and predict market trends so that you are producing the right goods at the right time. It's all about supply and demand. If electricity is scarce and you're not producing your own, you'll end up spending a fortune buying it. If the market is flooded with food you might as well buy it rather than waste land and resources to make it yourself. Likewise, if there is a fuel shortage and you are producing a lot of fuel, you can make a lot of money selling it at high prices.

Don't let the simple (thought nice) graphics and animations fool you, there is a lot to this game. The depth and complexity makes it both fun and intelectually stimulating. The best part is that no two games are the same, and there are several strategies that you can successfully use to win. Also, what worked for you last time might not work for you in the next game. This is emergent gameplay at it's best.

There isn't much to dislike about this game, as an economic simulation it is unique and well balanced. It will take you about an hour or two to really get into the game and to appreciate why it is so good. That said, for the average player the full price (40 USD) is definitely a bit steep. It is still early access though so it might be a different story once the full release is out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Offworld Trading Company , although still in early access, does a great job of defining stages to the flow of a match. Why do I mention this first? Because the best RTSs I've played have loosely defined stages that allow for depth of strategy at each step. Available funds  are precious early in a match and there are several outlets to utilize these funds. You can upgrade early to try and get a lead in resource gathering, you can use the black market to shut down your opponent's income, or you can manipulate the market to make it more costly for other players to catch up to you. As the game progresses, the options available to you also expand, and strategies abound.

The mid-game in Offworld Trading Company is where the most important blows start being traded. In order to ensure your company is not bought, you must purchase and hold onto at least 5 of your own stock (which then have to be bought out all at the same time in order for another player to remove you from the game); however, the money available to you to buy your own stock could also be used to take out another player by beating them to 6 of their stock. This makes decisions on who to buy stock in, whether to purchase your own stock, or whether to continue to upgrade to get a lead in the late game potentially deadly. If the wrong choice is made, other players will take advantage of your mistakes.

Late game, if the game hasn't already been decided by the mid-game brawl, comes down to endurance. Each remaining player's goal is to get enough money to buy out the others before being bought themselves. There are several advanced buildings in Offworld Trading Company that allow for varying strategies to accomplish this task and, depending on the state of the market, each strategy has a place and can allow for you to outspend your opponents.

An economic RTS is a fairly unexplored idea, so be prepared to endure a fairly high learning curve before becoming competent in the gameplay. I'm sure most of what I've mentioned in the paragraphs above means very little to someone who hasn't played Offworld Trading Company , but the point is to show the depth of gameplay Offworld Trading Company allows for.

So, let's break this game into its parts:

Content: 5/10
Multiplayer is where this game shines. There is a campaign mode, but it is currently very limited.
Animations: 9/10
There is little animation in the game, but what has been done is done well.
Graphics/Artwork/Illustrations: 9/10
Once again, there are few graphical elements required for this style of game, but the graphics are this gen. and well done.
Gameplay: 10/10
Loads of depth to multiplayer games, and a good pacing built in to the gameplay.
Controls:10/10
I would only give less than a 10 in this category if there was no ability to change hotkeys or the controls were unresponsive/glitchy. Although I do not like the layout of the default hotkeys, I don't consider that a reason to downgrade this category.
Reliability: 8/10
The game is still early access and some bugs are being worked out. There are some issues with making lobbies and changing hosts mid-game that are being worked out, as well as a few smaller glitches.
User Interface (UI): 9/10
Very well put together to give an overview of how the game is progressing as well as easy access to your options. I took away a point because I think that the notification system could use some work when you are targeted by the black market or a shortage/surplus occurs.
Music and Sounds: 10/10
Some sounds are still being created, but the recently added new music and the completed sounds are very well done.
Originality: 10/10
I can only imagine how difficult it must be to enter a new sub-genre into the books. Soren Johnson and his team have done a great job in developing this original idea.
Community Vibe: 10/10
The developers listen closely to player feedback and are very active on the forums. The game is updated on a regular basis and has improved with each iteration.

Total Score: 90/100

If you're a fan of RTSs or enjoy market manipulation, I can highly recommend this game to you. If you enjoy a challenge, Offworld Trading Company will provide it to you. This is a Game You Absolutely Must Have :) .

Although there is plenty of room for casual players in this game, with its current player base of dedicated fans, I'd recommend people who put themselves in this category to watch some videos of the game before deciding to purchase.
Here is a video of some higher level gameplay with good commentary: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V0GaPMCA86o

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nComing home from school the other day, my oldest son asked me if there were any stock market games we could play this weekend.  Apparently, Black Tuesday has been a hot, recent scholastic topic.  After a quick discussion, we agreed that we’d give Offworld a go.  I've owned this game for about a year, having bought two copies right before it came into alpha, and played it with friends and my kids.  I enjoyed my initial experiences, but I only put about six hours into the game then.  Like Civ4, I didn't play this game too much at first, probably because I didn't really know what I was doing, and it was so new.  Now, like Civ4 (BTS especially), I'm hooked.  This game is accessible for anyone who can read and comprehend math, and has 20-50 minutes to spend.  The map and black market randomizations, plus the different faction choices and patent auctions insure that no game is ever like a previous one, and if you are playing against friends or family, be prepared for them to not speak to you for a while if it’s you doing the backstabbing.  In short, this is a great game designed and inspired by great game designers, and I highly recommend it.  Offworld Trading Company is the first game that got my kids to stop playing CS GO, and start plotting against each other through intrigue and economic espionage.  In my world, that means something.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't care what negative reviews you read about this game. (Multiplayer population will increase as people see the game.) Now I know the price point might be off-putting. But I'd rather pay $39.99 for OFFWORLD TRADING COMPANY, than the $49.99 I payed for GREY GOO.
I've played some games in my time. And this one is remarkable. I wish we had more games like it. It's what I wish the newest Sim City had aspired to.

Offworld Trading Company is pure genius.

If you're into economy games, you'll love it.

The goal is to buyout your opponents by amassing resources as one of several differnet types of colonies. Each has there strong and weak points. This premise alone seems pretty minimal, right?
Wrong.

You're gathering your metals, making steel, etc. You start gathering water, or food. You feel safe. You're doing alright, and your money is going up.
Suddenly one of your opponents EMPs your grouping of three water generating facilities.
Now you're going into debt.
Water is $212 a unit. And you need three units a tick. That's $636 you're going into debt, each tick.
Your debt risses, you have no spare cash. The duration" of the EMP is another THIRTY seconds.
You sell your stockpile of resources to lower your debt. It seems to be working.

reviewText:
Okay; but, not worth the £22 (25% off) I spent on it. Played for 11 hours before I completed it. Of which I would say 4 - 5 hours where learning to play (and the tutorials are great); but, then the main story I lost once, and then completed it the second time within 3 hours - I am going to update the difficulty from the default one that it sets as it does have replay value; but, the story is so short I wish I had spent the money on another game that would have had a better long term campaign length - even just double of the current campaign would have been enough.

Such as complete the current campaign with say 2 of the 4 races, then you go to another area of mars with the other 2 fraction in with a greater intensitiy and repeat with those 2 races.

Would I have brought the game again knowing what I know now - if it was around £15 I would have.
Will I try to retrun it - probably not as it does have some replay value, and I did enjoy it.
Will I be cautious about spending £22 with this company again - yes.

Overal very good concept, just really, really short for the price tag in my opinion.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

- PROS -

Elements of Stock Marketing
Elements of Production Mechanics (Supply/Demand)
A realistic approach towards coperate financing.
Interesting methods of victory.
Basic elements of auctioning.
Basic elements of share holding.

- CONS -

Lacking in content. These basic elements should be expanded upon.
In game UI could use a rework. Or simply made easier to access certain things. (Buttons to be moved around, to avoid slow computers conflicting with other background interfaces.)
Too Pricey for its lack of content.
Lacking in a diplomancy system. (Coperates talk to each other/deal with each other.)
Lack of freedom in terms of buying from other Companies.

- Overall -

Very simple, effective and efficient. The developers here have really impressed and hit the mark on this game. However for its Price I just have to disagree with it. Its too expensive for the amount of in game content thats offered. I played this game for about, 30 minutes and I achieved victory far too easily. Not because the game itself is easy, but because it really is just lacking in content.

To spice things up and really make the game unique and different. Consider adding more events.

Example:

Earthquakes.
Coperate diplomacy. ( The ability to deal and exchange with selective companies )
Add to the Debt system. Allow for Company to company investment (with return), or unknown shady investment with 5% - 10% or even 30% interest.

Those are just some general, throw around ideas. Hope this helps.

Early Access Review

Absolutely loving the game. The well designed gameplay eases you in and really feels like a game you can learn very quickly but take an age to master.

This video covers the first tutorial & my attempt at my first win: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PBBkC2pQMJU


Particularly as you move up the levels & start to play online against human opponents rather than against the AI.

The pace of the first tutorial is slower, which is needed to wrap your head around the basic game mechanics, but as soon as you start the second tutorial & try to win vs a competitor - the heat & pressure is on! I can only imagine the RTS stress playing against 3 or 4 actual players. Going to find this out now!

I heartily recommend this game - great fun, very well designed and has me hooked already within 30 mins! Well done Mohawk & Soren :-)

reviewText:
As a long time RTS and stragegy fan, as well as an extreme Civilazation fan, I have to say I was a bit disappointed with Offworld TC.  As a whole, this game feels more like a fantastic foundatation for a spectacularly complex trading sim versus what it actually offers.  Do not be fooled, you will devour this game in its entirety in a matter of hours.  It does not hold a candle to the complexity and depth that the Civ titles (and other leading titles) have to offer.

I purchased the deluxe edition of this game (on sale) for 39.59.  Within a matter of 2 days had not only beaten the campaign, but had exhausted (unless I missed something) every aspect of playability and replay value that the game has to offer.  A more reasonable price for what this game actually has to offer, at least in single player mode, is more like $10-15.

I found that I had lost the desire to keep playing after a very small amount of time.  I even stuck with it for a bit longer just to see if there was more that I perhaps had missed...turns out I found no reason to keep playing beyond the couple days I devoted to mastering it.  As a fan of the genre, I had high hopes of progress, strategy, and replay value that the best RTS/stragegy/sim/farming/economic games have to offer.

This review is not meant to ONLY bash the game.  With more content, resources, campaign options, and other things of this nature, this game could be epic.  In reality it's nothing more than a foundation for what could be an absolutely fantastic game of depth and strategy.  I would recommend this game only when the price is reduced to something more befitting of a game that lacks everything that was mentioned above.

In summary, this game is great and certainly worth playing, but only if the price is right for what the consumer can get out of it.  As of right now however, it feels incomplete and very limited as far as play choices, resources, strategy, economy, variability, and overall complexity,  Kind of sad that its almost over before it begins...

I am recommending this game because of its uniqueness and potential but on a scale of 1-10 this game is a 4, at least for the price.

I really, really, really wanted to like this game. It is right up my alley and I thought it would be a blast. Unfortunately not.  There is no joy in building an economic engine or a profitable company. There is no satisfaction in making good strategies. There is no logic in the buy-out end-game.
There will be games in which you are hit three four times a minute by sabotage. Every company will attack you and you can't execute a strategy for the spam.
There will be games in which you are the strongest company and suddenly find yourself bought out by a company worth half of your value. And I mean sudden. One moment you are thinking wow
date:
I am actually generating a profitable company here and then WHAM! Game over!.
It's a total WTF moment because there is no clue it's coming.
In Railroad Tycoon you could buy up your shares to keep from getting taken over.
Not in this game.
It's simply not fun.
It could be

While in it's current early state I've had a great time playing OTC. It's a game that appears simple but there's a lot to learn from what I can tell. Scanning at the start of the game you begin to see what resources are available so it's this instant choice on do you find a few good tiles then set down fast and grab whatever you can or do you hold an extra few seconds incase there's a better spot for your HQ. You then need to pick which type of business you want to set up with based on what resources you can see and the way you prefer to play. Begin managing your claims and where you position your production tiles etc for maximum efficency. Controlling debt, being mindful of the market, expanding competitively against your opponents. I've had a great time and I greatly look forward to the future of this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Offworld Trading Company™ – Competitive Market Strategy

Rating: Recommended


For young aspiring entrepreneurs, Earth has grown much too crowded to do business. The vast openness of the barren planet Mars calls to explorers and investors alike. Once the colonies have been established, the entrepreneurs see the potential for profit. Businesses start popping up on the Red Planet – this is where you come in.

Offworld Trading Company is a fast-paced strategy game all about manipulating the Martian market, producing goods and buying out other businesses. Natural resources are limited and competition is brutal for control of the richest veins. Placement of mines, extractors, and other resource-producing buildings is critical to amassing enough materials to purchase new structures, upgrade your headquarters and get more claims. Each claim allows you to place one structure – use them wisely.

Price values of the thirteen types of resources fluctuates with market activity. Is someone selling off their entire aluminum stash? Expect to see prices nosedive. You can also buy stock in your opponents’ companies. If all stock gets purchased and you have enough money, you can buy them out, causing all their buildings to come under your control. The goal of the game is to be the last man standing by buying out all your opponents.

The only bad points this game has so far are its high retail price ($40) and the black market feature. The black market in this game makes investing in buildings risky. Found a high (level 3) water deposit? Someone can purchase an Underground Nuke for a paltry $1000 - $3000 to knock that deposit down to low (level 1) permanently. It seems an unnecessary element in an already risky business environment.

I haven’t explored deep into this game, still in Early Access at this point, but it’s been both challenging and rewarding. You may ask “Is it really worth $40 in Early Access?” No. Wait for at least 25% off, preferably 50% or more. If you’re a dedicated economy gamer (Railroad Tycoon, Capitalism series), this might trip your trigger. Pick it up if it goes on sale.

Not Recommended
Recommended with Caution
- Recommended
Highly Recommended
Recommended as Essential

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Its a very interresting market simulation/RTS that getting along nicely for an early access game.
The basic mechanics revolves arround manipulating prices (through supply and demand, as well as some special events) to make enough money to buy out your opponents, while using the market and special black market effects to gain an advantage and prevent your opponent from doing the same.
It takes a few tries getting into to understand the mechanics but after that it starts to get very fun in multiplayer. Gametime is arround 15 to 20 min for a 1v1, sadly the playerbase is not yet big enough to regularily play more than a 1v1 match. On the plus side, Quick match will find you opponents in short time pretty regularly now.
Fazit: I enjoy playing it now, and it looks to be moving in a good direction, so i look forward to an even better game at full release. I would definately recommend it.

reviewText:
If you love M.U.L.E. buy this game. If you don't know what M.U.L.E. is play it free on planetmule or alternatively buy this game. If you hate M.U.L.E. I respect your bizarre life choices, but do examine this game to see if your complaints were addressed.

Offworld trading company is in my opinion the best non-combat RTS on the market. It's not M.U.L.E. but it takes that core concept and give it's a fresh modern spin. It is a well balanced blend of risk vs reward which is simple to learn but challenging to master. A lot of attention and love has been poured into the game and it shows.

Considerations:
* Game is fast paced.
It's a not a case who ever issues orders the fastest wins like most RTS but the game is about balancing you income and the market environment which influences that income is in constant flux and you must be constantly on your game to adjust your strategy and make choices as the climate shifts if you wish to stay on top of your competitors. It eases you into it buy things get more frantic as things go on as you are juggling more and more avenues open up for players to sabotage each other. Point being there isn't time to relax in a match like their would be in a turn based strategy. Most people think a quick game is a good but this is a preference you have to weigh up for yourself.

* The extra campaign features are just for single player.
It is a constant gripe of mine that competitive games that offer mechanics for campaign map don't accommodate multiplayer. Sometimes you want spend to an afternoon with a couple of friends competing for a long game of back and forth struggle. As usual that's not an option. The campaign mode offer a fun and in depth expansion to gameplay experience by incentivising you to continue playing successive matches and thus is makes a good introductory experience to the game and augments your single player experience so it's more then just death match skirmishes with AI bots. Just a shame death match skirmishes is the only experience you can share with your friends.

* Competitive play will take practice.
The downside of simple to learn difficult to master means that without putting the time in you simply will not be able to compete with experienced players. The AI is very well developed at this point as a training tool but you are still going to take a beating before you can compete with regular players.

* Replayability.
The game has a solid core mechanic with a good deal of depth but that's the extent of it. The different factions all follow the same core rules they just each get to break specific rules, meaning learning to play one means you can play them all, you just have different ways to apply their advantages to different strategies. There isn't a lengthy/branching tech tree and if you've played one 30 minute match you've seen all the game has to offer. It's not that it lacks content (it's packed with it) it's just that the content is focused on a specific experience. It's fair to equate it to a game of speed chess. How many matches can you play before you get bored? For some people it depends on the opponents, others just love and can't get enough of the game while other just enjoy a single match every now and then. When you buy the game you a buying a quality board to play with. It's up to you to assess how much playtime you'll get out of the board.

If these considerations do not concern you then I can heartily recommend this title. It is solidly built, well polished and has benefited from rigorous balance testing. Also it's fun, which is what matters most. If you are unsure if it's a fit for you or not remember you can always buy the game, play a few matches to see what it's like and then refund it. 2 hours playtime is plenty of time to get a feel for the core mechanics. For many of us it's exactly the revival of this niche genre we have been waiting for.

reviewText:
I've only got about four hours into the game and so far it is an ever changing, fast paced, economy game. I played through the tutorial and did a few games against the computer, and lost, but I am starting to get the hang of it.

Pros:
Fast paced
Orginal idea


Cons:
So much orange on Mars
Fast paced
Music gets annoying after a while
Steap learning curve
Computers will gang up on you early if you pull ahead fast

Don't let the cons change your mind, at the current price point of $40 for the delux version it's worth the money.

reviewText:
Offworld is a unique RTS game that captures the best and worst parts of capitalism, in space! I've been following this game for some time, and I am not disappointed by the results of the hard work of the development team.

The overall objective of the game is to become the most profitable off-world trading company by becoming the most profitable and efficient corporation around. You'll achieve this by building supply chains of goods, selling them to a local colony, shipping them off the planet, and using your gains to buyout your competitors while avoiding being bought out yourself.

Positives:
+Amazing soundtrack by Christopher Tin (composer of Baba Yetu, of Civ 4 fame)
+Quick cutthroat gameplay; the decisions on where to land, and what to start producing are the beginnign of a race to quickly provide goods that meet the demands of a local colony.
+The gameplay is unique: there isn't any 'militay' component to this game; instead you will be competing with other corporations in the marketplace to become the most efficient and profitable offworld-trading company.
+Interesting hostile actions - while you can play it straight and just compete on the 'free market', there are a variety of options to sabatoge your competitors through illicit means.
+Unique factions  - each faction has their own set of strengths, and weaknesses; playing one versus another feels very interesting and different.
+Great writing (in the tutorial and opening missions, at any rate).

Negatives:
-It seems like there's not really a comeback mechanic once you start to fall behind; if you make a few mistakes early, you're probably going to have a bad time. I could be wrong, but once I start to lose, I continue to lose.
-The factions aren't visually all that different.
-This game is probably overpriced for the content that you're getting; I recommend purchasing this game on at least a 25% sale, probably closer to 50%.
-I'm unsure about the replayability of the game; so far, the experience has been novel; outside of multiplayer, I don't think the game will provide more than 20 horus of gameplay.

Overall, I highly recommend this game for RTS players who want a different experience - namely one that focuses on competitive supply chains and economic efficiency. The game has a lot of character, and has been very enjoyable to explore.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was interested in this game since it was announced and I can safely say it is everything I wanted it to be. The AI is incredible, constantly buying and destroying buildings to account for changes in the market. I can only imagine what complex algorithms are driving these decisions. If the AI isn't cheating, then the developers must be geniuses. Thanks for this awesome game, I can't wait to see it finished. Too bad it is a bit under-the-radar.

The only changes I wish to see made are to the stock market. Currently it is not worth it to sell stocks because the stock is worth more than the sell price. Stock market trading needs to be more strategic rather than just a button you click when you want to beat another player. Players should be encouraged to invest in other players, possibly by removing the penalty for selling a stock and by removing the stock boost when you buy a stock. This way I can invest in a player early on, then sell the stocks and turn a fair profit later.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overall, somewhat suprised and pleased with the game. I'm still not terribly happy with the price point (I think for EA something around $20 would be more fair with a possible $30-$35 point when the game is finished) but I don't think I wasted my money.

Some of my negative comments first:
- The UI can be a bit clunky and laggy at points.
- If you leave a campaign game in the middle you seem to automatically lose that round (no way to save it and return later unless I'm being oblivious).
- If you start losing rounds in the campaign it becomes extremely difficult to make up the lost ground.
- No clear indication of when a campaign is over/ability to have multiple campaigns going at once.

My biggest takeaway - no problems with the gameplay. The rounds definetly go by quicker then I thought they would as do the campaigns. I do wish there was an option in the campaign to vary the number of starting opponents (simply because once they are all eliminated you win and they can get eliminated fairly quickly) but thats fairly minor. The AI is extremely robust and even the start of the game takes some thought (eg do you drop your base quickly and move to what nodes you can see, do you spend longer scanning hoping to hit the motherload, etc). It does feel like it's really all just a race to the offworld markets (they are so lucrative that whoever gets their first is more or less going to win the game) but the gameplay itself is great. The game takes some forethought as you are limited in what you can do via a limited number of claims (it would be nice if you yourself could give up or auction off a claim). Graphics overall are simple (but clean) and make it extremely easy to see what is going on in-game.

All in all I still do have a bit of an issue recommending it at this price point but if you think you'd happen to like the genre and aren't tight with cash I would pick the game up. Hopefully this turns into a good example of Early Access but even if we never heard another word from the Devs the game is completely playable now.

Edit: After playing some more I do have to say there are some annoying balance issues (some of the races" are clearlier to play/win with then others and some of the abilities/techs are way to strong while others are almost useless) but hopefully those will be addressed going forward."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a promising unique type of Real-Time Strategy (RTS) game.  Even on its normal speed, that you could adjust even in multiplayer, things are fast paced enough to finish a match in 30mins but plenty of time to think about your actions.

You begin by scanning the map for a good starting location.  Each player does the same, but here's the catch, if you are one of the last to found you get bonus tiles (called claims) to build buildings on because you are pretty much forced away from the prime locations that the first founders took, unless your lucky and they didnt spot something.

After you found, this is the fastest part of the game, because you want to claim certain tiles first.  Now each game is going to have a different strategy.  Perhaps you want to claim that lone carbon resource so no one else can get it and force them to buy off the market.  Maybe you think that the other players are going to sell water down so the price to purchase it would be $1, so forgo water and go for more prime minerals or power sources.

As the game progresses, you can buy items off the black market or on auctions.  Some help yourself but most of the time you are buying them to stop production of your enemies or to steal one of their resources for a short time.  Each time a player buys, say a dynamite stick, the price goes up for all players the next time you want one.  There is a lot of choices in a fast matched game to choose.

End game is always the same, trying to constantly protect your Offworld Markets with shields (Goon Squads), trying your best to disrupt the enemies Offworld Markets.  It usually ends with the first one to amass a huge amount of cash to buyout the remaining shares of your competitor.  It really is no different than a military RTS how to end a game, always ends the same way with hordes of marines going time and time again.  However looking at stock prices for the end game and scanning over to your enemy base to disrupt stuff is about all there is in the end game, nothing fancy like seeing buildings get destroyed by your units.

All and all, it is a great game to try out.  They havn't really stated what will be coming in the future except for leagues and ladders like any good RTS game would do.  If they do that, they need to limit the observer mode to a delay or something, and I can see free for all getting out of whack with teams trying to join in and gang up on a player.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eSc9IG8ywxQ

Upon loading up the game I was surprised to find that despite the early access tag, it's actually a full game with polish.

The game is sort of similar to Civ in that it is a 4x, but that's where the comparisons will end. It's closer to an economic simulator. You build infrastructure that produces resources. Resources can be used to produce new infrastructure. Infrastructure can take resources and created finished products out of them. And with all that you can sell them out to a dynamic market in which the price will fluxuate based on how much each player is selling of that commodity.

The main part of the game is surviving as a company and buying out other ones. If your company value falls low you become vulnerable to losing shares of your company to competitors. Your company value is your debt and your infrastructure value combined. So paying off debt will make it harder for people to buying you, while having a large sum will allow you to buy an opponent.

Once you have bought an opponent you gain their stuff in full and gain a significant advantage.

The game comes with a tutorial for playing the game and playing each of the four factions. Each faction comes with its own unique set of opening boosts and needs. With a few dozen maps to choose from there is tonnes of gameplay value for your dollar.

Fans of games like Port Royale, Rise of Venice, Anno 2070, and C.E.O. should definitely give this game a try. For people who are newer to economic simulators and want to give it a try, this might be the game for you.

reviewText:
After playing for 70+ hours, I still don't understand why anyone is making a negative review on this game, unless it was not what they expected. It's Starcraft meets Civilization with a stock market. Except, that it is neither Starcraft nor Civilization. It's something totally unique. If you don't like how short the skirmishes are, then play some campaigns (personally, I wish the campaigns were longer than 7 matches. Marathon, anyone?). If the AI is predictable and unchallenging, then turn up the difficulty and watch them pound you in the ground - it will improve your strategic capability, if nothing else. If you don't like keeping tabs on your competitors while you're busy advancing your own goals, then you're in the wrong genre entirely.

The beauty of this game is there isn't just ONE strategy to win, but dozens or perhaps hundreds. There are many choices that can be made (by you and your competition) that can affect the later part of the match. And then you throw in the variability of the game's stock market based resource pricing. Sure, if everyone is producing and selling iron, then the price of iron will tank, but unforeseen and ultimately random events can change anything. You may need to adapt: if you decide to make your fortune on glass and then the price of glass plummits because of market saturation, you have the option to scrap your facilities and focus on something new.

It's not a set-it-and-forget-it type of RTS. You have to adjust and adapt to each unique scenario and you may have to do so several times to achieve victory. It's the kind of strategy game that leaves you wanting more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a great game, lots of fun. The first round will be very overwhelming, however the learning curve is easy. It is still in beta, I hope they add a minimap and some hot key functions. navigating is a little odd. An issue I find with all steam games is the hot corners on mac, if you have it enabled, mess up the game. The task bar pops up over the game interface as well as the header bar. It can be irritating when scrolling to the edges is the only way to navigate.

It's super fun, but fast paced. You'll be done with each round in 30-45 mins each.  It does leave you wanting something more enduring sometimes. I want to play longer, do more, expand. I don't want to own Mars in an hour or less every time.

Again I know it's a beta but the game seems unbalanced, for example my second time through I had bought out all my competitors but one and owned all the resources. I had lots of money and resources, but I was just sitting and messing around. Unfortunately the AI generated enough over a long period of time and bought me out. I lost even tho I owned 90% of the map. Seemed odd.

Overall, lots of fun, not time consuming. Leaves you wanting more strategy space RTS tho. Great beta! I hope to see some more features in the full release. 100% worth it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

High price for an 'early access' game.

I enjoy challenges, but mostly play games for their 'enjoyment factor'.
The idea is nice, much of how the game is set up is great.  However, the approach seems to be from the extreme side of 'play the market', and not from the standard view of 'invest in your resources to build your empire'

Each 'faction' has certain needs that are emphasized, but you can't invest your extremely limited resource placements based upon those needs. It seems impossible to win on first run, forcing you to play through to see which commodoties pay the highest returns, and build to emphasize those - knowing you're paying out for the commodities to survive, utilizing 'profits' from commodities you probably don't need.

Often as you seem on the cusp of winning, one of the  competition will suddenly, and quite rapidly, buy you out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Love the game and has potential. I do have a few comments and suggestions tho.

I'm a fan of the campaign mode and wish it could extend Much longer. There should be an option for more maps than around the 6-8 currently.

That aside there is a steeper learning curve than people realise and certain information isn't readily available for those who just jump into playing.


The tutorial doen't explain certain mechanics, like the fledgling colony you're there to support. When it fails (loses all population) some people fail to realize this and think they've been bought out with no notification. This is not the case as they are your local consumers. The larger the independent colony is the more resources they suck off of the market.

Having a resource monopoly can be your best friend. Just know when to hold, and when to flood the market. The ability to precisely time buy/sell actions is paramount.

The least powerful faction so far in my opinion is the scientific. Especially in the campaign mode, as they have no indipendent water production to start with.

Geothermal in campaign is near useless so are the ice and dry ice condensors. Half of the time you don't have 2 of the 3 mentioned if not none at all.

My suggestion to improve scientific is give their buildings slant drilling (except mines and quarries and water pumps) by default instead of the reduced sabatoge innate perk.

Another thing that should change would be if your debt is higher than some % of  your asset value, any cash made should automatically go to pay off debt, including the automatic selling of stocks that you may have. I know there is an option to have all cash towards debt; however, at a certain point I think lenders would hire collections on your goods. This would allow some negative operational budgets but prevent abuse. As is your stock could be worthless, however maintaing stock in other companies gives a high value well beyond what should be viable.

I was attempting to see how high of a population i could get the independent colony to grow and I managed to get an AI opponent into -10,000,000 in debt with an asset value around 1.5 million.  What was interesting is that he still held high cash reserves , and decent stock value because of an earlier purchase of some of my stock. I got it to almost 70 population when my game crashed due to me spamming up around 30+ offworld trades.

For the love of God give us a save/load option in Campaign! Also please fix the game lag from opening up any specialized building menus (engineering upgrade, hack net, etc).

One final thing I'd love added is a Sell at 'X' value" option similar to the auto sale of electricity but have an option to start/stop selling at a certain value. This would further increase the potential of market manipulations

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll put this out there to start: I picked this game up on sale for $20, which after having played it feels about right. This is a recommendation based on the $20 pricetag, I do not feel it's worth $40 quite yet.

Pros:+Interesting concept that is (mostly) executed well.
+Four different faction types that are relatively balanced.
+Good level of mechanical depth that makes the game more enjoyable as you learn.
+Multiplayer is fun, particularly co-op
+Winning is satisfying - there's no other way to put it. When you buyout your last competitor, you feel like you've earned your monopoly.

Cons:-Tutorials are bare bones at best, useless at worst. On top of not covering very basic but vital mechanics (using claims without building, the usefulness of upgrade buildings such as the offworld market/patent office, etc) the last three tutorials simply throw you into a standard game and tell you to win with a given faction, with barely a blurb about that faction's unique traits as a guide. You will need to suffer through a lot of trial and error before you feel skilled at the game.
-The market essentially functions the same way every game. Certain goods (electronics, chemicals, food) are basically always the most expensive on the market, so a strategy of spam electronics late game" is always viable

reviewText:
Product received for free

Offworld Trading Company is a space strategy game with many great attributes and with constant support from the developers.
If this review is too long for you, I suggest you to only read the first paragraph about the game's content and the final verdict at the end.

What is happening in the game:You are in control of a colony, based on Mars, and you have to get as rich as possible. You can build mines, factories and farms and then sell them when the price is right. Defend yourself from other companies and try to take them over.

Pros:    Trading Aspect | There are a lot of similar strategy games, but this game has something other games rarely have: trading. It adds something new to the game and it makes it different from other games of the similar genre, which is definitely a huge advantage. Trading has a lot of different options since you can have different strategies for higher profits and you can even influence the prices, just as you can in real life (if you're wealthy enough).
Appearance | This game looks great and it doesn't use a lot of system resources, which is great. Even if there are a lot of things happening on your screen, it is still very easy to track everything. This is sometimes a problem, especially when you get so wealthy that you can afford anything, but your screen gets littered as well. Anyway, this game doesn't have this problem.
Tutorials | This game offers an amazing tutorial which covers all the basics well and prepares you for your journey. There are five tutorial levels and each one covers a few connected topics. When you complete the tutorials, you're mostly good to go as the game itself is not extremely complicated, but I will also mention this later on.
Learning Curve | You don't need any prior experience with similar games as this game teaches you game mechanics very gently with some funny dialogs, easy-to-understand instructions and helpful explanations. I've never seen something like that and it's really something every game should have. I sometimes feel frustrated when I don't understand what the game wants from me, but no such thing happened with Offworld Trading Company.
Game Modes | Game modes are definitely another great thing about this game as there are many of them, which means more hours of interesting gameplay. After completing the tutorial, you can play some prepared practice games. Then, you can play the Campaign, Skirmish, Daily Challenge levels and even multiplayer ones!
Atmosphere | The music in this game is really great and game events also have some influence on what kind of music is played. The sound effects are also pretty great (such as explosions and other things). This is one of rare such games where you don't need to turn on your own music if you don't want to get bored!
Achievements and Rewarding | When you do something good in this game, it really lets you know that you did something good and that you learned something. There are quite a few achievements, some harder than others, and they are one of the rewards for making progress. This really makes the player to play the game more since it's like getting a cookie each time you do something of value. This developer really knows how to keep its players!
Almanac DLC | These kind of things are usually available as paid DLCs, but this DLC comes with the game for free when you purchase it. You get access to many things, such as a 91-page (!!) strategy guide by professional players and designer notes from the developer.
Cons:    Pricing | 40€ for a game is really too much, even though it's a very good game. Games of the same genre are usually priced at least 10€ lower. If you manage to find someone who wants the game as well, you can buy the Deluxe Edition which gives you an extra copy of this game. Otherwise, I just don't find this game to be worth so much. Hopefully, the developer will drop the price at some point or at least put a nice discount on it on every major sale.
No SteamOS Support | Linux lovers are sadly excluded from this game's player base as well.  I wonder when developers are going to realize that there are some hardcore Linux fans that only buy games when they support their operating system ...
The final verdict:Offworld Trading Company is most certainly an amazing game. Apart from its trading mechanics, there are also great graphics, many game mode, a very helpful tutorial and many other great things. Overall, there is nothing particularly bad about this game apart from its pricing. I still think that 40€ is way too much for such a game. When you do buy it, you should have no problems liking it, but I do recommend waiting for a sale before deciding to buy this game. Hopefully, there will also be a price drop in near future.

With love,
BirdCute

Note that my copy of this game was obtained for free for reviewing purposes. However, this did not affect the quality and objectivity of this review.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The RTS-economics focus really interested me, and I was sold on it. I played for about 3 hours  right away. It really grows on you. If you like the level of complexity of Civ, but with the focus shifted to commerce, and played at a faster (RTS) pace, where you're always busy and focused on efficiency, you'll love this game.

Pros:
+Highly realistic economic forces, including pirating, debt interest and corporate sabotage
+RTS pace requires you to constantly be on alert and focused
+Challenging and rewarding to build a complex resource network and corporate empire

Cons:
-A bit of a learning curve, don't skip the tutorials.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIt makes me sad but i cannot give this a thumbs up...yet. The game is fun and a fantastic idea. I love tycoon and money makinga games so i was really excited when I saw this, but $40 looked a little steep so i waited till it was half off. Wow was I glad. The game is a good challenge but very similar every time. The campaign is just...well...for lack of a better word, lame. And when you win in a regular its a strange feeling of emptiness as the little fireworks start popping and a giant YOU WON floats across the sky, This is because you fighting and fighting and selling and launching rockets n then you realize you can just sell all the products in you inventory, buy all of every competitors stock and then in two seconds the game is over. No continuation no new threats to ever sprout. For lovers of classics like AOE like myself where you have to beat your opponent to a pulp and search for and destroy every last unit and building until you see your foes at their knees making some lame exuse why they lost and you get that triumphant message of victory, you feel like youre fighting tooth and nail and then it kind of landslides n youre like oh look i won. ok i should go get a life now. It is also somewhat lacking in variety and substance. That said it is a good game and is still being worked on. But at the moment the most I would want to pay for this game is $15. 40 is faaar too expensive for what the game currently offers. I will keep playing it though and hope for it to improve. If you're thinking about buying it, wait for a good sale. 20 is ok for this game. I simply can't recommend this game at its full price and current state. If either of those changes for the better i'll be prompt to alter this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am reviewing this game far earlier than I usually do.  Generally I try to get 10 or 12 hours in on a game so that, even if I haven't finished it yet, I have a solid feel for all the merits and flaws of a game.  However, I am having so much fun with this one that I decided to review it already.

Now, the game has flaws.  It does have a tendency to lag out a bit, especially when engaged in the daily challenges.  The graphics are pleasant, but nothing particularly special... of which I approve, since my graphics setup is more for work than gaming, so I have trouble with graphically intensive games.  And you can further turn the graphics down to save on your computer's resources, which is nice, also.

There is a minimum of combat (although you can do several different kinds of sabotage, including detonate an opponent's property), since the game is primarily market based warfare, and you win by buying out the competition.  Managing to balance your debt, so that your stock price stays up, while still generating the liquid assets to buy out an opponent makes for some interesting and fun strategizing.

There are points where this game lacks, but it's still in Early Access, so that's no big surprise.  Because of this, further reviews will be coming as the game develops.

Initial Scoring: 8 out of 10

reviewText: This is quite a special game that does not fit into any conventional category. It's an RTS-like game but there are no combat units to manage. You win by out thinking your opponents (AI, in my case) by outplaying them in the commodity market. The game's premise is that you and a few other AIs are setting up shop in Mars. You race against each other to see who make the most money out of mining minerals in the planet. The more of certain minerals you sell, the price of the minerals will go down in the stock market. This manipulation of the stock market will enable you to influence the net worth of your company as well as your opponent's. You win buy buying the company shares, having a corporate take over. The action is pretty intense and yet, you can always auto pause to take a breather and think of your next strategy. Having high reflex and able to execute many actions per minutes does not matter here, this is not your usual RTS. And yet, the amount of excitement from creating espionage to influece the stock markets, causing the shares of your competitors to drop is very real. Each game is short, maybe an hour for each sitting, very useful for a quick fix before bed. Highly recommended!

Pros:

-Easy to pickup

Cons:

My strategy gaming experience was exclusively turn based before I tried this game. Because of that I was a little skeptical that I'd enjoy it, but after playing a few matches against ruthless friends and the almost as ruthless AI, I gotta say... it's great fun! As an RTS noob, I found it fairly easy to pickup the basics. The fast pace takes some getting used to but I really like the economy-focused concept. I'd recommend it to anyone looking for a fun little title to play when you don't have a whole lot of time to spare but need to get your game on.

I think the only thing wrong with it is the (at present) 40 dollar price tag. I personally believe it is a bit steep. However if you disagree or can catch it on sale, definitely do.

reviewText:
What a fantastic strategy/RTS! I was looking for something to scratch the RTS itch I had and I've always been a fan of the economic side of these games more so than the combat. Coming from classics like Age of Empires and Civilization, I find this is a nice blend of everything I love about strategy games. Quick Summary

Pros:
- Deep economic simulation and strategy
- Ever changing and dynamic games
- Stellar soundtrack, to be expected of Tin
- Quicker matches makes multiplayer actually feasible

Cons:
- Could use a bit more content (better total stats, unique scenarios other than campaign, better multiplayer functionality)
- Price is a bit steep, especially when comparing to games with unbelievable amount of content and quality such as the Civ series

Overall I recommend this game for its price point though and that mostly has to do with the fact that there is no game quite like it. Polished, unique, and a ton of fun.

reviewText:
There's a lot of hype around this game since the Lead Designer of Civ 4 also designed and built this game... and that was the only selling point I needed when I bought this game while it was on sale for $20 a couple of months ago.

The final product was well worth the wait, a video intro, an awesome soundtrack, loading screen art work, updated UI, and I'm sure there is plenty more. The game was still very good when it only offered it's core mechanics, now with a fresh coat of paint it feels and looks even better now. All there is left is to leave it in the community's hands now.

I'm a little impatient with the PvP, but it's starts slow for a reason.

If you like Civilizations, you'll probably like this game as well... but for completely different reasons.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Offword Trading Company is a fun, challenging, economic trading sim. It's the only early access game I've played that I would actually recommend buying in its current state. It already feels like a complete game, and a fun one at that.

To start a match, you and your competitors search mars for a place to start your business ventures. The map is randomly comprised of different resources, used to either support your colony, or turn a profit. There are a couple of different colonies, all of which use the available resources differently, providing a slight variety on play-styles.

The matches last around 30 minutes or so, which I think is a nice change from the time-investment of the Civ games.

There is also a blackmarket, where you can purchase goods to sabotage your competitors, or even manipulate the market in your favor. Be aware: the AI are very well programmed -- don't expect any mercy!

Is it worth the price?" Yes! Stop asking and start playing."

reviewText:
Overall, this RTS game is a refreshing take on a familiar concept: Corporate Warfare as Alien Colonization RTS.  I've been playing it now for three days, and overall - I really like this game.  My only issue is that it seems the devs really took a few shortcuts that seem to show, the sort that you might not see in a release from one of the more established publishers.

First, typos - you'll see them in the game and referred to in discussions.  Seriously, guys - if you can develop a game you can spell check.  Just lazy IMO.

Second, balance - the game does not seem balanced between the difffering factions nor with the AI.  So far it seems to be either very easy to win, or impossible to win.  There are a lot of moving parts" in this game - i.e. a lot of resources
recommended: and attack options via the "black market" and hacker array to contend with
hoursPlayed: and no matter what you do the AI will make all the necessary calculations much faster than a human to determine the best strategy to win.  Devs have said this isn't true in discussion
voteText: but with respect they understand the game differently than a new user and they should listen to the criticisms.\n\nThird
helpfulPercent: font/resource icon size - there are many instances when the fonts are honestly nearly too small to read.  Anyone who might need reading glasses (not just middle-aged gamers like me) will find it hard to read numbers
votesHelpful: which is pretty important given this is a game of corporate warfare and espionage.  Seriously
votesTotal: make the fonts/resource icons like 10-15% bigger and it's much more playable.\n\nFourth - there seem to be issues with multi-player

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is a lot of fun, there's a learning curve for this type of game until you get the basic hang of it (31 hours of play until my first win). The UI is fine to me, could be refined or polished up later on. The graphics are decent in that they're not childish looking, but colorful and well done without being too detailed and distracting from the real content. Another great added feature is the customization of gameplay options.  Map size, location, resource amounts, black markets and many more options available to pick from.

The factions are great and seem well balanced on the surface, until technology and research are conducted with some factions  gaining a very strong edge. Some technology can compliment a faction weakness very well or enhance upon current factional strengths.

Gameplay can be quick and brutal, once you've mastered the learning curve you can be just as brutal. After 31 hours of gameplay trying different factions, and tactical approaches I won. OTC will eventually unleash your inner mastermind when you learn which Black Market sabotage to use on the leader of the pack to keep them in check and in debt. Low on power? Go steal some. Combination tech and sabotage can render great net returns with the correct amount of timing.
---
My only negatives are not knowing what the sound effects mean and the exact location of my affected colony. I feel like Factional structures should have an easily identified signature look rather than a colored border. It seems there's only one way to win and that's... Offworld Trading. Every game feels like a race to Offworld shipment rockets where other rts have multiple methods for obtaining victory.

If you're looking for something fun and different with 30 minutes to kill, this game will please. I bought the game even after reading the negative reviews and was able to overlook the smaller details.
