reviewText:
Early Access Review

While limited in content (only a 406 MB download on windows atm), this is a promising little trading game with a hopefully bright future.

You get to choose from 4 different classes of corporation to play from. Standard capitalists, Robots, Scavengers and Scientists. They each have a very different play style that works for them, for example Robots don't require food or water to survive, meaning they can focus right away on resource gathering.

You can't just throw down a load of buildings to gather what you need right away, you have to 'claim' ground and resources to gather them, and you can bid against other corporations or upgrade your head-quarters to get more 'claims'.

To win a game you have to buyout your opponents corporation, this gets harder as the game goes on, and the surviving corporations get bigger and more effective, but a single campaign could last maybe a couple of hours.

rapid expansion, careful selling and buying of goods, and sometimes abit of espionage can soon become formulaic. For example I've only spent about 4 hours, and I've manage to figure out how to win every time with the Robot faction (haven't won much with the other 3 yet)

IF the dev's add more to the game then I could see a lot of re-playability in this game, but at the moment its limited, and you may wish to wait while the price tag drops a bit, I kinda regret getting this at £26 (that was with a 10% discount).

Wait a few months, see what the price is like, see how much its changed, and I'll come back and do a second review of the updated version.

It's not an interesting RTS (though i might be proven wrong if in a couple of years we see this game played competively, which I doubt). reviewText:
I have given this game a recommendation, but I wouldn't call it a complete or total recommendation as there are some parts of the experience that didn't really meet my expectations.

The good:  The game tutorials are humorous and the gameplay is interesting enough. I would call it a resource management game or 'an RTS without troops' if that makes any sense.  I like it overall.

The bad:  I bought this game to play as a co-op experience and that's why I thought it came with a free 2nd copy - to play with a friend!  Turns out that there is no co-op campaign and it's basically just multiplayer skirmishing against AIs or other humans that can be considered cooperative.  I wish games would stop being labeled as co-op if they only have it in the multiplayer mode - that should be called multiplayer co-op or something to differentiate the two.

The ugly:  The single player mode is well designed and has some very interesting mechanics but it's damn short.  It hardly feels like the mechanics of planning your company and investing your personnel while managing your cash flows have a chance to amount to anything over the few chances you get to make choices.  It feels like they cut the single player down to the shortest allowable length, which is too bad as it has potential.

I recommend this game but be aware of the above.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A deep RTS that requires more skill and strategy than a high ATM.

Offworld Trading Company had been on my wishlist for a while before I decided to buy it but I am so pleased I bought the game.

Some reviews stated the game was to simple or shallow and this were the ones that made me think twice before pulling the trigger but this is one of the deepest games I have ever played and whilst it is very simple to pick up (thanks to a very good tutorial) its a very hard game to master.

You have a few options when it cames to playing pick from the single player skrimish mode or campaign both of which provide a very hard to beat and smart A.I. and the campaign is endlessy replayable, a test your score against others daily challange and of course multiplayer.

As the title states this is not a game where a high action per minute rate is the be all and end all but a game that requires a plan (a plan that you also might need to abandon ) and some forward thinking.

All in all a great game that appeals to someone like myself who does not enjoy the more classic RTS games.

Early Access Review

Plays a bit like a real-time board game. Has a very futuristic-styled Monopoly feel to it. Once you play a few games, it becomes a little repetitive - there doesn't seem to be a lot of depth yet, but it is alpha.

Games are very fast. Would be better if you could have longer games that aren't ended so quickly by buying out companies. Instead of this system, players/AI should self-elect to sell their shares, or be forced to when they're in debt because of another player's monopoly. This way, there will eventually be an end, but at least it won't be 5 minutes into the game where another computer player suddenly owns 5 companies, leaving it pretty pointless to continue playing.

reviewText:
This is a really good game. It is an RTS but with really no units to speak of. It is an economic sim like Anno but with greatly streamlined gameplay. It is a multiplayer game with an incredibly strong single-player campaign with progressive unlocks.

It is by the lead designer of Civ4, and it shows. It is all about fun with incredible depth beneath it on every facet. Also the music is incredible. It's by Christopher Tin. You know that awesome song in Civilization 4 (Babu Yetu, which is Swahili for Out Father)? He did that. He does it again here. It feels somber as you enter in. It is tense as the game roles with his music. It ties together nicely.

I played it under early access, but it is so, so much better now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well,  in it current state the game is rather easy and broing after a few hours of play.  I was excpecting a little bit more even from the alpha release. Winning is not winning as it is a mass scramble to buy up more claims, expand your base and build up your tradebale items.  For the price point I was expecting more options of trading, pipe lines and more detailed process to extract your resources from the ground. everything in between is automatic(bring in and return of resources). Maybe adding ship building may help to add a little more flavour and to add more depth to collection of resources.  To me it seems you need more stuff to do, and less about the capitalist pig system we live in today. Buying out your competion is fun but it should be a little less predictable and more random events.  Sabotage and goons are a nice addition but I find it very lack luster and overall not that interesting.   I was expecting this game to have more options, pipelines, trains, space stations to deliver your items to and be able to ship out from to earth or other planets.

over al I cant really reccomend this game in its current state, Especially at $40.00 price point, feels like 10-20 at most would have been sutiable.  And this is a small game, not a grand strategy I was hoping for. I enjoy no armies in it just, need more things to do to keep my brain in the game.

Pros-
- Great concept
- Graphics ok

cons
- lackluster overall gaming experience - lacks in depth realistic  resouce gathering, mining, and processing.
- Very basic layout and buiuldings.



Overall


roll the dice if you want, I waited for a few months to get this game - I have been following it on the internet - and now what it has been released - slightly dissappointed more then I was happy. But hopefully this game will have new features added and the game will get more in depth - I will update later after a few more hours.

( I WISH THEY HAD A NEUTRAL BUTTON)  not no or yes - But i will go with no !

reviewText:

First Impressions:
The art style is amazing, and very professionally executed, and the UI is intuitive and well designed for the most part. The tutorial series could explain how to manipulate prices/research etc a little better, but I figured it out in my first couple of games. One thing that I felt early on is that something was lacking, the game seemed a little shallow, but I believe that was because I hadn't been introduced to the rest of the game's features.

Pros:
- Beautiful graphics
- Great performance
- Extremely varied gameplay
- Great learning/skill curve
- You can turn on/off sabotage and other features and pick an appropriate skill level very easily

Cons:
- A little hard to get up to speed on
- Several menus and UI elements are incomplete/hard to read
- Gameplay seems somewhat shallow at this point (as of 5hrs of gameplay ;)
- At $40 it is definitely overpriced, however I think $20 is reasonable

reviewText: This is an interesting economy tycoon game.  The first few games are tough but after a while you get the hang of it.   But, then after a while you see how basic the public stock ownership is, and the game starts to lose its sparkle.  Especially when you can lose the game so easily by it.  And, then you realize how unrealistic it is.  So, then you try to focus on building, and you start to realize the game is really kind of confining,  The maps are small even when you pick huge.  Then you find yourself competing for the same area with 4 or more competitors that in a very short time build up to the limits and try to take over you and each other.  That gets old quick because you want to build and develop Mars, not just fight in a little plot of land on it.  Finally, you say to yourself, well how is multiplayer.  If your lucky enough to find someone in the lobby and play, i imaging it could be fun.  I've been there 3 times and its been empty.  So, up front it looks fun and interesting, and it is for a while, but the replyabillity is limited.  I think it's overpriced for what you get.  Wait until it drops under $15.  Just my opinion.

CPU players are far too aggressive (Think Civ 5 Ghandi meets the Red Skull) and do not seem to compete with one another.  There is a bug currently in the game that allows CPU players to purchase stock in your company even when they do not have the funds to do so.  The game also, apparently, gives stipends of cash to the AI player, resulting in an early game juggernaut.  Every game is a zerg rush - there is no long term strategic play in this game whatsoever.

Sabottage corporations in particular are incredibly frustrating to play against and their playstyle is one dimensional: to deny others the ability to play.  This is not a very good design for an RTS game, as there is no effective counter to this playstyle that is accessible at all during the early game.

The CPU text-to-speech announcements get annoying very fast, especially the one voice that is barely understandable - I thought I had selected the wrong localization.

Overall, this is a great concept and the game could be fun, but for now the game is balanced such that it is just a mad rush with no real strategic depth or fun factor.  It needs more Sid Meier.

Could this game be worth the money?  Eventually, maybe.  It isn't right now.  Hold off on this one.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Read the game description and take them at their word. This game is not like Anno xxxx or Planetbase. This game plays like Starcraft or Command and Conquer. This is fast paced strategy, and when it comes right down to it, there's not much difference between matching your attack type to an enemy's defence type and sabotaging your enemy's chemical production right when you notice a lot of players building labs all at once. But the latter for me feels more grounded in plausibility and ends up more fun.

The only criticism I could have for an economic version of this type of rts gameplay is that when you are defeated, it is with an instant cash buyout. There are many interesting routes to that situation being possible, but when it happens there isn't much warning and then bam- you're out of the game. I don't even really mind that so much, though. When you're about to lose Starcraft you have to preside of the death of all your soldiers. This game rips the bandage off quickly, and your company becomes a subsidiary. I presume most of your workers even get to keep their jobs.

I play the crap out of the daily maps. I haven't won one yet. 9.6/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is very enjoyable to play. The graphics and animations of the buildings are really great, it has a good playability experience in general.

The game is exensive, as I don´t really feel there is that much to do just yet in Early Access, but having spoken to one of the developers it is obvious that they really care about the game, so I am looking forwards to see what they add to it in the future.

I found the game either very easy, or very slow on the extreme ends of the difficulty spectrum, so I would suggest you start off on a mid range setting. Also don´t expect the AI´s to all gang up on you, they work on an every man for himself basis,which is more realistic.

I would perhaps wait for the game to be on discount if you are tight on money, but if you are working and have cash go for it at full price.

The game is very accomplished graphically, and with some more voice over work in the future I feel the sound would be equally good.

I don´t like the tutorial system in the game, I find the teacher characters annoying, but then who really likes tutorials in any game anyway.

All in all I would give the game a 7 out of 10 in its current form, needing more content to make the game longer and bigger to score higher, but overall worth a look even if just for the cool animated buildings and atmosphere of the game.

For the developers, here is what I would hope to see with this game in the future:

- More buildings. It would be cool if you could have 12 or so more buildings. My recommendations would be: A Biodome (food), Shield Generator (black market defence, e.g. emp), Casino (pleasuredome clone), Landing Station (for importing materials or tourists), Gold/Diamond/Valuables mine (profit generation), variants of the existing buildings.

- Larger maps, I feel the current map, even the large one is too small.

- A sandbox mode without claims, where you can spread accross the map.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

4x strategy without combat and Stephen Hawking doing the voice-over!
Graphics serve their purpose, the interface is sharp and controls in general feel very polished. This looks and feels like Civilization 5. Just do yourself one favour: turn off both the music and the sound effects.
It's a business game that offers a lot of macro economic goodness. Supply and demand at its core, resource shortage, bottlenecks, dirty tactics.

This game offers the best a.i. I've ever seen and it's still far from finished. The a.i. doesn't cheat on low to medium difficulty settings and it still gives me a tough fight for my money.
I'll give you an example what the a.i. did to me:
I was totally reliant on my next two steel shipments. The a.i. evaluated my situation, hired pirates and intercepted those vital steel shipments. I went bankrupt because I was used to games offering poor a.i.. I was aware of the bottleneck in my supply chain. Hell, I'm even writing a paper on supply chain management RIGHT NOW! And the a.i. was set on the 3rd of 8 difficulty levels! This should have been a walk in the park.
Well, I learned from it. After 3 hours of playing I'm pistol-whipping this little ******. I own the a.i. (on level 3 of 8). Now it's time to be a man and face it at 50% of its might. :D

The price:
I got it on 50% summer sale. For 19 quid it offers fantastic value. I would go as high as 30. Wouldn't pay 40 though just yet. It's too steep for an early access game. Wait for a decent sale and get it if you enjoy economic games.

The con:
There's only one problem with the game and unfortunately it's a major one: the performance is sub par. The game is rather cpu-heavy. I got a decent system (i5-4660, gtx 960, 8 gb ram) which is way above min reqs. The cpu seems to be the bottleneck and it shouldn't be really. It's just a matter of poor programming (no multi-core support maybe?).

-----------------------------------------
Update: As of beta 4 the performance has improved significantly and is actually pretty good now.

Update: The game is in beta 5 by now. Many improvements again. Farther zoom level, balance, more campaign features etc.
Having played it for 45 hours now in total, I can easily recommend it. Still not burned out on it in any way.

rating: 9/10

A deceptively fast-paced economic, base-building strategy game with no military units.

Offworld plays very well in a FFA environment, and I enjoy 6- and 8-player games regularly. It keeps you on your toes as players react to changing prices, trying to make profits. You need to be constantly asking yourself, what resources are the other players neglecting?"

It can become quite frenzied in the end game as you buy up a couple other players and suddenly you need to manage ~60 structures

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I first saw this it looked promising, nice new RTS to play.

I've been playing it for awhile now and all I can think is how I got fooled into dropping 35 bucks for this. The balance is practically non-existent, the AI seems to make horrifyingly bad choices and at times it seems like the game is straight up cheating as ridiculous as that may sound. A particular example of this happened in one game when the bot, finding itself roughly $80,000 in debt, suddenly and inexplicably, had it's stock-price nearly quadruple while it's debt only increased.

It then proceeded to use it's newfound debt to buy me out in all of twenty seconds.

Deciding that perhaps operating so far in the red that you're in the black must be how you do things on Mars, I tried a similar strategy only to be met with the bot making the same miraculous turn-around only a few days in.

Setting aside the questionable balance for a moment, I'd also like to point out that the audio is almost impossible to understand at times. But I guess that's kind of a moot point considering the probables you're going to have to go through to play this miserable game.

All in all? Save your money for a better game. Wishing I'd stuck to the avoid early access at all costs" lesson I keep learning and ignoring..."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So my friends and I have  been waiting in anticipation for this game to launch for weeks now and so far, definetly not disapointed! While this game is pretty fun in single player it really shines in multiplayer. As someone who plays a lot of 4x and strategy games with friends, this game is a blast. It's something completely different which I'm always on the hunt for.

The game is you play a company on mars and you are trying to snag the resources you can and make money, all while buying out the other players. But it goes deeper than that. You only have so many claims for resources, and distance from your base makes a serious difference. Sabatoge adds a whole other layer to the game as well and is probably my favorite part! Nothing like completely shutting down another players supply chain and listening to them curse.

It still needs some balancing, for example, the off world trade center seems almost too powerful, and a save function and maybe a minimap would be nice.  But the game honestly feels finished and if someone didn't know it was EA, I don't think they'd guess.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an interesting game. The fact that it is non violent is a clear plus. The economic twist to it is a plus too. But considering its current state it is overpriced and the 10% discount is a joke. I would recomment buying at 15-20€ even for an early access (shouldn't early access games be cheaper than finished ones ?)

The main con I find to it that the graphics are really slow (or it requires a graphic card too powerful) especialy when one considers the quality of the graphics of the buildings.

Oh, sorry, the first con is actually the fact that you cannot scroll on the map and there is no minimap. You use the keyboard to move. Or maybe I missed something which could be included in the absent documentation.

The second/third con is the lack of diversity for the decor. The maps are diverse with regards to the resources, but the red mars tend to be a bit boring on the long run.

If you can overcome these issues, the game actually turns out to be... ok (I din't say great or anything similar). It really is about trading so you can afford to loose money on cheap resources that you don't produce as long as you earn more on expensive resources that you produce.

The number of tiles (aka buildings) that you can build is very limited so you should be careful about how you use them and how you place them. You can scrap a building to build another but only at the same place.

Finally, once you've built the offworld market you've more or less won. This is how I won the scientific scenario that some others claim to be unfeasible. By the way, I won all the tutorials without using the engineering. I still don't know what it does but it does not seem very useful so far.

One should also note that this a rather fast paced game especially at the beginning (or maybe it is just the game lagging that prevents you from playing fast enough).

I haven't done the multiplayer part yet. Hopefully, this will be intersting.

Early Access Review

I have never played anything like it before. Someone wrote, it compares best to the classic M.U.L.E.

The basic idea is, that you found a venture on mars to grab ressources, manufacture goods, and sell them for a profit.
There is a dynamic price mechanism based on supply and demand. This is nothing new. But it plays out in real time and feels like an RTS. (Sidenote: One of the designers mentioned Company of Heroes when talking about OTC! The game is totally different, but it feels" as action packed as CoH while being all about economics).

So you have to make decisions all the time - and since it is real time
date: there is a cost for not deciding: Do I claim a nice tile of land on mars to put a new factory there? Or do I make my existing stuff more efficient? Do I buy up someone elses stock? Or do I pay back my debt to prevent someone else from buying me out? Do I want to produce something that will guarantee small profits
recommended: or do I take a risk and switch to a potentially more profitable strategy? And .... WHO THE HELL has sabotaged my power supply again?!?\n\nThe content and scope of this game is limited

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a very fun multiplayer economic strategy game.  It feels like a spiritual successor to MULE, though with quite a bit of added complexity that I welcome; in MULE you had just three (technically four) resources:
- Food, which gives you time to work during your turn
- Energy, which is required to operate your MULEs so they can produce resources
- Smithore, which is required to build your MULEs in the first place
- There was also a fourth (rare) resource, Crystite, which was purely valuable as a commodity to sell when the price randomly fluctuated to a high level.

Despite being very simple system, the three main resources worked well together and a shrewd player could, at great risk to themselves, potentially corner the market in one resource and leave all the other players out to dry.  Offworld Trading Company allows similar risky maneuvers, such as cornering the silicon market and preventing other players from producing glass and electronics, or cornering the water market and preventing other players from producing food, fuel, and oxygen.  While MULE was a local multiplayer game (it was the 1980s, online wasn't a thing), Offworld Trading Company is online, which allows for large player counts and real-time play instead of turn-based.  There are a lot of other differences, many of them positive, a few of them negative.

There are still a few things I think need to be worked on; the ability to collude with other players to cooperate against another player by directly trading resources instead of putting them on the stock market would make a tremendous improvement and is one of the few vital game mechanics I really miss from MULE.  I'd suggest adding a new building which gives the ability for players to directly trade resources with each other with the caveat that like in the original MULE, the other players in the game should be made aware that these players are colluding.  It wouldn't necessarily say what specific transations took place, just that they made a transaction.  Transactions could range from a constant pooling of a certain resource or transferring resources in specific amounts, to temporarly lending ownership of a structure to another player.  Another thing I'd like to see is the ability to license patents to another player in exchange for a lump sum of money or a percentage of their profits.

reviewText:
It looks like an RTS but plays closer to a real-time version of a board game, specifically, a worker placement game. Whereas worker placement games tend to fall under the Eurogame umbrella (i.e. boring abstract pieces of uninteractive garbage) Offworld Trading Company thankfully doesn't fall into that trap.

You're on Mars to make mad dosh and prevent your fellow corporations from doing the same. The black market exists for you to fry their steel industry at key points with EMPs, to hire pirates to prey upon their shipping lines, and to cause energy blackouts.

Every decision has heavy weight, especially the decision to spend claims, which is the game's territory system. You can't endlessly expand your borders like Civilization. Every time you upgrade your HQ you gain 4-5 tiles' worth of claims which you can then spend to create facilities on land. The level of long-term strategy is high here because you can't refund those claims; the most you can do is destroy the building, which may not even help you if you need a building with a different resource.

I would recommend this to any strategy gamer who has grown bored of traditional manifestations of the genre. Don't forget to make lodse money! https://youtu.be/ON-7v4qnHP8
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've been playing this consistently since the day it went into EA, and can thoroughly recommend it.  It's not something you've ever played before, and it requries you put in some effort in order to get anything back (at the end of the day, this is a competitive game, so that's the way it goes).

But once it clicks and reveals its incredible depth, anyone with an interest in complex strategy games will be pulled straight in.

For those just starting out:  My advice to you is to begin by playing this as a pseudo-turnbased game vs AI.  There's just so much going on, if you try to play through in real-time you're going to be missing the intricacies and not learning how to play.

Once you're better, play in real time vs humans.  This game has more in common with Starcraft than anyone will tell you:  APM is hugely important, map awareness is hugely important, and adapting your strategy CONSTANTLY is hugely important.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In short:
A slightly weak 7/10 for now, but overall worth the money if you believe in future improvements (given the Early Access as well as overall game design).

--------

First off, this is NOT my kind of game. I'm the kind of player who prefers to spend time investing in one persistent game (as in Cities:Skylines, Dark Souls or an MMO), rather than a match-based game like this one.

That said and given the premise of the match RTS subgenre, I have to say it's a very refreshing IP. No combat whatsoever, but instead an all-out trading system where you manipulate the market and make sure you produce, buy and sell the right kinds of resources for maximum profit and the detriment of your opponents (who share your market).

As for resources, they do feel a bit few and slapped onto" the game. There's no explicit tree structure or overall design that makes me feel like I should care (possibly because of the said match-based gameplay

reviewText:
This is a great game. It is incredibly hard to figure out on your own so I highly recommend watching a Twitch tutorial. You also want to learn with the pause button (space bar) pretty much constantly on. Good players can crush it in a couple of minutes so consider yourself warned.

I love that every choice can hurt you or help you in a logical way. If you build a dozen farms it will drive up the price on water to keep them going. If you sell goods cheaply they only get cheaper, so it is time to make something else. If you can see the impact of your actions you can manipulate the market in cool ways (e.g. using a robotics company that requires no water to create a water shortage can cripple your fleshy foes).

The AI is pretty good and it rarely makes outright terrible errors. This means that even the tutorials can be punishingly hard if you are not paying attention. The music is beautiful and the tempo builds as the match progresses giving you a real rush at the end.

Play it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Offworld Trading Company is a great RTS economy game, where the challenge is to find/sell/make resources and out-buy your enemie by getting their stocks.

The game is hard, but the torturial gives a good understanding about what is moste important and gives the relevant information about Robotic HQ, Scientific HQ, Scavenger HQ, Expansive HQ and the black markedet etc.

The game offers a challenging gameplay with resources you can either invest in or sell, while you can manipulate the markedet or slow down your enemies. The gameplay is smooth and is a interesting game that makes you wonder why you are better than this than you'r own economy.

Overall graphics and interface gives a no-brainer overview of what you have to deal with, even you need to be fast looking for resoucres. The game can be fun to make your friends turn their brain around a couple times.

If you like economy games, where you have to invest, sell, take care of the black markedet and slowing down your enemie while thinking of OC2 and fuel for your transportation of resources cross the map, then this game is for you.

reviewText:
Offworld Trading Company is a fast speed game where every little action and timing counts and will decide if you get owned or not. The matches are quite short and adrenaline powered compared to Civilization.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ever since I was taken in by Race to Mars (you know what I'm talking about), I have been ultra-leary of Early Access Games.  I am glad that I broke my own rule and took the plunge with Offworld Trading Company.  For a game that isn't even touted as a Final Release version, it is amazingly well along.  I have played many games so far and have enjoyed them, even when I lost to the AI.  I have yet to try the multi-player, but this game has given me faith.

I tried to make a list of Pros & Cons but found it difficult.  The only Con I can really give this game is that it isn't done yet!  :P

Big thumbs up to the team behind this game.  I can't wait for the finished version and to the DLC I know is coming!  (hint hint, DLC in the future please!)

I would advise investing in this game despite the Early Access tag.  Even if they stopped right now, its still WAY better than Race to Mars ever will be I fear.

As a side note...I did wait until it was going for $20 USD instead of $40.

As another side note:  I read some of the negative reviews (about 10% of them) and found that alot of people complained about 'shallowness', the Black Market and the AI's tendency to pile up money and buy you out.  I was perplexed by all of that.

The supposed shallowness allows for games that don't take an entire day of my life while allowing for a pace that kept me busy until the end.  If I want on 'in-depth' experience, I'll play Civ or something like that.

The Black Market...nope, no problems with that either.  I like the fact that not only can I sabotage the competition, they can also do the same to me.  The costs increase not only when you use it, but when the AI uses it.  So if you can catch it, you can get an idea of the general plans of the competition.  Couple that with keeping an eye on Share Prices, it's not hard to figure out who just bought what.

And as for the AI buying you out...that's what it's supposed to do.  And if you have played correctly, you have made it hard for them to do so...which drives the tactic of storing up the $1 Million+ it will take.  The best business deals are the ones that surprise everyone else.  Why would that be any different here.

reviewText: Very interesting and unorthodox approach to RTS. Here it's not about tanks and planes, but cutthroat competition none less. reviewText:
I am absolutely horrible at this game. I don't think I've won anything outside of the tuturial missions, but while I don't play it much because of that, I can definitely recognise the amount of quality there is in this game.

OTC is a RTS game, but instead of combat being the focus, it's economics. There is no military in this game, the game is built entirely around buying, producing and selling resources in order to become the best trading company on Mars. The economics, from my understanding, is easy to learn, hard to master. Essentially buying increases value, and selling decreases value, so the main layer of strategy in this game is balancing income, making sure you're not in too much debt, and keeping the economy stable. There's also the more questionable side of business, involving buying extra land off the black market, sabotaging competitors, and hacking the market to directly increase or decrease the value of goods.

It's pretty hard, and I don't think I'll ever get how to play it well, but it's interesting and I would definitely recommend it to people who like RTS games, but want something with a unique twist.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Offworld Trading Company is an intense economic macro-oreiented RTS. But don't be fooled by the lack of military units, the game won't be easy. There's a lot to manage, other players to worry about and futures to predict (or create). Those of you who've played M.U.L.E. will find this extremely familiar, but in real-time rather than the turn-based style of the original.

The game itself is relatively simple to pick up, but there's a lot of depth and interacting complexity to master. You'll be deciding which resources to focus on, which buildings are cost inefficient, picking between the two research options, deciding whether to double short the or just to rush into Off World Markets, not to mention who to wreck with blackmarket tech and when.

Of course, it's not perfect being that it's in Early Access, the UI needs polish, and I find the game can be sluggish at times, especially in the end game (though, that's likely my fault for running it at 1440p), but overall the game is ridiculously fun, and the core mechanics are extremely solid, and the multiplayer community is really strong and friendly (though, they may still wreck you at first, no hard feelings, of course). Absolutely worth picking up.

Ok,  as a disclaimer strategy games of any variety  I typically enjoy in some ways; that said I'm really fond of the angle they've taken here but... I'm not sure its remotely worth 40$. In todays day and age I understand inflation and general quality of life insists we pay more for our games but I simply don't understand why we pay 40$ for what should be, in its current state, a 20$ game.  I am all for early access even being burnt by df9 like others, I'm very inpatient but why not pay 20$ to have access to the alpha and a buy in of 10$ for the full game when your done and 35 for the person who didn't try it before release? games like planetary anhilation that set that alpha price to rediculous ammounts really dont want your feedback just your money.

-rant over-

The gameplay at this point is really unique , I liked it alot. I, like always, jumped right into the game campaign without doing the tutorial and got obliterated. repeatedly, something about the reasource grab in the begining can be very unforgiving. its definately more of an rts than those turnbased lovers of civ. That said I'd like to point out all 'popular' rts's tend to have a decent chunk of campaign to play through. I lowered the difficulty after a few losses and found myself beating it too easily but I was really intrigued by the sofar bare bone campaign so I figured I'd see what it was all about. Much to my disappointment that was it. after a few missions with no real plot or explanation of your conquests on mars you easily finish the campaign ina couple hours... praise the lord they arnt done developing. after a few missions you generaly get the idea of how to take the reigns, you quickly learn all the buildings and how to place them well; there doesnt seem to be quiet enough... even with 16 resources or w.e there was specialization was never really an option even on rare resource missions supply always exceeded demand  far to easily and demand never rose fast enough... I think there are some resource balancing tweeks to be done and alot to desire game wise but in its current state its VERY playable with only a few little bugs.


I want more; I will be watching this one.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OTC is a unique economic RTS made by one of the main AI developers for Civ 4 & Civ 3.

Each player strategically manages one of eight corporations competing to dominate a local Martian colony market while also trying to buy-out each other's stock, Danny DeVito style. Matches last about 20-30 mins.

You make money by selling resources on the free market. Prices adjust in real time as you and other players trade; supply and demand. You can mine raw resources and sell them, or refine them into other resources and sell those, or consume them with factories to produce high value goods to sell.

You have limited land claims so expansion is finite and ends in the late game phase, forcing you to begin trying to maximize profits and/or restructure. You will also give/take sabotage and market manipulation.

reviewText: A fast paced and at times even overwhelming economical RTS.  A normal games takes only 20-30 minutes and things tend to escalate quickly. Rarely do you just dominate the whole game, if you do then it's time to up the difficulty or find another group to play with. The coop and campaign are both fun and offer different takes on how to play.  If you enjoy RTS and don't mind not being able to zerg attack your opponent with an army of soldiers but enjoy using a planned and precise economical attack or long term choke hold on the market for a thrilling buyout win then this the game for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even in alpha, this game is already excellent and challenging. Plus, there's so much more the develpers (and modders) could do with it.

It has that rush RTS feel the entire game, with a great blend of strategy (choosing which resources to focus on, which research to do, which kind of ecomony to focus on, considering which faction you are) and tactics (black market sabotage, market manipulations, and selling/buying strategies). It may not look like it from the screenshots, but you feel like you're in constant combat with your opponents.

Economic and market considtions are constantly changing based on the given map's resources and player/AI behavior; however, it doesn't change so fast that you can't find trends and predict how resource demand will change and make decisive, bold moves to crush opponents.

I see a near-limitless potential for deep strategy, counter-strategy and evolving meta-strategies for this game. Extremely excited to see where this game goes!
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'd say this game is quite good. So far as I can see from the negative reviews, they're mostly there because they expected a long strategy game like Civ, which it is not. This is quite a fast game comparitively and it notes in the trailer that most games are expected to be 30 minutes.
I have mixed thoughts on the AI, as sometimes they make very stupid decisions, but to be fair most of the time they get it right. A lot of people are complaining that they quickly get bought out by the AI, but this is merely a strategy that is available in the game due to it's fast pace, and if you cannot deal with it then you should not be playing 30-40 minute RTS games, but rather something like Civ (Which is personally one of my favorite game series).
The tutorials in this game are quite lacking, and they are basically just throwing you into the deep end, so some people may find it hard to pick up. Overall, I'd say that before you buy this game, realise it is fast and you can't get comfortable before you start taking action against other players.

It's an RTS like Warcraft or Dune was, not a 4x like Civilization.  (This was a surprise, but I like it for what it is.)

Debt is a meaningless red number.  Maybe it figures into your stock price?  Perhaps this shouldn't be listed as a Con, I just don't understand it yet.

Long story short, I don't think that this game is worth $40 at the moment. Hey, early access games aren't normally good anyway- with the exception of Starbound -but my advice to anyone thinking about buying, wait a bit.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not sure why I bought this.

So you know how some RTS games with an economy focus let you sell off spare resources to get other stuff you need? It's basically that game, except you win by selling enough resources to buy out your opponents. There isn't any reason to build an economy beyond that goal. As a free-market capitalism tutorial I guess it's educational, but it probably would have made a better board game than a videogame.

As for the state of the alpha right now, balance is pretty wonky, such as lower-valued companies can easily and unpreventably buy out more valuable competitors off the back of a single off-world shipment plus a little commodity selling, and the framerate is both unlocked and badly optimized enough that my computer tries to melt a hole in the floor just on the main menu.

The game has ran stably for me but I don't know how they're going to bulk out the gameplay to make this an interesting thing to play. It is tuned so the commodity production and everything else can be done very quickly, so twitch plays a factor and you can't play this with anything but undivided attention, which is unfortunate since I find it quite boring. If it were slower paced and less hectic I could at least listen to a podcast or something while I played.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

3 hours of gameplay so far.

There is a lot of potential here.  I will warn that this game (as of 2/16/2015) is obviously in the very early stages of production.  The most obviously undeveloped part to me is that the tutorials are either buggy or not yet created, so the learning is mostly self-tought it seems like.  I anticipate these components will be added in due time.

For the first week on early access, this game is in really great condition.  It reminds me very much of the board game, Power Grid, where the prices of commodities are determined by in-game supply and demand.

If you are waiting around for a strong economy-based RTS, this game is worth taking a serious look at.

I look forward to future developments.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

THIS IS A GREAT BETA AND HAS LOTS OF PROMISE

Just the game I have been looking for! An RTS focusing on economic strategy instead of military strategy. The game is fun in single player, but really shines in multiplayer. If you have a few friends to play with, it can be a lot of fun. The quick pace of games is daunting at first, but once you learn the mechanics, things seem more manageable. One of my favorite things is the ability to jump into a game with friends and it only takes 30 minutes or less to finish up a match. As far as betas go, this is a pretty well developed game. Bugs seem minimal so far (though I have had some friends have more issues on Mac platforms). All around, it is a fun, quick game. The random maps and many different play styles provide a pretty good replay ability. I look forward to seeing how the game is developed from here.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OTC is an interesting concept. Right now I do find it enjoyable and I look forward to the addition of leagues and ladders.

Gameplay is already quite polished and it looks nice. It's an interesting take on the RTS genre and I would love to see more games like this.

If I could select one change off the bat, it would be more market information and more dynamic markets. Right now the only truly dynamic resources is energy. Global prices are, it seems, driven by either player stockpile purchases or running deficits, which someone else could capitalize on. I'd like to see the markets function by net contribution and less stockpile driven, so rather than attempting to accumulate valuable goods and selling them off in bulk to buyout opponents have running market contribution. There seems to be a bit too much random invisible supply and demand we dont know" driving market function. Giving us some idea of ambient demand and supply balance or even "global stockpile" that determines pricing would be nice
date: and then introducing exogenous price shocks to randomly shift market prices would be cool too. Something to give the pricing a bit more depth.\n\nSimilarly
recommended: the share ownership function could also gain more depth
hoursPlayed: giving extra utility to ownership would be quite interesting. Defensive ownership blocks provide no real benefit if you're behind
voteText:
and spending that cash on buying yourself only means you can't spend it on further expansion which I could see leading to increasingly snowbally gameplay. It seems like it would always be better to build ownership blocks in other companies.

Finally adding more depth to the debt system would be quite cool. Right now debt seems like it works primarily as a death spiral - if you don't get your basic resources up and running you just enter a fixed debt growth and unless market prices (which we dont know enough about) swing your way you won't be able to get yourself out of it. Allowing players to manually take on debt in order to boost their economy would be a nice idea.

None-the-less its an interesting and enjoyable game on to play on early access release which is a rare find
helpfulPercent: and with additional work it could become a genuinely deep and interesting competitive game."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's important to say when playing this game that we are talking the earliest days of early access so much isn't polished and there are a lot of niggles to iron out.

But... this a truly original game with a lot of potential. Soren Johnsen is a great game designer and this could be a major new gameplay franchise. It has loads of potential to develop into a really great multiplayer experience for those of us who want deep and interesting strategy but only have an hour to play a game.

If you loved the early iterations of Railroad Tycoon and want a much more brutal and competitive version of the Anno series then this is right up your street. This game has the real potential to be next on the list of great Early Access games following from Kerbal and Prison Architect.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game i think has a lot of potential. that being said i think there are some issues that need some work.

the concept that your whole company can just be bought out by one person regardless of who actually owns the shares is just annoying. even if you own shares it won't matter. not exactly how shares of a real company work. so i would like to see that structured/ geared a little more realistically. basically as soon as someone gets the launch pad the game is over. that person instantly makes all the money they need and can just buy out all other companies.

next the buildings and utilites that you plop down to give you resources can't be upgraded or anything. i'm guessing that's just an early access issue, so i hope that doesn't stay that way.

all in all i think this game has some great potential, but i don't think it's worth it's current price at all. should be more like 10$ until it's been polished a bit. keep it on your watch list though.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSo, you came here most likely wondering: Should i buy this early access game? Is worth it?" Well
date: the short answer to this is: "YES". I'll review some of the game features here and
hoursPlayed:
there is a tl;dr section at the end.

What's the game?

You're in charge of a trading colony on Mars and you compete with other companies to gain monopoly on the planet. It fits really nice with all the talks going on about an actual manned expedition to Mars.

How to win?

You have to buy stocks of the other players and gain control of their company. You win the game when you have bought all the other companies. If your own company gets bought
voteText:
you instantly loose the game.

What's the gameplay?

You start off with a little cash and ressources (or none
helpfulPercent: there are options to set it before starting a game). You'll then have to build some buildings (like a mine or a steel mill) to harvest some ressources
votesHelpful: be it iron or steel
votesTotal: etc. You can then transform these ressources into building materials or goods which you use or sell on a global market. All the players affect that market; if someone sells a lot of a product
votesFunny: its price is going to go down and
commentsCount: on the contrary
column16: if someone buys a lot of a ressource
column17: its price is going up for everybody.\n\nWith the money and the ressources
column18: you can expand your colony
column19: buy some stocks or use the black market (i'll get back to it later). In order to build more
column20: you'll need to spend some claims. Claims that allow you
column21: and only you
column22: to use a tile in the game. So
column23: especially at the beggining of a game
column24: the fastest to find and lay claims on ressources is most likely to have the better spots. Those claims are obtained by expending your HQ or bought on the black market. So
column25: the twist of the game is
column26: you'll be struggling with few claims and you'll have to prioritise what building you need. Are you going to try and be self-sufficient? Or maybe invest in a pricey ressource gathering infrastructure? That's the kind of questions you'll be dealing with most of the game.\n\nYou HQ and your ressource transforming building will need some base ressources that you can mine yourself
column27: or buy on the market (thus making it pricier). When you're lacking a ressource it increases your debt
column28: which affect the value of your stocks. If your stocks are cheap
column29:
it's easier for other players to buy and you might loose the game. So watch that debt carefully.

Is that it? A ressource harvesting/transforming game?

Mostly
column30: yes. There are some researches and upgrading you can do in the game
column31:
but you'll spend those hard-earned claims mostly on harvest/producing more.

What's the blackmarket?

You can't directly attack other players
column32: at least in a classic RTS way. There are no soldiers and you can't steal a nice spot claimed
column33: but you can affect their production with the help of some saboteurs available on the blackmarket. For some money
column34: you can dynamite one of their building or launch an EMP that will freeze their buildings for sometime. Of course
column35: you can also be the target of such attacks and
column36: if you're not defended (with goons also from the blackmarket)
column37: you won't know who hit you.\n\nOf course
column38: as it is the goal of the game
column39:
you can buy other players stocks and then win the game.

Is it a good early access?

Yes. I haven't add issues with the game crashing. It's working really well on my end and all the features are there. Of course
column40: some elements are still to be updated. As an exemple
column41: there are no dedicated servers provided for multiplayer games
column42: making the game quit if the host leaves the game. Like in the good old days.\n\nBut
column44:
everything is there and you'll be able to enjoy all the mechanics.

Any other notable feautres?

A few. This game has a lot replayability
column45: every map is random generated so no game is going to be like the previous one. A complete game lasts around 30-45 minutes
column46:
providing that you're the winner. A few options available before starting the game like a tighter debt or masquerade can add a little something to a game.


There must be some downsides
column48: but I would insist that they do not compromise the quality of the game mechanics. Except for the dedicated servers I spoke about earlier
column49: the voiceover is actually horrible. You can't understand half and there is no clear logic in them (like

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Offworld Trading Company is exactly the kind of game I want to see more of. It reminds me a bit of a resource based board game (Power Grid, etc.) but done in real time. A really nice blend of chin stroking strategy and frantic moment to moment tactics, all without guns and combat! There is dynamite though..

There are some problems. The biggest issue by far is the abruptness that games end, at least in the default game mode. It's very possible to be humming along, building your successful empire, and then all of the sudden an opponent completely buys you out and bam, you lose. Uhh, ok.. gg?

This comes down partially to the stock purchasing mechanic and partially to the UI being somewhat rudimentary. If the fact an opponent was about to buy you out was somehow *much* more visible maybe everything would be fine. As it stands there is no late game tension unless you know where to look for it. Compare this to combat based RTS games where its obvious your base is under attack and you are about to lose.

This game /is/ in early access so I do have hope that the above problem can be addressed in some fashion. Until then, you do get used to if after a while.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been a RTS fan since the first warcraft game. Generally I favor the more military focused games like warcraft, starcraft, red alert, age of empires; so I was a little wary of giving this game a try. So glad I did.

I really enjoy the pacing of this game. Yes, it can move quickly, but for the most part it doesn't require the twitch reflexes that starcraft 2 and other modern RTS games demand. For those who say this game is too shallow, I couldn't disagree any more. Yes, it's true there are less building options and tech trees to work with, but Offworld has more than enough to keep the game engaging. When dealing  with an ever-changing economy you don't need tiers of tech to have content that is hard to master.

Mastery in this game is learning to predict your opponents' market schemes, adapting to the chaning economy, and knowing when to take risks in certain investments such as a new patent, claim or black market. While predicting, adapting and risk taking aren't new skills to the RTS genre, having to master them in a passive setting rather than an active go-attack-em setting makes for some new challenges that I've really enjoyed trying to learn.

More Thoughts:

It is true the tutorial could be a little more thorough, but after a couple of hours, you should be able to figure out the gist.

This is just me, but I think the Black Market takes the fun out of the game. I'm sure with more experience I could make better use of the black market, but for now the cost/benefit ratio doesn't seem to justify any purchase except for the new claims.  My biggest beef with the black market is that it takes away from the game's best feature, a rts focused primarily on economy. With the black market enabled it can get really annoying when your production is stopped, especially because it doesn't really hurt you, it just slows the game down. Thankfully there is an option to disable the black market, which i've found myself doing on every game now.

8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In this game you are the CEO of a company that is trying to establish a foothold on Mars. You balance managing resources and growing your company with nuking your opponents mines, tampering with their water supply, and buying shares in their company with the ultimate goal of acquiring all of your competitors businesses. You buy and sell resources on the open market, and the price of goods is reflected by the supply from you and your competitors, their demand, the distribution of resources on the map, and the demands of the Martian colony.

It's a very tense economic RTS" from the designer of Civ IV. This is an RTS more about timings

Music:

Replayability
Great replayability, until now I played more or less only with one faction or cooporation type out of four just to get used to one playstyle and discover different strategies about it. So there is so much more to discover with the other three coorporation and I've already over 20 hours on my steam clock on playing.

Frustration:
On of the games where you even after loosing had a lot of fun instead of being frustrated. I tried the multiplayer not once as I had enough fun with the single player campaign, so there is much more to find out with MP.

Time friendly:
Was really worth the money and is one of the games that you come back and play once in a while without need of playing it hour for hours each day.
One match goes around 20-40min which is very nice. Playable for years.

The different colony types add many layers of strategy and allow you to counter or adapt to what your opponents choose.

reviewText:
Offworld Trading Company is an economic warfare based real time strategy game. That makes it quite an interesting take on the RTS genre.

How does the 'warfare' work? Well, you and your competitors mine raw materials and produce goods - and sell it on the shared market. And if someone else has a building you don't want them to have, it may accidentally explode.. or you 'borrow' it for some time to win the race to one of the juicy patents (buffs only one player can have). In the end, you want to make money more quickly than the other people (and avoid debt!), in order to buyout their companies. And .. sometimes you may have to manipulate the market prices a tiny bit..

So how does the strategy layer of OTC look it? Well, one important aspect is that space is limited. Every time you upgrade your HQ, you can claim some more (4-5) tiles on the map. These normally are tiles either next to your HQ or tiles with resources on it.

Since (good) resources tiles are limited, you can create the situation where you nearly have a monopoly on a raw resource. And if everyone has to buy from you (via the market), you can make quite a profit by actively generating this situation. Doing so is tricky though, since at the start of the match, the map is covered with fog of war - and only when your HQ position is selected, the whole map is revealed. Might turn out that whole map is covered with silicon.. but there barely is any carbon! Time to change long term plans!

Once you own a tile, its yours for the rest of the match. This is where good positioning and foresight comes into play, because whatever buildings you are going to use, those have to be on these limited tiles. Got those now-useless mines on the other end of the map? Well, just put factories there instead. However, transporting goods costs fuel, which requires water to make, which drives up prices and reduces profit.

All producing buildings get adjacency bonuses (each +50% for 2 buildings, +75% for 3). So your first idea might be well
date: get some mines in the middle of nowhere and a big cluster of tiles at my HQ to maximize adjacency". However
recommended: this leaves your production very vulnerable to area of effect sabotage by that dude that doesn't like you. Ouch.\n\nThe market prices rise and drop depending on what all players do. This requires you to switch up production on the fly. You produced food? Well

reviewText: Biggest surprise of the year so far. It is *almost* relaxing yet at the same time very tense when the market heats up! The soundtrack is fantastic. The tutorials are some of the best I have ever seen. It really isn't a spreadsheet, the game has character, and scrounging Mars for hot spots is fun. It is very satisfying to build a nice economic engine and there is just enough spite between players that you can't just do your own thing and ignore the other competitors... unless you build a real powerhouse that you can shrug off mutinies, saboatge.. erm.. incidents I mean, etc.  Nicely done, Mohawk. Who could have thought buying and selling could be so fun (capitalists all over the world scream in extasy).

reviewText: Fun strategy game - you can play clean or dirty if you choose.  I am a big fan of the old game MULE from Ozark Sofware.  This game is not really like it, but you can see the inspiration.  (Not too mention - I bought a MULE from the black market and saw a reference to Dr. Bunten in the game - nice!)\nThere is a market for goods, a black market, and different playable factions with different bonuses (and negatives I suppose).  The commodity market is fun - my favorite was when the computer hacked a water shortage when I had a huge surplus.  Oops :)\nIf you like strategy games, give it a try.  The games seem to last about 30-45 minutes each.  I have only played the computer opponent.  I will work my way up to humans (and probably get destroyed).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OTC is in the place you would expect and Early Access game to be. The core gameplay cycle is in great shape, and it really is just the outside edges that need to be fleshed out to complete the experience.  When I first heard of the concept I wasn't sure that the gameplay would standup over time, but so far the single player experience has been very good through multiple campaigns. Even when I lose I want to get right back in and try a new strategy. The AI is solid, so even on the lower difficulty levels it doesn't feel easy.

I still need to play the multiplayer, but as a single player experience I'd highly recommned it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is really fun game, but it has one very serious flaw.  You can suddenly, and randomly lose the game, and there is no foolproof way to prevent it, nor a warning that it will happen, and once you have lost, you half to start over -- there is no save.  This anti-feature completely saps my enjoyment of the game because its no fun to suddenly lose as your are building your empire and waiting for your plans to come to fruition.

If the developer really wants this anti-feature in the game, he should provide a way to disable it when you set up the scenario; that way I can play in peace!

Early Access Review

The game's somewhat shallow so far in depth of play.  When you play its pretty much a race to accumulate about 100k in money first and from there its a race to buy-up your competitors stock and then its game over. The AI in the game seems to be overcooked in that it accumulates weatlh freakishly fast.

The multiplayer version of the game is quite laggy sadly.

Look the game has enormous amount of potential if it gets finished. The game devs are onto something that could be a massive hit if they carefuly focus on the game mechanics, specifically adding layers of depth to various routes you can play (think paper, scissors & rock).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access - Buy only if you want to contribute to the developers through playtesting and feedback, or simply just to support them
Full Game - Worth a shot at this price range if you like a fresh take on real time strategy sims - provided it is polished up, of course.

The main problems at this time of writing (Feb 2015) are listed below:
1) AI is extremely aggressive even on Intern and Assistant level.
2) Stock valuations for AI companies are skewed too high (perhaps due to AI aggressiveness?)
3) AI has a real tendency to buy your company shares once you're doing fine and having low debt-equity ratio, yet your company's share price doesn't go up by much?
4) The AI also likes to bid aggressively on the auction house, and takes good plots of land before you are fast enough to react!
5) Hex coverage for pirates does not make sense if the transport system makes no sense - for example, if the freighters travel in one straight line to HQ, and the HQ occupies larger than one tile, the effectiveness of using the pirates ability is rather muted.

Things that I would like to see
1) Adjustable game speed and better notifications/audio feedback on events (I mean, come on, the sound of a can being trashed is the sound for a resource surplus?)
2) Ability to unclaim" a hex"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Frankly, a really disappointing game (and this is the BETA, not the ALPHA stage of developing...).
Also, is REALLY overpriced, for what it give.

It's not a simulation game and it's too poor (simple game mechanics and a small quantity of contents) to be a good strategy game.

The graphics compartment is still nice, however.
And also could be funny to play on multyplayer.
But this is also the main problem with this game!

It's way too simple, and overpriced, to be worth of buying only for the single player, also at 50% of the current price! (as today 12 €).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a fan of RTS game, Offworld Trading Company has definitely been a refresher for me. It feels very different from the conventional RTS (examples: StarCraft, CnC), but it still plays very solidly as a game in the genre. While it may feel bland at first to know that there is no martial combat aspect in the game, it compensates for that empty space very quickly by bringing pressures in macro decisions.

As the name of the game suggests, this game puts you in the position of a decision maker for a trading company on Mars, with range of actions from claiming different plots of land on Mars and trading the goods, to tampering the markets to your advantage (or your opponent's disadvantage). Your goal is to buy out all of your opponents and become the monopoly on Mars's resources.

The game is fully focused on macromanagement, which may make the game feel a bit slow. However, that does not mean that it is not exciting. Game gives you a lot of options with very limited number that you can actually choose, so you have to really plan a bit ahead on how you are going to work things out. As time progresses, your choices grow, but you will see that you will constantly be hassled by your opponents and may start facing the danger of being bought out. Your only friends will be your wits and your guts, as you make your own moves to press down your opponents and take control of what they own once and for all.

While the game is enjoyable in many aspect, I feel that the snowballing effect may become an issue as people become more familiar to the game mechanics. I guess that will be another thing that will be countered, either by evolution of player strategy or developer intervention. I am just bringing out the possibility.

Overall, I would give this game a 9.5/10. Half point off for not enough music. =D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is another one of those games where they took the basic RTS idea and tried to change it enough to make it fresh and interesting. Shockingly, they pulled it off.

This is an economic RTS, which means no direct combat. You win by buying all the stocks of your opponents. Don't think this means no conflict. The games sabotage system is rather brutal and you will have ample opportunity to harass your opponents as well as get bent over by the AI.

This brings us to the computer controlled players. They will completely kick your ♥♥♥ on higher difficulties. According to the developers, the AI does not cheat, they are just that good. Although this might sound like a bad point it is in fact a positive. You can lower your handicap enough that you can learn to play without getting insta-killed to learn and then ramp up the difficulty later.

There are a wide variety of resources to collect and even more production items you can make with those resources. Many of them are required to progress and anything you do not make yourself must be purchased. Although there is a limitless supply of resources to purchase, the more an item is bought the higher the price becomes. Likewise the more you sell resources the cheaper they become. It is a constant balancing act that becomes quite enjoyable.

Multiplayer is fantastic. You can easily partner with a buddy and share resources. This means you can each focus on specific raw resources and manufacturing. When you build two of the same types of buildings next to each other, they gain an adjacency bonus of 50%. With three touching the adjacency bonus is 75%. This means that building two of the same building next to each other does not double production, it triples it. This is a huge advantage in co-op play.

At this time the game is listed as early access. I would disagree and say it is release quality. We have played probably 50 games with no glitches ot crashes of any kind. The game is solid, balanced, challenging and fun. Completely worth a buy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you believe appearance doesn't make a difference, then it doesn't.  But if you do, it does.  I really, really wanted to like this game for its appearance.

I think OTC has most of the strenghs of the Civ series with more replayability, due in large part to real-time pacing.  Beginners fear not!  The single-player version defaults with a pause button and save-or-bail options!  Advanced players fear much!  Multi-player doesn't!  But I digress.  Real time pacing enhances replayability by deemphasizing the start and playing a perfect strategy, and emphasizing making the fewest mistakes.  And who doesn't want to make fewer mistakes the next time.

I wanted to like OTC.  I liked it.  Still do.  Got some hours under my belt and still nowhere near ready for prime time.  Still single-player, pausing and saving, and trying something new.  I really, really like this game.


//  A Robot Colony  //////////////////

Figuring out the Robotic Colony first really worked for me.  Given lots of resources and Employee difficulty, map options, I was able to get experience with interface, the upgrade options and sequence, and the financial system, and win consistently against the AI.  Always a good thing.  The financial system is the key to winning the game.  The AI is pretty good at finding local optima, better than I am anyway.  I'm better at global optima and was glad of the head start Employee difficulty gave.  And lots of resources ment the build script for my Robotic Colony was relatively simple so I could concentrate on the financial system.  And finding a nice big fat organic colony to buy out, er, ally with.  (Look, I know we don't have a lot in common, but . . .  What, that gyser of molten high-test steel behind me?  We meteored into a huge pile of iron ore.  By design.  3% over expectations, actually.  So, I can crank out launchers like Detroit does cars and you can crank out organic export products like a Kansas farmer.  As long as you aren't against me, we _will_ win.  :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Got it for £15. It's fun, and I think that's a fair price. Still getting to grips with the game, but first impressions are good. Graphics are neat, it has original economic gameplay, and the content is quite streamlined. I don't think there's enough to justify much more than £15 cost though. The game is enough for quickfire competitive games to kill time, but completely lacks the depth and complexity of many games out there with a £30-40 price tag.

Multiplayer is the biggest problem it seems. I've found it very hard to find other players to play with. Like many others have said, worth a buy, but only on sale.

Edit: When matchmaking, sometimes the game gets stuck in a perpetual matchmaking state, with all buttons greyed out and unable to go back to the main menu. Requires a restart. This happens even if it says there are other players available. Would be great to have an update for that.

reviewText: I wanted to like this game.  It's very easy to learn and four different factions that each play differently is a nice idea for an economy game.  The problem is that it's just not fun.  You can max out all your buildings in about ten minutes and after that it's a game of fine tuning what you are producing and manipulating the market to drive prices up.  It's almost impossible to lose money so there's never any worry about that.  The only real point is to make money faster then your competitors so you can buy them out.  Offworld Trading Company is a good idea that just didn't work out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've always enjoyed the economic side of Real Time Strategy games. Offworld Trading Company scratches my itch, gets me addicted, and then all of a sudden it's 1am and I have work in the morning.

THE GOOD
This is very polished for an early access game. Very polished.
Games last between 30-45 minutes, which is perfect.
The UI is very intuitive and I was able to figure it out quickly.
A game with market, economic, and game theory. Yum.
Frequent updates from the devs.
THE BAD
There are still a couple of bugs and balancing issues floating around. The devs are tackling these through the aforementioned frequent updates so it's really not a dealbreaker. And, after all, it IS early access.
The AI can be very frustrating sometimes, buying you out in the space of 20 seconds and leaving you scratching your head as to where you went wrong. As with the previous point, this is something that the devs are aware of and they've already taken steps to resolve the problem.
THE UGLY
This list is empty, because the game really is very pretty.
Would wholeheartedly recommend. In fact, I've already bought this game as a gift for someone else!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I reccommend the game with the following caveats:
- The price is high for an early access game (I paid $44 because of the weak Canadian dollar)
- The gameplay is stripped down to include only economic forces. This is not Civilization or Anno 2070.
- The tutorials are weak, with merely a popup explaining each faction at the start of each game.
- I have not completed the campaign, so no comment there yet.
- The interface is currently dominated by a lot of fast-changing numbers. You will spend more time looking at the numbers than you will at the playing field
- The useful charts (stock price over time, resource price over time) are hidden in another menu that you have to switch out of the game view to get to.
- Learderboards and leagues are not implemented yet
- The game menus and buttons are not totally polished yet
- Fonts were sometimes difficult to read on my laptop screen (1366x780)
- Games tend to be one-sided as soon as a player begins to dominate. Last minute upsets are possible, but require skill and timing.
-Late-game becomes entirely unnecessary once you get the hang of the mechanics (after playing a few skirmishes), this game desperately needs balancing.

The overall game is very fun and fast-paced, much like Monopoly. This game essentially purifies the economic victory modes (domination) common to other RTSs, elevating resource gethering and market tactics to its own strategy genre.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a true strategy game, where macros and preplaning make little difference. Quick thinking and good knowledge of what is effecting the prices are the keys to winning each round.
You can produce aluminium and steel to upgrade for free or take advantage of cheap prices from other players selling off their excesses, however you won't know which is the better move until the game has started and you see what resources are available.
Resources are on a first claim basis meaning that you can miss out quickly or shoot yourself in the foot by claiming them too early.

The only thing I hated was that you could be bought out too unexpectantly. If you have 5 shares in your own company you start to feel safe, however someone can buy you out all at once and you wouldn't see it coming.
This is already being addressed by means of a warning when an oponent is close to having the funds to finish you off however it's not implemented flawlessly at the time of my writing this.

It shows its signs of being an early access but for the most part playes like a full release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I waited for a good discount before I bought OTC. That's what the reading the market is all about, right? Now I'm a very satisfied customer. I like the idea of economic domination of Mars. Of course the big money comes from shipping resources  back to the earth. It took me many days to get into the league where the big boys are playing. Or maybe I'm not there yet, but I've certainly gained more insight in the past few days from playing and taking notes how the good players are playing.

Even though the game is still in beta, it feels like a finished product. Some people say that Mohawk hasn't added enough content, but I think that's what this game is all about. Finding the best stratety with the tools you've been given. And yeah, Soren Johnson, the brain behind this game was heavily involved with Civ IV, so you can't go wrong with getting this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is very challenging to play and currently has a pretty steep learning curve, but it is a really engaging experience. It is interesting how it deals with financial takeover of your opponents (through buying out their stock) as the win condition. I'm not sure I've played another game that used a mechanic quite like that. As I've learned how to play, I've slowly been increasing the AI difficulty and the game has remained fun and addicting. I haven't tried online multiplayer yet, but will probably play against some friends once I've got the strategies down a little better.

At the time of my review, the game was early access, and it feels like a finished experience. I'd say the most work could still be needed in the tutorials as they were not the most friendly to learn what to do. I had to checkout some developer video tutorials online to really get the hang of the later (and harder) tutorial levels.

I definitely recommend this game though if you are looking for an interesting twist on the old real time strategy / resource management game type. They are doing a lot of cool things with this!
