reviewText:
Early Access Review

Imagine an RTS game where you have to collect resources, but instead of creating troops, you manipulate the market (think stock market) to make a profit. You can try collecting a resource that you know several other people will need, or monopolizing a single resource so that you can raise or lower the price of it at will. The goal is to buy out the other companies, and the depth of gameplay is deceptively larger than you may imagine.

You build an HQ that has colonists that need to survive, and you must provide for them. They need food, water, and air, among other things. But there are 4 different types of HQ's, all with different benefits. For instance the Robotic HQ has robotic colonists, so they obviously don't need food, water, and air, but they do need electronics.

A typical game involves grabbing the best resource nodes that you can reach (before others take them), and then deciding your strategy. You could make some quick money to buy out another company before they can raise their stock price, or expand your development to all market resources so that you can capitalize on any high prices. Every game is different, and no one strategy will work every time.

Companies are not isolated from each other. You can hire hackers to artificially raise/lower any stock price temporarily, hire pirates to hijack shipments from your strongest competitor and bring them to you, or start building rockets to send shipments offworld if the prices for an item that you have a surplus of are not high enough.

It's easy to see why someone not interested in an Economic RTS would want to pass on this game. But if this type of game interests you, then this game is a must play. The AI is very tough, but fair. I can say with 100% confidence that the negative reviews on here about the game being bland" were people that didn't understand just how much depth there is to the gameplay. As a fully completed game
date: I would call this a "must buy"
hoursPlayed: this is a "no brainer"."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like Anno, Civ, Starcraft, and construction/citybuilding games, you will like this game. I've never played a more pure economic RTS, and it does its job exceedingly well. There is a small and manageable set of well-defined mechanics which can be combined in endless combinations.

It's hard though. You need to be able to predict the future, act on your predictions, and react to competitors at the same time. Try and corner the market. Watch what happens when you have the only good silicon resource and use the hacker array to drive up the price of glass. Suddenly everyone takes our your ability to make power and you go into huge debt. But now you can boost yourself up to the next HQ level and seize those last good carbon resources so you will have an advantage in electronics production and win the game.

Unless someone destroys the only good silicon mine on the map. Your entire strategy depends on that one tile. Better hire some goons to protect it.

Don't forget...

The AI won't.

Early Access Review

This game is fun, though very unstable at this point.  Good graphics, good models and sounds, really enjoyable gameplay, they just need a few more months of beta testing to make it stop frequently crashing.

column19: either by throwing one of a very small set of 'black market' attacks at them to disable buildings or resources
column20: or by manipulating the market somehow.  Cut off their oxygen supply; don't sell surplus power; sabotage their mines; flood the market with the commodity that they rely on as a cash source.  The supply chains are long enough that there's usually a weak point in everyone's

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay, my first experience of this game is very similar to board games like Settlers of Catan. I try to find nice places to harvest resources, I expand and try my best to gather the most points.
Unlike Settlers, there is more to this game that only resource gathering and expansion, aspects I haven't understood or learnt yet. So I lose...
But losing doesn't feel like failure, it feels like learning. And that I think is because of the game. It beats you but only to make you learn. Me, I like that.

It is a mechanical game, it's mostly about making the right decisions long term vs short term. When I link my only two sources of power I get bonuses but become vulnerable to sabotage. I gamble that I can make it. Afterwards, I get sabotaged and lose some time later, I'm bought out and lose. I play on employee" level (low difficulty) and still I get my ♥♥♥ wooped.

What I'm trying to say is that this is a challenging game with no easy path to victory
date: even on a low difficulty and after three playthroughs. Hopefully multiplayer will be equally enjoyable or more.\n\nSo far I'm very satisfied with my purchase! =)"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A little over priced for what you get, but overall very fun. Its an rts game with an economic focus. Unlike other rts games where destruction is the end goal, yours is to amass enough wealth to eventually buy out your foes.

First impressions: Its quite appealing to the eye, Its nothing incredibly realistic looking but it seems to work for it. Interface is brilliant, really. I was confused as to how to play the game for maybe the first play through, after that it seemed straight forward. The A.I. are competent and tricky at times which is nice considering the multiplayer is very buggy right now. As an economic focus rts, It seems a little silly that they enabled things like emp's and dynamite and such.

Final remarks: Its a good game, definately worth playing if you love economic domination games. however 43 seems a little out of the price range but if  you have the cash go for it, its fun.

Message to the developers: I take issue with the black market tactics. I mean, a lawsuit could easily just give the money back. What I'm trying to get at is that if you want to blow stuff up but want to collect tonnes of resources, Anno 2070 is a great place to go. This game seems more oriented towards production and cash flow but to attract a larger volume of players, such as those who prefer kick ♥♥♥ explosions, you added dynamitesabotage.

Corrective action on that issue is easy, either make it another rts game with armies, or you focus on actual economic strategies that take place in actuality. Lobbying, public affairs and propoganda, lawsuits, banning of certain things (types of mines or means of production) or both in game or enabling certain things within the game lobby (no army, no sabotage, no economic victory etc.) Besides the aformentioned issue, this game seems to be headed in a very interesting and refreshing direction, I eagerly await the new developments

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game! I managed to get 3 hrs of gameplay out of just the tutorials, without doing any multiplayer or campaign mode. So that to me is a great start. The graphics are pretty and the interface is really easy to use. For an Early Access game its suprisingly complete and polished.

Unfortunately I did encounter some graphical issues, but I feel that is more because my computer is at the low end of the (mac) system requirements, and not because of the game. The whole game just slowed to a lag fest by the end of tutorial 4 and 5 (so much is going on, onscreen), and the text was fairly unreadable in some areas from the start. Changing the settings didn't help much and made it worse at one point. So if you are reading this for opinions on tech specs, note that game is pretty resource intensive (pun not intended) so you might want to check your system requirements are closer to the recommended than the minimum.

That said, I still recommend the game! Its a great resource management game, and if you like that kind of game you will love this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A virtual economy where you create things; sell things; and buy out your competitors. So heres the crazy thing: Its shockingly complex

First; the AI.
the AI knows what its doing but it doesn't seem to want to over-saturate the economy as I'm so keen on doing.
Dunno if that was intentional but if you can make a product not at all worth the actual product; it makes it harder for them to earn the money needed to buy your stocks.

Second; the black market
It would be hilarious to blow up someone's mine on a skype call; but otherwise you can basically shake it off. They never really get you to a choking point. Pirates kept stealing really pathetic amounts of water from me, for example (about 30-50 water a minute or so) and it didn't even matter because my production supported beyond that. The worst ones are the magnet storm and emp. The rest (save for nukes which I always buy just to get it out of the game if its being auctioned) doesn't even matter. If you are producing and you're staying afloat; go ahead and laugh. Otherwise its a minor inconvenince.

Third; the economy itself
It's a simple Supply/Demand type thing and is constantly checking itself and I love that. Things feel as if they have value despite being totally meaningless just like in real life.

Forth; gameplay
The game is smoothish on my laptop and is graphically pleasing. Its in early access but that's not going to excuse anything. A mine looks a mine and a transport looks like a transport. Each faction looks very different from each other.

Fifth; the 'realisim'
Each faction has its own voice; but is as well quite robotic. Think Hal 9000 but just slightly less human sounding. Its a bit hard to put into words. the Robotic faction sounds like a male GPS voice, the scavenger faction sounds like a british robot, expansive sounds like a female GPS voice, and so on. Each mine reproduces whatever item its tile says and each tiles material stacks (0-3 but 0 is just a blank tile) and the amount of stuff that exists keeps it interesting

My biggest issue is the games one limiting factor; claim titles. all tiles on the game are fair game but you can only grab x amount of until you level up your hq (up to level 5 and that comes quickly; trust me) And, if you place something down by mistkae; and so you go to destroy whatever you placed on it; well you just wasted material. That tile is yours son. Congrats. Didn't need that carbon? Too bad.  The only way to get rid of a tile is to auction it and the game never actually tells you how to auction things. It just introduces it maybe 10 mins into one of the tutorial missions. Never tells you how; just lets you particpate.

My other issue is how the game handles debt. You got two big numbers; the current money you have, and a possible accurued debt. The idea, of course, is to not need to buy things, and if you need to, rather than subtracting it from your current cash; it just created debt that you can pay off whenever you feel like. While that's nice it doesn't feel like a negative. Its not pressing.

The game doesn't remind you of the hole you're digging for yourself; it just points it out with a red number and that's it. Each new day it'll go up by x percentage but what does it matter? The only real negative is you don't make any profits (all profits made through like, selling power is funneled to your debt rather than your cash pool) but you can still make money by selling materials; and you can then pay the debt back 1k per click.

But why when I don't feel the need to because nothing bad happens.

I don't feel punished by the growing red number and I feel that might be an issue.

7/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I enjoyed this game. The UI was a little puzzling at first, but eventually with the help of the tutorials I figured it out and went on to play campaign games. The game sessions themselves last 20-25 minutes, and 8 of them strung together make a campaign, so you can finish a campaign in a couple of hours.

If there's a downside to the game, it's that once you're done with Mars, you're done. The game model cries out for an asteroid campaign, a europa campaign, and so on. I also think a longer campaign model with more objectives would make good use of the persistant personnel you can buy in campaign mode and help you make a more custom faction.

I'd say this game is worth $10-15 US dollars.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A solid game that breaks away from the normal RTS collect 1-2 resources and then send your army over to the enemy to kill their workers because that hurts them the most.

In this game you're tasked with laying out a plan to develop your resources in a solid production line. Against the AI you don't have to deal with many hiccups, but unlike what the negative reviews have said about 0 depth, when you get in to multiplayer skirmishes you've now got to build efficiently, and take in to account what they might do to you.

For instance, there are 4 factions, each different than the other, if you can keep in mind the resources that each needs, you can punish your opponents my stealing them, or stealing their building, but this may leave you open to similar attacks. Then further from that you have to manage your debt, you might have a short term victory, but if they cripple you at the right time, they can send you spiraling in to debt which will stop you from further attacks or defense tactics.

So, to those who wrote 0 depth"
date:
try winning some multiplayer matches.

- One of the most intelligent queueing systems I've seen
recommended: you can practice against the AI while waiting for a 1v1 skirmish

- A unique (afaik) game style that focuses more on the resource management side of RTS rather than militaristic side.

The cons:
- Fewer than I'd like number of players online at any given time

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is great.

I'm not sure why people are hung up on the game being in Early Access/beta.  How polished the game is in beta has more to do with the company you're dealing with rather than a universally-accepted standard of development.  For example, Blizzard games in beta are already polished to the level of release.  EA, on the other hand, had no problem with Battlefield 4 being unplayable for several months after release; BF4 would crash constantly on both new and old computers alike.

Offworld Trading Company has all the graphics and core gameplay complete.  At the moment, the developers are finalizing the balance among the types of companies and completing alternative modes/winning conditions.  The only main feature that is missing is central hosting by dedicated servers, which is scheduled to be completed by release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I like this game and I think it uses a market system beautifully. However, I think allowing the player to set a starting price for their own sale of goods might lead to a more competitive edge in terms of pricing, because the value of goods are not worth exactly what the seller says they are, its up to the buyer. So in a way the market in the game is not a truly free market where the price mechanism reflects the condition of the market because often times you are encouraged to instead sell things that might lend a good profit instead of selling things that ARE returning a good profit. The price of a good refects the entirey of its condition meaning the availability of the materials and the ease of production, and of course, its demand.

Other than that minor thing I think the game is solid, however I dont think its worth $35.99. Maybe $29.99.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I waited for a good discount before I bought OTC. That's what the reading the market is all about, right? Now I'm a very satisfied customer. I like the idea of economic domination of Mars. Of course the big money comes from shipping resources  back to the earth. It took me many days to get into the league where the big boys are playing. Or maybe I'm not there yet, but I've certainly gained more insight in the past few days from playing and taking notes how the good players are playing.

Even though the game is still in beta, it feels like a finished product. Some people say that Mohawk hasn't added enough content, but I think that's what this game is all about. Finding the best stratety with the tools you've been given. And yeah, Soren Johnson, the brain behind this game was heavily involved with Civ IV, so you can't go wrong with getting this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is very challenging to play and currently has a pretty steep learning curve, but it is a really engaging experience. It is interesting how it deals with financial takeover of your opponents (through buying out their stock) as the win condition. I'm not sure I've played another game that used a mechanic quite like that. As I've learned how to play, I've slowly been increasing the AI difficulty and the game has remained fun and addicting. I haven't tried online multiplayer yet, but will probably play against some friends once I've got the strategies down a little better.

At the time of my review, the game was early access, and it feels like a finished experience. I'd say the most work could still be needed in the tutorials as they were not the most friendly to learn what to do. I had to checkout some developer video tutorials online to really get the hang of the later (and harder) tutorial levels.

I definitely recommend this game though if you are looking for an interesting twist on the old real time strategy / resource management game type. They are doing a lot of cool things with this!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A virtual economy where you create things; sell things; and buy out your competitors. So heres the crazy thing: Its shockingly complex

First; the AI.
the AI knows what its doing but it doesn't seem to want to over-saturate the economy as I'm so keen on doing.
Dunno if that was intentional but if you can make a product not at all worth the actual product; it makes it harder for them to earn the money needed to buy your stocks.

Second; the black market
It would be hilarious to blow up someone's mine on a skype call; but otherwise you can basically shake it off. They never really get you to a choking point. Pirates kept stealing really pathetic amounts of water from me, for example (about 30-50 water a minute or so) and it didn't even matter because my production supported beyond that. The worst ones are the magnet storm and emp. The rest (save for nukes which I always buy just to get it out of the game if its being auctioned) doesn't even matter. If you are producing and you're staying afloat; go ahead and laugh. Otherwise its a minor inconvenince.

Third; the economy itself
It's a simple Supply/Demand type thing and is constantly checking itself and I love that. Things feel as if they have value despite being totally meaningless just like in real life.

Forth; gameplay
The game is smoothish on my laptop and is graphically pleasing. Its in early access but that's not going to excuse anything. A mine looks a mine and a transport looks like a transport. Each faction looks very different from each other.

Fifth; the 'realisim'
Each faction has its own voice; but is as well quite robotic. Think Hal 9000 but just slightly less human sounding. Its a bit hard to put into words. the Robotic faction sounds like a male GPS voice, the scavenger faction sounds like a british robot, expansive sounds like a female GPS voice, and so on. Each mine reproduces whatever item its tile says and each tiles material stacks (0-3 but 0 is just a blank tile) and the amount of stuff that exists keeps it interesting

My biggest issue is the games one limiting factor; claim titles. all tiles on the game are fair game but you can only grab x amount of until you level up your hq (up to level 5 and that comes quickly; trust me) And, if you place something down by mistkae; and so you go to destroy whatever you placed on it; well you just wasted material. That tile is yours son. Congrats. Didn't need that carbon? Too bad.  The only way to get rid of a tile is to auction it and the game never actually tells you how to auction things. It just introduces it maybe 10 mins into one of the tutorial missions. Never tells you how; just lets you particpate.

My other issue is how the game handles debt. You got two big numbers; the current money you have, and a possible accurued debt. The idea, of course, is to not need to buy things, and if you need to, rather than subtracting it from your current cash; it just created debt that you can pay off whenever you feel like. While that's nice it doesn't feel like a negative. Its not pressing.

The game doesn't remind you of the hole you're digging for yourself; it just points it out with a red number and that's it. Each new day it'll go up by x percentage but what does it matter? The only real negative is you don't make any profits (all profits made through like, selling power is funneled to your debt rather than your cash pool) but you can still make money by selling materials; and you can then pay the debt back 1k per click.

But why when I don't feel the need to because nothing bad happens.

I don't feel punished by the growing red number and I feel that might be an issue.

7/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I enjoyed this game. The UI was a little puzzling at first, but eventually with the help of the tutorials I figured it out and went on to play campaign games. The game sessions themselves last 20-25 minutes, and 8 of them strung together make a campaign, so you can finish a campaign in a couple of hours.

If there's a downside to the game, it's that once you're done with Mars, you're done. The game model cries out for an asteroid campaign, a europa campaign, and so on. I also think a longer campaign model with more objectives would make good use of the persistant personnel you can buy in campaign mode and help you make a more custom faction.

I'd say this game is worth $10-15 US dollars.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A solid game that breaks away from the normal RTS collect 1-2 resources and then send your army over to the enemy to kill their workers because that hurts them the most.

In this game you're tasked with laying out a plan to develop your resources in a solid production line. Against the AI you don't have to deal with many hiccups, but unlike what the negative reviews have said about 0 depth, when you get in to multiplayer skirmishes you've now got to build efficiently, and take in to account what they might do to you.

For instance, there are 4 factions, each different than the other, if you can keep in mind the resources that each needs, you can punish your opponents my stealing them, or stealing their building, but this may leave you open to similar attacks. Then further from that you have to manage your debt, you might have a short term victory, but if they cripple you at the right time, they can send you spiraling in to debt which will stop you from further attacks or defense tactics.

So, to those who wrote 0 depth"

reviewText:
The game looks neat... but that's about it. Don't get me wrong it has a unique game style, and it is pretty fun for a few to a couple of hours, but not more than that.

GAME INFO-
Unlike other RTS games, where the player builds and gather resources to buy armies. Offworld Trading Company is mostly about economic RTS. The player has to claim certain lands, which consist of natural resources, and manage those resources by buying and selling on the market. Each player has a share in the stock market and the prices for the stocks will range on how well the players are doing (The better income the higher the stock price will be). There are special abilities that the players can buy from the Black Market and interfere the progress of other players (I will not give the details but players need to buy this abilities to help win the game). Whoever buys all the stocks wins the game.. and that's, that is how to win the game.

It Sounds complicated but it is not. You get the hang of it when playing the game for a couple of hour, but that's the problem. When you start to understand the mechanics of the game it gets boring because the game itself feels very... linear unlike other RTS games. Most RTS you have to strategize your moves and attacks to win the game, and there are so many ways and routes to plan and play which makes you hooked to it for days, months, even years. However, Offworld trading company has limited strategic gameplay... you just manage your resources in the best way to make you profit.

MY OPINION-
+Fun game :D for couple of hours.
-After that not fun :(
+If you are into this type of game go for it.
-If you are not into this game don't buy it because you will regret it when the game is sitting in your library for years and realize that you had only 20 hrs+ or less of in-game.
+Why did I buy the game? Because of Quill18.
+Why did I thumbs up? I had fun even though it was for a couple of hours, and I recommend this game for those who are into Economic RTS.
-But it is too expensive... So
+I recommend this game when the price is low and those who are into this game:p
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Short version, I liked this game.

Longer version;

At 5 hours of play I loved this game.
At 10 hours of play I thought this game rocked all out.
At 15 hours of play I was wanting more.
At 20 hours of play I probably wont play this game very much anymore.

Offworld Trading Company is an excellently balanced economic/base building/strategy game.  But in some ways it is too well balanced in that while there are 4 different styles of play based on the base you choose, those 4 different styles of play have very little opportunity for variation within themselves.

Even on the mid-range difficulty levels I found that you had to play a particular way determined by your base type and too much variation was usually a quick way to lose.

On the upper difficulty levels forget about trying something new, either you play a flawless game with a very specific and particular build order (and hope you don't get disproportionally screwed over by the black market) or you might as well not have bothered starting the level.

Now none of the above makes it a bad game, but unless you are the sort who has a hard-on for the multiplayer experience or grinding out every Do X 100 times" achievements OTC has limited replayability.   I enjoyed my 20 hours of play and have no regrets on the purchase but probably will never reach 25 hours of play."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was skeptical because this was early access, I liked the developers other works and I figured I'd give it a try.  The Economic RTS is really a big change as ♥♥♥♥ moves and market forces can really change a game around.   I really like how maps start unexplored and it is slowly releaved.  You can choose and deploy your colony at any time but waiting till later also has its advantages, if you deploy too early and spend a lot of resources trying to corner the aluminum market you might miss the massive deposit on the edge of the map.

OTC is really about picking the best tradeoffs to get you where you want to go, which is fitting as it's an economic game.   Each colony type has different advantages and needs. expansionists are good at the early game land grab, Scavengers don't need steel and get early warning for random events.  Robots don't need food, but take power instead; and scientists can skip some of the early steps of the production chain by putting factories right over resources.

The early access parts show in that some units don't have detailed textures yet, and they use text to speech instead of voice acting.  There were also a few minor issues I had like not getting an opponents patents after buying out his company.  Overall the game is stable and looks better than most early acess games on steam.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAn old Civ gamer here and Civfanatics follower. I have played one game so far, and decided to refund it. To be honest, this game has some very good ideas and also it's very nice to see something not combat related in the market. But during the gameplay, I cant shake the feeling that this is more like a visual representation of a spread sheet mechanic. At this stage, it needs to get a longer gameplay (too short at the moment) to be fun and a less simplistic approach (main stream will never play these type of games, you do not need to dumb down your ideas or the mechanics.). Also the end game is mostly decided by what you do at the very early, almost impossible to overcome the mistakes done at the beginning. Regarding depth, the game needs more strategic elements, less mobile-game like mechanics, more things to manage in both macro and micro, and the espionage/sobatage needs to have better visual representations, including some strategic ways to counter.  Environment being mars or somewhere else would have no effect in this game at all.  At this stage, this game is just like an iOS/Android game to have some quick fun but nothing more. It has a lot of potential, but seeing that it has been released on February and mechanics not chaning so far, I am not much optimistic about its future. More or less, in the core, this looks like what you will be getting when the early access ends.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a huge dissappointment for me. Yes, I know it's just early access, but the problems with it are already starting to show off and they aren't just bugs & like but rather core things.

The game feels extremely shallow - frustratingly fast paced matches, total lack of content: the amount of resources and production chains is 3 times smaller than in Anno 2070 and you have several factions that are almost completely the same save for some little differences in resource needs and HQ model. Graphics is almost non-existent, but so is sound acting which is far worse in my opinion. I don't care much about gphx but replacing sound acting with synthetic voice generation is not just goofy, it's outright ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

Play a couple of matches - and you've seen it all! But wait, there's also a 'campaign mode' with multiple rounds for same companies. None of your technologies or patents researched during a campaign round will matter because in every new round you will have to start over. Instead between rounds you hire specific engineers to increase corresponding building efficiency and get a bonus perk if you won in the round - this is the only thing persistent through rounds, as well as your stock value. I'm totally unimpressed by this 'campaign', it just doesn't feel even a little bit like managing a company but rather feels like being tortured by bad and exhausted game design. Generally the idea behind this game has good potential, but the way it's done here - just meh.

So far I don't recommend spending money on this game. You can always download it from torrents or wait for steam free play weekend and try it before buying to see that I'm probably right about it. If you want some good economic play - better go for Anno 2070 (but don't BUY Anno 2070 if you know what I mean, haha) or upcoming Anno 2205 (if it will be OK).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From lead designer of one of the highest-rated games of all time (Soren Johnson, Civilization IV) comes an entirely new kind of ♥♥♥♥ UP!

I was really looking forward to getting this game and when i did i was surprised to find at first it did not dissapoint.  I played through the training missions which had their own learning curve and difficulty and was beaten several times but its all part of the learning to play this game.  However after i finished the training and went into the campaign the problems started.

Firstly you choose your team and any purchases you would like to make before the mission begins, things like extra engineers and stuff and then its all go you and up to 3 NPC players battle it out.  You can imagine my complete surprise and shock when i was 10 seconds into the first mission and i get a heads up telling me that the enemy HQ has been upgraded to stage 2 already, ALREADY, they have the exact same buildings i have built so far yet they have aqquired the neccesary 80 aliminium, 80 steel and 40 glass in a matter of seconds, but it does not stop there.

The NPC has an unlimited supply of money on hand always buying up stuff from the black market that costs thousands of credits and giving the starting conditions they could never amass in such a short time, as i am writing this the game is minimised in the background still going and all i can hear is scientific colony expanded, and all this banging and crashing as their launching emp after emp after dynamite attack after pirate attack on me again and again and these are again thosands of credits and the cost goes up with each use.

Everything you build puts you in debt you buld one thing to cover one debt and another starts draining your resources so you build to cover that and another will start so you build to cover that and the first ♥♥♥♥ing thing you were trying to control is drainging you again, its just a viscious circle of shear repition and failings but your opponents are buying this and that and upgrading at a blinding rate and then like i mentioned earlier attack after attack after attack, your left with not much enjoyment at all.

Then theres the heads up you have lost this amount of whatever to piracy.... piracy? when in the hell did the game mention piracy? Oh thats right it didnt, you sit there and watch these messages appear every second one after the other in the HUD you have lost this to piracy, you have lost that to piracy again and again and all your resource rates are firmly in the negative forcing you into this bottleneck of no recovery.  This game could be fun but when your being steam rolled every match due to an overwhelming NPC and its never ending trust fund, fun is then a very hard thing to find and the game becomes stressful and a complete horror to play.

I want to like this game i really do but its broken, very badly broken and unoptomised i feel as if im just hosting an arena everytime i play so that a group of NPC's can battle it out and im just observing, hopefully future patching will sort things out but thats the problem with early access games you end up getting such a bad taste in your mouth from the game in question and alot of the time like myself, you never play it again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review is written during Beta.

OTC is an expansion/economics game which combines a procedurally generated map (replete with varying forms and quantity of resources) and a 'market' feature in which you trade the resources with other in-game players. The enjoyment of this game comes from using your awareness of the overall availability of resources on the map to predict which will become more valuable as the game progresses. Do well and your personal stock price raises; buy out 100% of the stock in competing players to win the game in the default play mode.

Matches take anywhere from 10 to 25 minutes in my experience and are usually enjoyable all the way through.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OTC is an interesting, if frustrating sort of economic RTS game.  Despite the fact that I have yet to actually win a skirmish vs cpu game (though, I think this is largely to do with finding my footing) it continues to draw me back in.  It feels a lot like a cross between Sid Meier's Railroads competition with a dash of Settlers of Caitan thrown in.  I found it enjoyable.

There is no combat, so hostile actions are all indirect.  It's all about managing economy.

This kind of game may appeal to you if you happen to like games like Banished, or any of the economy based Tycoon games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

We're on Mars. Resources are limited, and trade is king.

Who needs large armies or airforces? Not us. If we want to destroy an opponent, we can nuke their resources, buy up all their stock, or even EMP their bases.

The more you play, the more you upgrade. The more you upgrade, the  more claims you have on Mars. Be warned, just because you have more claims, doesn't mean you will win. You still need to make use of those claims to the best effect. If you've gone and claimed a bunch of resource nodes, it doesn't mean you're king, without the ability to smelt things.

Got that under control? But what about air, water, power, fuel? Miss out on those limited Geothermal Vents? Well instead of awesome power production, you'll be stuck with solar, which doesn't work at night, or wind, which is less than 25% as effective as the vents, when you first start out.

This strategy game requires actual strategy. You can't zerg rush the enemy base and win.

Conquer Mars using brains, not brawn.

Early Access Review

This game has a lot going for it. It isn't a military/war game so don't get confused by the Civ4 reference. I like the fact that it isn't a 2+ hour game, it's far less. There isn't much grinding in this game in single/multiplayer. More so in campaign on a low resource map.

Single/Multiplayer is enjoyable but may get boring after sometime due to rush.

Campaign seems to be more thought out and enjoyable. It has a lot more strategic game play.

There are some small bugs but that is expected for a Early Access Game.

All in all this game has a lot of potential, especially when single/multi becomes more balanced/finished.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OVERALL REVIEW:

8/10

ABOUT:

Offworld Trading Company reminds me a lot of a business simulation I played in college called MARKSTRAT. In Offworld trading company your objective is to buy out all of your opponents. There can be only one man left standing. You start and scan a planet for resources, and then select one of 4 factions: Expansive, Robotic, Scavanger, or Scientific. Each of these factions has several unique traits. Expansive has extra claims so they can build more, Robotic only needs power and electonics, scavanger gets early access to black market items and uses carbon instead of steel, and Scientific can put buildings that need resources on hexes that have that resource thus reducing the amount of claims they need to use: EX you can put a steel mill on iron without any iron mines and produce steel. My oppinions of the 4 factions are below. The game also has a black market where you can buy things to better your faction like extra claims/protection from enemies or undermine other factions with things like underground nukes. It also adds random auctions that go to your debt, which can really help if you need to save a geothermal vent for later in the game or are in desperate need of another claim.

-Expansive: (Best)(1) This is in my oppinion the best faction. The extra claims they recieve make it much easier to be the first to get a HQ lv5. This faction will generally be the easiest to get the offworld trading export rocket, which is almost always a sure win.
-Robotic: (Good)(2 Tie) No need for water, fuel, food or oxygen. Rush for electronics early and have some power and your society will almost never be in debt.
-Scavanger: (Worst)(4) Inless the map has high carbon contents and low iron, this faction is a no-go. See what I said in cons about the black market issues.
-Scientific: (Good)(2 Tie) Great faction for maps with a large amount of water or low iron. You can keep costs way down if you build your food supply and fuel/oxygen supply on this water. A great strategy is to build two steel mills at the beginning of the game on iron since you dont need an iron mine.

PROS:

-This is the most original game I have early access played since Minecraft. I think it has a ton of potential.
-The game is pretty fun, and I think it will be much more fun when multiplayer isn't just player hosted.
-To play a round takes generally around 30-40 minutes, meaning it won't take all day.

CONS:

-$35-$40 is just flat out too expensive for an early access game like this. This game should be in the $20 dollar range. I mean you could buy Skyrim for $40!
-Big issues with the black market: No matter what faction you choose or how early you settle, the AI will always get the first action in the black market, meaning that by the time you get to it, additional land claims will be more expensive. This in my oppinion, defeats the point of going with the scavanger faction.
-Random events are too extreme. In the real world an oversupply of a resource will not have it go from $100 to $1. I would like to see these events toned down. Perhaps a oversupply would lead a $100 dollar resource to become $40.
-Offworld Export Rockets are ABSURDLY overpowered. The first person to build one will generally win the game. Generally this will be the expansive faction.
-The game ends too suddenly. All of a sudden someone will get rich from the offworld exports and in litterally 2 minutes after this is built the game is over.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I do not write reviews for games.  I will also say that I quit preordering PC games due to the fact that a lot are released with many bugs (SimCity) and/or are stripped of many dynamic features of its predecessor, such as recent Civilization games.  However, I took a chance with this game as it is the first early access game that I have ever purchased.  I am shocked at the stability of the game and how much fun this game is given the fact that it is early access and within two days of release.  This game is worth the cash, especially with more on the way in regards to content.  I have only crashed once in my 14+ hours of gameplay.  Yes, there are things that could be balanced or added to increase the length of each map.  Also, I believe that the maps could be bigger, but they are nearly the perfect size for the current content.  The tutorials could use some work with directing you, but I learned quickly outside of the tutorials in the actual single-player after the AI beat me a couple of times.  Regardless, this game is extremely enjoyable, especially the single-player campaign.

The single-player campaign adds a new dynamic that I find intriguing.  You are against a number of AI opponents going for different locations on a planet.  You do not face the same combination of AI opponents, usually, on the different locations.  If you win the map, then you (or the winning AI) own the map and the perks/income associated with the map are the winners to use for the next location.  Also, the remaining AI battle for some of the other locations while you are playing your map, but never more than the remaining opponents can fill up.  For instance, if there are 8 players including you, then you choose the location that you want to play.  The location can have one-three AI players (2-4, including you, of the 8 total).  This leaves 4-6 AI to battle for 2-3 of the other locations.  After every match, new locations open up.  Depending on the victory conditions (how well you win), you increase in the leaderboard of that campaign.  As you move through the campaign, you use your income to buy new engineers to enhance or unlock buildings, same for the AI winners of other maps.  Each map is different in size, terrain, rules, and some have events such as “dust storm,” which lowers the efficiency of any solar plants built on the map.

This game is definitely worth buying as is and even more so knowing that the game will have more content added due to how early in the early access" we are.  I highly recommend this.

For those interested

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review is written during Beta.

OTC is an expansion/economics game which combines a procedurally generated map (replete with varying forms and quantity of resources) and a 'market' feature in which you trade the resources with other in-game players. The enjoyment of this game comes from using your awareness of the overall availability of resources on the map to predict which will become more valuable as the game progresses. Do well and your personal stock price raises; buy out 100% of the stock in competing players to win the game in the default play mode.

Matches take anywhere from 10 to 25 minutes in my experience and are usually enjoyable all the way through.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From lead designer of one of the highest-rated games of all time (Soren Johnson, Civilization IV) comes an entirely new kind of ♥♥♥♥ UP!

I was really looking forward to getting this game and when i did i was surprised to find at first it did not dissapoint.  I played through the training missions which had their own learning curve and difficulty and was beaten several times but its all part of the learning to play this game.  However after i finished the training and went into the campaign the problems started.

Firstly you choose your team and any purchases you would like to make before the mission begins, things like extra engineers and stuff and then its all go you and up to 3 NPC players battle it out.  You can imagine my complete surprise and shock when i was 10 seconds into the first mission and i get a heads up telling me that the enemy HQ has been upgraded to stage 2 already, ALREADY, they have the exact same buildings i have built so far yet they have aqquired the neccesary 80 aliminium, 80 steel and 40 glass in a matter of seconds, but it does not stop there.

The NPC has an unlimited supply of money on hand always buying up stuff from the black market that costs thousands of credits and giving the starting conditions they could never amass in such a short time, as i am writing this the game is minimised in the background still going and all i can hear is scientific colony expanded, and all this banging and crashing as their launching emp after emp after dynamite attack after pirate attack on me again and again and these are again thosands of credits and the cost goes up with each use.

Everything you build puts you in debt you buld one thing to cover one debt and another starts draining your resources so you build to cover that and another will start so you build to cover that and the first ♥♥♥♥ing thing you were trying to control is drainging you again, its just a viscious circle of shear repition and failings but your opponents are buying this and that and upgrading at a blinding rate and then like i mentioned earlier attack after attack after attack, your left with not much enjoyment at all.

Then theres the heads up you have lost this amount of whatever to piracy.... piracy? when in the hell did the game mention piracy? Oh thats right it didnt, you sit there and watch these messages appear every second one after the other in the HUD you have lost this to piracy, you have lost that to piracy again and again and all your resource rates are firmly in the negative forcing you into this bottleneck of no recovery.  This game could be fun but when your being steam rolled every match due to an overwhelming NPC and its never ending trust fund, fun is then a very hard thing to find and the game becomes stressful and a complete horror to play.

I want to like this game i really do but its broken, very badly broken and unoptomised i feel as if im just hosting an arena everytime i play so that a group of NPC's can battle it out and im just observing, hopefully future patching will sort things out but thats the problem with early access games you end up getting such a bad taste in your mouth from the game in question and alot of the time like myself, you never play it again.

reviewText:
If I had to describe what Offworld Trading Company is like, the closest games to it in terms of feel and gameplay are those from the Starcraft franchise, minus all the combat units. That sounded like a good sales pitch to me- I've played a bunch of Starcraft and Starcraft 2 and enjoyed them thoroughly.

The problem with this is that if you analyze a Starcraft game, the first few minutes are always the most boring ones- you (usually) just execute some well-rehearsed build order before you get to the more interesting and exciting parts where your units interact with your opponents'- and Offworld Trading Company never gets to that part, by design. There are no units, no army compositions, no micro-management. The entire game is like those boring first few minutes of every Starcraft match, but there's no payoff afterwards.

The Free-for-All nature of the game's standard game mode is problematic. The optimal move is to invest in raising your income and buying as much stock for your own company as possible and not waste any money buying your opponents' stock until endgame where the Offworld Market gives you (or your opponents) enough money to win the game. The extremely passive gameplay that the game rewards makes getting to the lategame feel like a chore, and victory does not feel very exciting. You can mess with your foes via industrial sabotage, but it doesn't feel very satisfying when you use it (whereas it does feel annoying when it gets used against you).

There is a frustrating lack of clarity as to the game's systems. Last game I played, I had bought out 2 of my 3 opponents, had the most improvements to my production buildings and the most patents, plus the most total land claims... and yet my remaining opponent's stock value was somehow 50% higher than mine. Why was it higher? I have no idea. But his higher stock value meant that he managed to buy me out first, so I lost- and I have no idea what it was that I did wrong, or how to do better next game.

I'll end my review by saying that Offworld Trading Company is a very innovative game. I haven't seen another game quite like it and I'm glad to see new concepts like this one take form. That said, for all its innovation, Offworld Trading Company is not a good game. I never really enjoyed any of it, and I would not recommend it to anyone.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Refunded...

A cool premise destroyed by a plethora of bad design decisions.  (this all mostly about MP, it fairs slightly better in SP)

1) there is NO need for this to be RTS... in any way, shape or form.  it has ALL the problems every other RTS game has... as far as MP is concerned, it just comes down to who clicks a little faster...

2) repetitive - you can not enjoy the mechanics of the game or take them in, AGAIN, because it is an RTS.  You spend the entire game furiously putting down buildings withut being able to take a step back and make strategic decisions or view your opponents moves... this is ALL you do...

3) a horrific tutorial that tells you all of nothing...

4) MP games last like 30 minutes... dont know ONE gamer who wants their strategy game, whether it be RTS or TB, to be that short.... not one.

5) Feature-wise, it is a $14.99 - $19.99 games, tops.

For me, a massive let down.  What bothers me the most, is that all of this could have been avoided with intelligent design decisions.  It is a GREAT premise and eventually someone else will clone this game and do it right... and it will be a massive success.  I suggest waiting for that to happen.  Soren shot himself in the foot here.

reviewText:
The game is not very deep in the sense that its pace and variety of game elements are designed to be more of a board game nature. On the positive side, that makes matches not as long drawn out and the mechanics easy to learn. The campaign is more a set of challenges the game generates, e.g. you can't build this building or that particular resource is very expensive.

Fair enough. Brownie points for originality.

But what really turns me off this game is the lack of traceability of why you lose a match.. Suddenly the AI just buys you out and that's it for you, while you stare at your ever growing debt, and wonder how the hell the AI keeps spamming out buildings and upgrades so fast even at the medium difficulty levels. It's very hard to recover from a bad start, no real gradient of improvement because once you optimised your base, the match is already over

It really feels like Super Meat Boy" became a tycoon game. It's made for masochists
date: who want to start over and over again."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOT MAKING A RECOMMENDATION ISN'T A NEGATIVE REVIEW.

With that out of the way, I like this new trend of using the RTS format to create a game of economic superiority. I enjoy the prospect of colonizing Mars, but I do have to admit that there only being four factions does somewhat seem like a limiting factor. Perhaps some other colony types along with a wider array of black market trickery and an expanded array of structure types?

Overall, I like the concept and would definitely like to see more updates for the idea. Unfortunately, at the present I can't recommend purchasing the game for $40 until it leaves early access. I do enjoy the idea, and don't regret that this is the first early access game I've bought, but I suggest to everyone else that you standby until they finish polishing things up.

reviewText:
Basic RTS game except you can only build buildings. After dropping an HQ building down you can then put down resource collection and/or processing buildings. Once you build something you're stuck with that tile, so if you later decide you want to build something else you can't move to construct to another tile.


Like simcity the game features random events, most of the time they are beneficial like a solar flare increases the power production of solar panels. Other times resource shortages or excesses cause price fluctuations. some events don't make sense like the random auction for a tile no one has built on.

Construction is limited based on the level of your HQ, once you hit level 5 you're unable to expand your HQ any further unless you purchase additional slots or a tile goes up for auction.

Solo player is pretty weak, in that you have 3 other ai players all competing" with you
date:
but are unwilling to target each other most of the time.

The game features a "black market" where you can buy one shot abilities like emp bombs that disable other buildings which in turn means that your stop producing resources and start incurring costs. As mentioned above you can purchase additional slots to build stuff on but that requires either an auction or a black market event.

The black market allows you to purchase these one shot abilities to screw with the other companies
recommended: you can buy beneficial things like additional tiles or sabotage protection but ultimately it feels gimmicky.\n\nIt's alright
hoursPlayed:
but seems like the focus was on how to make a RTS game with combat without shooting each other.

most of the time i played this on the max speed setting because i was just waiting for something to tick.

Sorta feels like im playing a 3D version of Democracy"
voteText: April 29
helpfulPercent: false

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you think Railroad Tycoon would be a better game with these game features, then Offworld Trading Company (OTC) would be for you:

1. You can bomb your competitors' train stations, railroads and related structures;

2. You can hire bandits to rob the opponents' train cargoes;

3. You can use EMP to shut down the competitors' train systems; and

4, You can sabotage the power supply of your opponents.

I'm a fan of business / economic simulators and I don't think the above military / criminal / terrorist means of competing should be the gaming mechanics in a business sim. When I play a business sim, I want to use business / economic strategies to outsmart my competitors. I have no interest at all in using any military or criminal ways to win. Honestly, no matter how much AMD dislikes Intel and Nvidia, AMD wouldn't hire criminals to bomb or sabotage the opponents' fabrication plants, right?

When I played Railroad Tycoon, I had the feeling of being the CEO of a growing railroad company. However, when I played Offworld Trading Company, I just felt like being the boss of a mafia business using criminal and military means to hurt my competitors. I don't like this feeling at all.

The game description says there's no military" in OTC but I think this's completely wrong and misleading. The in-game black market offers all the "dirty tricks" mentioned above to sabotage your competitors' businesses. I'm not sure whether this black market will change later
hoursPlayed: I don't recommend this game to fans of business / economic sims."

That in itself promotes hatred and discrimination to people who supported the developemnt when the game was utter ♥♥♥♥. those who shelled out 40 bucks get jipped out of a key for friend due to there was never any mention of a deluxe edition containing dlc and key.

Since it came out of EA the game hasnt changed much since, outside of a few graphic tweaks and asset changes for claims, and the new campaign UI it's still pretty slow paced unless you fast forward.

MP got a wealth of maps today during release from the Real Mars Map Pack DLC" which you have to pay (unless you were EA or bought deluxe) $4.99 USD ontop of the $29.99 sale going on till May 16th 2016 then it will be $39.99 + $4.99. But
date:
it does add 30+ maps which can only be used during skirmish and MP. So the campaign wont be given a boost anytime soon(if ever).

All you do is start small become big buy out everyone during rounds of mashed up skirmishes against the AI.

reviewText:
I was looking forward to this game.

Call me cheap but I don't often spend more than $15 on a game, I wait till the bugs have been ironed out and usually till games I like go on sale or I can at least check out a demo.

Other than the GFX to me the essence of this game feels like a mobile game - I'm watching numbers on the left side of the screen and timing my plays accordingly.

I have not mastered this game, not even close.  I can't see any patterns to the movement of the market and cannot successfully complete all of the Tutorial game missions (I've completed the tutorial).

I'm disappointed with this game.  I expected some form of data analyisis to assist me in my decision making - I played Eve Online for a LONG time and played the markets successfully there, so I'm not an idiot.

I wish it was a deeper game that I could get into .. it's likely going into my games collecting dust" folder.   :("

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are few games in my opinion that warrant a good review beyoned a few simple words. This is one of them. RTS fans will love this game. Strategy and long term planning is a must. There are no tanks, no soldiers and no real weapons in this game. Everyone plays right on top of eachother in a mad battle for resources and stock. The objective is to Buy Out the other companies stocks. You will first chose a class, there aare 4. Each one is unique in what resources they require the most. You will build buildings and mine resources and sell them and balance your money. You will set yourself up to buy out all of the other players stock. While this may not sound like much fun, the game is extremely fun in my opinion. It is a different type of RTS that you will come to love. The first day I got it I played for 6 hours straight. Addictive personality aside, it is that much fun. Please buy this game and support the growing community as well as the dev's. They have released a bug free polished game which is a huge task for any dev. The game is easy at its core to learn, but deep enough to keep you wondering for a while. There is MP, SP & Skirmish. They have thought of everything. Give it a go and you will not be sorry. Hit me up for a game too!

Peace!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is already quite good as it is, the price is quite steep ($40) for the available features and given it is only early access right now.
The concept is basically a real time version of civilization resource map/panel, but none of the army stuff.
Your objective is to mine the limited resources on the map and buy the other players out.

It's not deep (very limited tech tree) but there definitely has re-playability.
I love the concept and execution, but there is a lot more room to grow if they take the effort to.

My only concern is that the tutorial are basically simple missions instead of actually trying to explain the interface and mechanics of the game to you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Offworld Trading Company is a strategy, space economy management game where there goal is to mine and refine resources to turn a profit and buy out you competitors in the stock market. But they can buy you out so you must be strategic in raising your stock and NET value. No 2 games are truly alike as resources are abundant or sparse in different random map games or dependent on what is more commonly manufactured by you competitors.
I recommend this game fully other than the price it was a great addition to my collection of games.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've had my eye on this game for quite a while, and it's been developing into a very competitive strategy game:

Randomized maps force you to improvise and play every game very differently, and slow and relaxing phases with time to think about your strategy intertwine with phases of extremely fast-paced deciding and hectic stock market action. The futuristic setting on Mars rounds the game off into an entertaining sci-fi strategy title.

If you enjoy ruthlessly exploiting your players by hogging the rare resources and buying them out one-by-one, this game is definitely for you.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFor a game that looks like simple buying and selling this is surprisingly fast paced. You can't simply build a load of factories and sit on them, you have to keep an eye on other players and react to what they and the market in general are doing. There's that horrible moment where the buyout percentage starts appearing next to other player's names (showing that they're more than 50% of the way to buying you) and the scramble for as much cash as you can scrape together in a hurry. That being said if you're more of a casual and methodical player you can freely pause games with the AI to analyse your next move, which has helped me out quite a bit!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOffworld Trading Company is a realtime strategy game that is currently in Early Access. However, this game isn't about war like other realtime strategy games, it's about economics and business. But before that last sentence turns you away, I want to say that this game has such great potential for being a great strategy game. Your main goal is to collect resources, watch the stock market, and plan out your life of business on Mars, ultimately outsmarting your opponents and taking control of their base. The game looks pretty good overall and presents a refreshing taste on the genre. But because it is in Early Access, it isn't perfect. It may be a bit pricy right now, and the fact that the tutorial isn't actually a tutorial, and that there isn't a great amount of content to the game at the moment, but the developers, as far as I know, are putting their hearts into this game, and i'm anxious to see what this game has in store for the future. But don't get me wrong: This game is fun and addicting, and the price of the game will NOT go up when the full version is released as a side note.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edit/Update 10/6/2015:

Months after release, the game has all the bugs worked out and has fixed many of the gameplay issues I initially had with the game. It's a very enjoyable experience now, and I'm glad the title is in my library. I just wish I had waited until it was on sale instead of buying it at full price at release when it was unplayable.

Overall, it's a fun little game. Can be played casually or competitively. I love the depth in the strategy. Great balance and interesting races, while keeping the complexity low by making mechanics and game elements very intuitive. The game aesthetics (what most people incorrectly call graphics") are exceptional given the genre and studio size.

The one major gripe I still have with the game is that there isn't enough information given about how exactly the neutral colony operates. I understand that it grows as it finds cheap necessities available
date: but I'd like to be able to see more detailed
hoursPlayed: rather than just watching it plop down a new building every once in a while."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really like the concept of this game. In a game market dominated by games that use violence as the main driver of story real time economic stratagy games are rare gems. Video games are quickly becoming the major story telling device of the 21st centry and I would like to see Offword Trading Company embrace this. Please develope this game to teach economic and market principles like short selling, supply and demand, ect. The setting, Mars, also is a great pick. It ties into our cultural obsession with the red planet and our longing for a new frontier.

The game diffently needs some more work and polishing however. For starters the rounds are seem very short and the tutorial is not very good.

The possibilities for expanding the game seem nearly endless. I would like to see some resources and building types added. Some possible resources to add: white metals (gold, silver, platinum), rare earth minerals (lithium and others). Uranium, medicine, and art just to name a few. I would like to see more power options like nuclear reactors added to the building types.

Also more random events might make things interesting things like dust storms.

Update: This game no longer works and has not worked for many weeks. It crashes when you go to start a mission and even after two updates, an upgrade to windows 10 on my machine, and two re-downloads it still crashes. Do not pay for the beta of this game save yourself the money and aggrivation.

Update: After months of this game being offline it is finally fixed.

Edit: UI update ruined this game. It is ugly, extremely difficult to use, and borderline unplayable now. Game had a lot of potential but now I would strongly suggest avoiding it unless they restore functionality.

Very unique and enjoyable. Even though there are probably only about 25 buttons in the entire game, it's very different every time and doesn't get stale quickly. The multiplayer community is alive even in early access. This is not a click spamming game, you don't need  300 APM to play, but it is still an RTS so there are areas where a bit of speed helps. Personally I think about 40 APM is the limit beyond which there is very little difference. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Quick review...the game so far.

I got this game during its first few weeks of appearing on the steam store. After installing I got to the main screen then it would crash back to steam. Ok I thought, its in beta so maybe its something they are working on to fix. I tried a few times over the weeks and still the same issue....that is until their latest update.

I can now play the game <cheers all round>

I play quite a few stratagy type games so jumped straight into a single player game. It did not go well and was bought out by rival corps pretty quickly as my stock price was low and I amounted a large amount of debt! So I hit up the tutorials which cover very basic gameplay and could do with hints on the way to improve stocks prices or reduce debt/cancel out debt all together.

Yes there are diferent classes which have there own benifits/restrictions. For instance Expansive (human) require large amounts of food/water followed by power and oxygen. Robotic eats through Silicon and Power whereas Scavenger eats Carbon like theres no tomorrow!

So what have I learnt in the past 10hrs of play..?!

Ping quick at the start so you can find the best resourse spot on the map.

You can plant your HQ down ontop of a resourse which adds it to your starting inventory but will not regenerate the resourse like it would if you just planted a mine ontop of the resourse.

Try and keep modules attached to the HQ that way your not charged to transport across the map (Power also = fuel)

Solar panels are good but shutdown at night and thats where debt can mount up quick if your transporting alot! Wind turbines work day and night which give a steady trickle of power. Geo thermal plants work best as they operate day and night and dont require transports but are expense!

|

The game has a steep learning curve currently which is brought about mainly due to the tutorials included with the game. I found out more through looking in the forums and youtube. Doing so I won my first game last night.

Early Access Review

8/10
I admit I was expecting something more like Outpost... but it's not the surviving that's difficult. Base-building is deceptively simple, yet has subtleties that aren't immediately obvious - like connecting buildings to your HQ gives you free transport to them, while grouping them together gives bonuses to production but makes them easier to sabotage.

Once you start to grasp the way the competition works, though, and realise it's all about monopolies, resource manipulation and making good use of your scarce sabotage opportunities to outdo your opponents it really starts to shine.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edit/Update 10/6/2015:

Months after release, the game has all the bugs worked out and has fixed many of the gameplay issues I initially had with the game. It's a very enjoyable experience now, and I'm glad the title is in my library. I just wish I had waited until it was on sale instead of buying it at full price at release when it was unplayable.

Overall, it's a fun little game. Can be played casually or competitively. I love the depth in the strategy. Great balance and interesting races, while keeping the complexity low by making mechanics and game elements very intuitive. The game aesthetics (what most people incorrectly call graphics") are exceptional given the genre and studio size.

The one major gripe I still have with the game is that there isn't enough information given about how exactly the neutral colony operates. I understand that it grows as it finds cheap necessities available
date: but I'd like to be able to see more detailed
hoursPlayed: rather than just watching it plop down a new building every once in a while."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are few games in my opinion that warrant a good review beyoned a few simple words. This is one of them. RTS fans will love this game. Strategy and long term planning is a must. There are no tanks, no soldiers and no real weapons in this game. Everyone plays right on top of eachother in a mad battle for resources and stock. The objective is to Buy Out the other companies stocks. You will first chose a class, there aare 4. Each one is unique in what resources they require the most. You will build buildings and mine resources and sell them and balance your money. You will set yourself up to buy out all of the other players stock. While this may not sound like much fun, the game is extremely fun in my opinion. It is a different type of RTS that you will come to love. The first day I got it I played for 6 hours straight. Addictive personality aside, it is that much fun. Please buy this game and support the growing community as well as the dev's. They have released a bug free polished game which is a huge task for any dev. The game is easy at its core to learn, but deep enough to keep you wondering for a while. There is MP, SP & Skirmish. They have thought of everything. Give it a go and you will not be sorry. Hit me up for a game too!

Peace!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Top line?
'Its not like other trading games'
Worth a go while its on a good sale.
lot of it feels like placeholder material but the core mechanics are very well put together.

Pros:
>A unique concept
>Devs that care about improving their product
>Bizarrely, adrenaline pumping multiplayer action
>Great atmospheric music
>Intresing lategame mechanics
>short games 10~30mins a round
>genuinely varied starting 'races' instead of reskins
>low system demands
>great balance of simplicity and hidden complexity
>functional
>good UI
>Great artwork

Cons:
>No feeling of long term progression once a match ends, like a profile or vanity item unlocks.
>price point, sale price feels worth it though.
>There's a weird mix of extreme formal and extreme informal in the decriptions, popups and V/O and cutscenes that is often immersion breaking.
(I suppose that might have done to try and inject some fun into what was feared would otherwise be a dry subject, but it feels unessasary and over the top, the game is already fun, or perhaps some departments got crossed wires? either way, feels weird and a little forced against the contrast)
>Some of the voice over is cringe inducing, not just the pitch, tone and tempo, but the script too.
the black market is online" makes me wince everytime; sounds like a drunken Stephen Hawkin mixed with HAL from 2001 when Dave is pulling out his memory cards causing the computer equivalent of a stroke as they were talking.
Same when this disembodied anonimus robot starts telling you it "hates those stinking pirates"

The game is still in devolpment and seems to be having a bit of an identity crisis
date: with its contrasting serious fuctional content and its randomly placed goofy content
recommended: its still very fun to play with a long learning curve to hold intrest in its current state if you overlook the rough edges
hoursPlayed: which get noticably smoother every update."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A definite change of pace from your typical RTS game, and actually quite relaxing on easy settings.

There's a lot of interplay between the resources you scout for early and the market values.  Depending on how you start alone could change the entire challenge.

Right now, a game session is a relatively short experience, even on 'snail' pace.  But you're never too long waiting on anything to do, just that it ends quickly once you start steamrolling.  Personally, I do think there need to be some additions to make for a longer, more drawn out game.  Perhaps additions to the 'game market' as it were, such as land taxes, worker pay, and maintenance costs that scale with how much you expand in order to make that money you make more than just something you dump into a bank. (And we mustn't forget making those values something you manipulate that alters production and profit.) And of course, random events that further aggro those values.


But overall, if you're the type that play an RTS in that way where you like to watch your forces build up into a mighty base rather than actually attack and crush the enemy as soon as you can.  Try this game out.  Its current brevity can even be useful if you want to kill time, but not a lot of it.


Give it a shot.



Also, someone needs to get on the dev team and get some better quality audio for the vocal parts...  Decent quality graphics and gentle music, and then literally the microsoft 'sam' and female equivilent for audio cues.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Got this on 50% discount and I'm very happy with it. What makes me buy the game:
+ Beautiful visuals (look at those screenshots!)
+ Amazing animation when constructing a building or upgrading HQ (no kidding)
+ Hex grid, I like hex grid
+ Unique concept (economic rts, market warfare)
+ Daily challenge + leaderboards (what Steam is good for)

Being early access, there's some work to do:
- Optimization, seems to me it's not fully optimized yet in performance (varying between 40-60 fps for me)
- Heats up VGA card, the only game to ever make my GTX 555 reach 83% fan speed
- 1 of the 4 HQ (race) building in the game is missing its animation

If you find the price comfortable, I'd recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really like the concept of this game. In a game market dominated by games that use violence as the main driver of story real time economic stratagy games are rare gems. Video games are quickly becoming the major story telling device of the 21st centry and I would like to see Offword Trading Company embrace this. Please develope this game to teach economic and market principles like short selling, supply and demand, ect. The setting, Mars, also is a great pick. It ties into our cultural obsession with the red planet and our longing for a new frontier.

The game diffently needs some more work and polishing however. For starters the rounds are seem very short and the tutorial is not very good.

The possibilities for expanding the game seem nearly endless. I would like to see some resources and building types added. Some possible resources to add: white metals (gold, silver, platinum), rare earth minerals (lithium and others). Uranium, medicine, and art just to name a few. I would like to see more power options like nuclear reactors added to the building types.

Also more random events might make things interesting things like dust storms.

Update: This game no longer works and has not worked for many weeks. It crashes when you go to start a mission and even after two updates, an upgrade to windows 10 on my machine, and two re-downloads it still crashes. Do not pay for the beta of this game save yourself the money and aggrivation.

Update: After months of this game being offline it is finally fixed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Interesting concept. As someone that likes management games that make you think rather than click aimlessly I do embrace such games but it does need a lot of work still. The devs seem determined to clear out the issues but as it is right now my recommendation is pretty weak and to a big part hopeful thinking that they will deliver.

The logic in this game as it is now is flawed. Even being the best with profit and having the most structures you at times actually lose and nothing in the tutorial gives you a basic idea why.

Also definitely too high priced. 20 € seems fair to me with some mindset to support them but I really wouldn't pay more for this than that.
